name: Antonio TAJANI
text: The first item on the agenda is the discussion on the statements of the European Council and the Commission on the conclusions of the European Council meeting of 19 and 20 October 2017 and the presentation of the leaders' agenda "Building our future together" (2017 / 2745 (RSP)). After the proposals of the European Parliament, which you will find in your offices in a summary, we heard the speech by the President of the European Commission Jean-Claude Juncker on the Commission proposals, and today we will listen to the President of the European Council in this hemicycle, who wants to continue to be the venue for the debate on the future of the European Union. That is why, at the last meeting of the European Council, I invited the heads of government to participate in a series of meetings in this Parliament with representatives of European citizens. However, when things occur in Europe that offend our sensitivity, I would like to remind everyone that we cannot talk about the future of our Union, the future of the Eurozone, the future of our institutions, the future of our citizens, if we do not have the strength and the will to defend the founding values ​​of our Union. We are together, we are part of a community if we share values, we must always remember this. And today I cannot but firmly condemn what happened in Rome, Italy, where a group of hooligans used the image of Anne Frank to offend fans of another sports club. Using the image of Anne Frank as an offense against others is a very serious matter. Everyone in our Union has the right to practice their religion. Jewish communities are part of our European Union; I am proud to have European fellow citizens of the Jewish religion and I believe that anti-Semitism should remain only a horrible experience of our past, a horrible experience of the century that has concluded.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, as you know, I am obsessed by unity. This obsession was with me during the last European Council, but in fact it has been with me since the first days of my work in Brussels. This is why I rejected the idea of removing Greece from the eurozone in 2015. And it is also why I pursued a common position of the EU vis-à-vis Russia during the conflict in Ukraine. For many months I was building agreement among the 27 in order to give Prime Minister Cameron arguments to stay in the EU, even though this meant that each of the 27 had to make a sacrifice. Unfortunately, this was not enough for the Brits. After Brexit, I worked towards creating unity of the 27 in the negotiations with the United Kingdom. We have shown also during the last European Council that no one can divide the 27 in these negotiations. Striving for unity is also the main reason for creating the Leaders’ Agenda. Last Friday, all the leaders agreed that the priority for them is unity among the 27. This was voiced in unison. On this most important issue to me, we reached full understanding right from the start. The Leaders’ Agenda invalidated a dangerous assumption that together we can only stand still, and that we can only move forward when we divide. It is about reconciling dynamism and unity. About being ambitious and staying together at the same time. This, of course, does not rule out enhanced cooperation as the last resort, open to all, and in accordance with the Treaties. My intention is to build on what connects, not on what divides. But it does not mean that we should not stand up with courage to the issues that are – or could be – divisive so that we can find common solutions to them. I will just mention migration, the EMU and Brexit. When it comes to the migration crisis, I appealed from the very beginning to build Europe’s response on what connects us: on the protection of our external borders. I did so being aware that there are also ideas that put Member States in a permanent conflict. One such question is relocation: precisely speaking, the mandatory quotas. On this issue, consensus is as unlikely today as it was many months ago. But I do see a real chance of full agreement by June on matters like protecting external borders; decisive support for front—line countries (Italy, Greece, Spain and Bulgaria); strategy vis-à-vis Africa and adequate support for international organisations helping refugees and migrants – UNHCR, IOM and the World Food Programme; European management over return and readmission policy; and most of the elements of the Dublin reform. If on these matters we are really effective, we will be close to a lasting solution to the migration crisis. As regards EMU reform, following the publication of the Five Presidents’ Report no one should have any doubts what we need to do: everything is crystal clear. The problem is Member States’ conflicting interests. One of the first effects of the Leaders’ Agenda is the agreement to find potential solutions in the nearest possible future, despite these differences. I will do everything in my power to take the first very concrete steps by June towards establishing the European Monetary Fund and strengthening the stability of the Banking Union.  I still believe that this is possible. In June it will become clear if I am an incurable optimist. But one thing I can promise you today: if we do not reach agreement by June, I will say precisely why it was not possible, and who is responsible. As for the Brexit negotiations, we have managed to build and maintain unity among the 27, but ahead of us is still the toughest stress test. If we fail it, the negotiations will end in our defeat. We must keep our unity, regardless of the direction of the talks. The EU will be able to rise to every scenario as long as we are not divided. It is in fact up to London how this will end: with a good deal, no deal or no Brexit. But in each of these scenarios we will protect our common interest only by being together. We continue to look for the best way towards a Europe that is united, solidary and sovereign. Our quest must be accompanied by a constant and profound reflection on the essence of our community. I would like to say a few words on three of its dimensions. First of all, we are a territorial community, which means that we have a common territory and common external borders. Our duty is to protect them. The migration crisis has made us aware, with full force, of the need to rebuild effective control of our external borders, while the aggressive behaviour of certain third countries, and the destabilisation around Europe, has made us aware of the need to defend our territory. For this reason, we want to launch Permanent Structured Cooperation on Defence, the so-called PESCO, by the end of this year. In order to protect our external borders, we must build a model of durable and efficient financing on a bigger scale than ever before. It should become a part of our discussions on the future MFF. Secondly, we are a cultural community, which does not mean that we are better or worse – we are simply different from the outside world. Our openness and tolerance cannot mean walking away from protecting our heritage. We have the right and obligation to care for what distinguishes us from other cultures – not in order to be against someone, but to be ourselves. Without a feeling of superiority, but with a feeling of justified pride. I remember a great hashtag by one of your leaders, which said: ‘I am European and I am proud’. This is why the first point on the Leaders’ Agenda for our meeting in Gothenburg in November is culture and education. Thirdly, we are a political community. It is high time we renewed our vows in the name of our political values enshrined in Article 2 of the Treaty on the European Union. Let me quote: ‘The EU is founded on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities.’ These values are common to the Member States in a society in which pluralism, non-discrimination, tolerance, justice, solidarity and equality between women and men prevail. I would like to remind all those in power, all the Member States, that by signing the Treaty you have also signed this article. So either you respect it, or you clearly say you reject it, with all the consequences of this fact. Finally, I would like to refer to an issue it would be hard to avoid, being here in Strasbourg: the future composition of the European Parliament. For this topic, I have planned a special European Council in February next year. As you know, we must deal with this matter because of Brexit and because of the changing demography. I take all the proposals that have surfaced in this debate seriously; they are all interesting and pro-European ideas. I, personally, believe that the most natural solution would be to adopt a simple rule: fewer countries, fewer mandates. It is not only pragmatic and logical, but also what is expected by public opinion. Of course, such a solution in no way invalidates the idea of transnational lists. I am aware that this will be our common decision, since Parliament will be proposing and co-deciding on this matter. This is why I would like you to take such a possibility into account. When I was here in March this year, you may remember that I recalled a proverb: ‘If you want to go fast, go alone. If you want to go far, go together’. Today I feel we have a real chance to go together, far and faster. (Applause)

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: President of the Commission. - Mr President, Mr President of the European Council, ladies and gentlemen, my intervention will be brief because, apart from a few minor nuances, I fully share the points of view that were expressed by President Tusk and I do not I don't want to paraphrase what he just said, since I largely agree. I would first like to recall, in a spirit of solidarity, the tragedy that Portugal and Spain have just experienced. These terrible fires shocked us all, challenged us. This was also the case for the torrential rains which hit the three Baltic countries a few months ago. Solidarity is a key virtue of our Union, and when one of us is confronted with difficulties, it is obvious, necessary, elementary, for the European Union to come to the aid of those who are suffering. This is the reason why I have asked Commissioner Stylianides to reflect within a month - in fact, before the end of the year - on the remodeling, the re-articulation of our civil protection mechanisms, which are not working. 100 %. It is not normal that, when a fire breaks out on a Sunday morning in Portugal, we have to wait until Wednesday evening to see the first European plane arrive for help. We have to speed up the process. Until then, we will trigger, and check if they are applicable, all the mechanisms of the European Solidarity Fund for Portugal, Spain and the three Baltic States. I will not develop in front of you the proposals that the Commission has made in the area of ​​migration policy and the digital internal market. All the proposals that the Commission has drawn up are on the table in Parliament and in the Council, and I would like to invite you to speed up the work, in particular as regards the common asylum system. We are wasting time and it is urgent that we agree on all of these proposals. I I would like to pay tribute to the LIBE committee of your Parliament, which took the right decisions a week ago and I congratulate you on it. We talked about Africa. We are always talking about Africa, and I regularly call on the members of the Council, that is, the Member States, to match their actions with their words. We have set up an Emergency Trust Fund for Africa, endowed with 1.8 billion euros, with the hope - I must say naively today - that the Member States will make exactly the same effort. They did not do so, which means that the Commission had to increase its contribution to 2.9 billion, to be financed from the European budget. Member States have so far made a considerable effort to make EUR 175 million available to this fund. It's scandalous. Talking about Africa with tears in your eyes, and not doing what you are committed to, is unacceptable. (Applause) As regards digital Europe, the Commission has proposed 43 initiatives, 24 of which are legislative in nature. To date, the Council and Parliament have adopted six directives. It’s not really impressive and so it will be necessary - since everyone is talking about digital - to get things done. The same goes for everything relating to broadband networks and fixed networks. As far as 5G is concerned, we would like to speed up the work that will allow us, by 2020, to make bands of the radio spectrum available to economic operators. These decisions must be made as quickly as possible. Obviously, we discussed trade policy among ourselves, at the initiative of some of us, including President Macron. I reminded the members of the European Council that the Commission continues to believe that it is necessary and urgent to conclude trade agreements with the Mercosur countries. It's a vast economic complex. It will be the most important trade agreement the European Union has concluded to date. But we insist on the need to put in place mechanisms of reciprocity, which will prove to Europeans and others who observe us that Europe is open, but that Europe is not offered, and , therefore, more emphasis needs to be placed on elements that reflect the will to establish reciprocal regimes. Herr President, meine sehr verehrten Damen und Herren! In wenigen Wochen werden wir uns in Göteborg treffen, um unter anderem und vornehmlich über Sozialpolitik zu reden. Im November 2017 machen wir etwas, was wir uns im November 1997 vorgenommen hatten. Im November 1997 fand der erste Beschäftigungsgipfel der Europäischen Union statt. Ich bin wahrscheinlich der einzige, der sich daran erinnert, weil ich im Vorsitz war. In den Schlussfolgerungen steht, dass einmal pro Jahr ein Sondergipfel zu Fragen der Beschäftigungspolitik stattfinden soll. Er findet jetzt 2017 –20 Jahre später - statt. Ich kann mich über die Emsigkeit in Sachen Sozialpolitik nur wundern. Aber gut ist, dass dieser Gipfel stattfindet, und wir müssen dafür sorgen, dass die soziale Dimension Europas nicht ein frommer Spruch bleibt, Sondern dass wir die sozialen Absichten - die es gibt - auch mit Inhalt füllen. (Beifall) In dem Sinne bin ich froh, zufrieden, fast glücklich darüber, dass es uns gestern im Rat gelungen ist, uns auf die Entsenderichtlinie ist verständigen. Nicht alles ist bei dem gefundenen Kompromiss perfekt, aber dass es überhaupt möglich war - auch mit Hilfe des Europäischen Parlaments, auch auf Druck des Europäischen Parlaments -, in Sachen Entsenderichtlinie zu Fortschritten zu kommenimmung Lob. Dass die Sozialminister sich gestern auch inhaltlich, von der Sache her und von der Form her auf den europäischen Sozialpfeiler, den die Kommission vorgeschlagen hat, haben einigen können, ist auch eine gute Nachricht.In Sachen Wirtschafts- und Währungsunion wird die Kommission am 6. Dezember ihre Endvorschläge vorlegen.Wir werden in Vorbereitung des Dezember-Gipfels hier im Hause über die Vorschläge der Kommission in Sachen Wirtschafts- und Währungsunion zu reden haben.Heute nimmt die Kommission ihr Arbeitsprogramm für nächstes Jahr an.Dieses Arbeitsprogramm soll dazu führen, dass Europa einiger, stärker und demokratischer wird.Herr VizePresident Timmermans wird Ihnen, wenn ich richtig informiert bin, heute Nachmittag im Plenum das Programm der Europäischen Kommission vorstellen.What should I say about Brexit?I would like to say that the Commission is not negotiating in a hostile mood.We want a deal.Those who don’t want a deal, the ‘no dealers’, have no friends in the Commission.We want a fair deal with Britain and we will have a fair deal with Britain.‘No deal’ is not our working assumption.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: Mr President of the European Commission, with regard to Portugal and Spain, Parliament shares your position and the position of the Commission.I wish to inform you that yesterday I announced in plenary that you, the President of the Council and I have decided to donate the money of the Princess of Asturias Prize to the Portuguese and the Spaniards victims of the tragedy which struckthese two countries a week ago.

name: Manfred WEBER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, first of all, the European Council discussed the right priorities. First, about Brexit. We have unity, thanks to the commitment of all the leading figures and personalities. We underlined that there is not sufficient progress. We clarified that there is no cherry-picking possible. You are preparing a scenario for leaving without an agreement. I think that is a good step, and the business community - that is what we see from the London side - is getting more and more nervous, and the Brexiteers have no common plan for the future of their country, and especially the relationship towards the European Union. That is the outcome, and I look to what happens in the Council and we look to what happens in London. One thing is, additionally, clear for us as the European People's Party (EPP): if we are discussing about the treaty, the contents of which will, finally, be asked for in this House, then we are ready for a kind of a transitional period. But I have now to clarify that we cannot accept that a country outside the European Union will have the same conditions and the same status as a country inside the European Union, so there must be a difference. That is Brexit. The second thing is about innovation. I thank Donald Tusk for this priority: that is our future, it is needed. Combine resources, strengthen our budget: that is what we need, and we need clear projects. One of these projects is Defense Union - this was also a discussion. The EPP is strongly in favor. We have a momentum on the table to go forward with our Defense Union. One aspect is important for us. On the one hand, that we discuss about funds, about better financing of our defense structure, but I think towards the people we also need visibility about what we are doing there. I can give you one concrete example which we are discussing in the EPP Group. There is a new threat about cybersecurity which is on the table. We think that small / medium countries and even the bigger countries in the European Union cannot defend themselves alone anymore in this globalized cyberworld. That means for us: let's combine our forces, let's really establish a European cyber-defense brigade where we have this at European level, and let's make it visible with officials and soldiers who have on their uniforms the European flag, to make people aware that Europe together can defend our cyber infrastructure. Another point was the discussion about Turkey. As the EPP Group, we welcome the cut in accession aid. We must make it clear that we are concerned and concerned about developments in Turkey. We will do the same in the European Parliament with this week's budget: cut accession aid. In this respect we are going hand in hand in the same direction. And of course we have to talk about the targeted use of funds. Therefore: A commitment to the funds for the refugees is also necessary. But we also need more clarity in our relations with Turkey. And we have to be aware that we need a partnership, but full membership cannot be a further goal, as this plenary has repeatedly expressed. I was surprised that the Turkish President was recently in Warsaw and the Polish government, which is so profiled by opposing the influx of Muslims and strongly polemicized against Islam and the influx of Muslims, was of the opinion that the Turkey must become a full member of the European Union. The consequence of this is that 80 million Turkish citizens will then have freedom of movement in the European Union - that is, they can freely choose their place of residence anywhere in Europe. From my point of view, it is difficult to fit together. One can address that. Dear colleagues, we have the priorities on the table. But we all know that we are too slow to implement - that was discussed. I just want to pick one point. In addition to the Africa issue, which Jean-Claude Juncker thankfully addressed very clearly, I would like to single out a second point. We have had us count it: It has now been fixed in the twentieth resolution of the European Council - for the twentieth time! - that one wants to build closer and stronger European border protection. This has been decided for the twentieth time! And what did we achieve? 1,500 officials! I once had it converted: If you had such a distance on the border from Strasbourg in France to Brussels, there would be an officer every 33 kilometers. A border guard would be standing every 33 kilometers with what we have set up today. And because of that: There is talk, but unfortunately far too little is done. That is why we must use the next few months, as our Commission President rightly encourages us to deliver now, to give answers now. And, dear colleagues, we have a momentum on the table that people in Europe see - the survey figures also show that people see that - how valuable this community is. The Catalans and also the British show us that it is a risk to question this European Union. That is why we must now use this positive momentum to further develop Europe. And because today - I may put it this way - the German Bundestag is also in the process of being constituted, I would also like to appeal to Berlin that the new Federal Government in Berlin take up this positive courage, this positive momentum, that Europe has a bright future. (Applause)

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Council has taken note of the deadlock on Brexit. President Juncker said well: we are in favor of an agreement, but the stalemate is determined by the unpreparedness of the British government. However, the separation of the United Kingdom is not the only rift affecting the European Union. We have other fractures: from Catalonia to Northern Italy, there are forces at work that foment divisions within our Europe. There is a sort of selfishness of the rich, on the one hand, a reverse Robin Hood syndrome, which wants to take away from the poorest regions to give to the richest ones, and I am not surprised that the tax issue is involved. There is nothing wrong with wanting more autonomy - I am a federalist, I am for a federal Europe, so I want more autonomy - but not at the expense of solidarity. Redistributing resources from rich regions to poorer ones is not a charitable act, but it is the foundation of the citizenship pact. Europe then risks another form of secession, more silent and more dramatic: the secession of the least, the detachment of those who can't take it anymore. The forgotten of globalization are rebelling against the order established in the last twenty years. And the paradox - we must be careful about this - is that to ride the wave of this revolt of the last is precisely those who have taken advantage of the system of recent years: it is often the billionaires, the multi-billionaires, who give voice to the anger of the last. Many small Trump are also growing in Europe, as we saw in the recent elections in the Czech Republic. If we do not want a "Trumpized" Europe, divided and weakened, we must act immediately to heal this double fracture, territorial and social. President Tusk presented his proposal for a new agenda for the European Council: more meetings, more efficient and more effective work ... fine, but we need to focus not only on the method, but on the effectiveness of the results. Our Parliament has given good proof of itself: it has approved the revision of the Dublin rules on asylum applications - it is a big step forward for the European Parliament, taken together, a historic step - and it has approved the revision of the Directive on posted workers. , again a big step forward for the European Parliament. So we, as an institution democratically elected by the citizens, are answering specific questions that our citizens ask us on two fundamental issues, and we want these dossiers to proceed and finalize with an agreement with the Council. And we want to give substance to the social pillar, which President Juncker recalled. After twenty years a Council has been formed, now we are not making the social pillar a slogan, because citizens have their pockets and ears full of slogans, they need concrete measures. The posting of the worker is a concrete measure, but if we also give an answer to unemployed young people, if we give an answer to the marginalized, to those who have no home, to those who are thrown out of technological progress and must be protected from the effects of globalization, then let's fill that magic word - "social pillar" - with concrete contents. Finally, an affectionate recommendation to the Council: be zealous about these things and care less about how the European Parliament is to be composed. It would be very strange for the European Parliament to tell the Council how it is to be formed; we do not accept the Council telling us what the European Parliament should look like in 2019.

name: Syed KAMALL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, Gianni, I admire your idealism when you speak, and it is important that we all tackle poverty but I prefer community-led solutions rather than top-down. Let me just correct you on one of the myths that you highlighted, which is about Robin Hood’s motivations. Let us remember that Robin Hood stole money from the tax collector to give the money back to taxpayers. Let us remember that when we are looking at the Robin Hood story. Last week’s Council meeting highlighted one simple fact: that the EU is sometimes in danger of allowing idealism to get the better of pragmatism. This is certainly true when looking at the European Council’s and Parliament’s positions on the migration package and negotiations with the UK. The European Conservatives and Reformists Group (ECR) welcomes much of the Council’s current strategy in tackling the migration crisis, closing trafficking routes across the Mediterranean, strengthening cooperation with international partners, returning unsuccessful applicants and strengthening the role of Frontex. Two years ago the ECR published these papers that called for exactly these kinds of sensible measures. Maybe if they had been introduced at the time, then maybe there would be more confidence in our migration and asylum system today. Instead, this Parliament appears to have a position on adopting a regulation that throws out the rulebook and long-established asylum laws to pursue a relocation system which has not exactly been a success, with proposals which mean that an asylum seeker would no longer have their application processed or even have a first admissibility check in the country that they arrive in and continuing to force quotas on countries which have already said that they do not support relocation. This approach gives asylum seekers false hope and EU citizens false solutions. These proposals will not increase solidarity but they may increase voters’ frustrations with politicians. Please let us rethink the unintended consequences of Parliament’s proposals in a pragmatic way. On the Brexit negotiations, let us be more pragmatic. As a British MEP, who leads one of the largest political groups in this House, who enjoys good relations with people on both sides of the negotiating table and who, like Jean-Claude, wants a mutually beneficial deal, I hope that we avoid becoming trapped by the sequencing of negotiations. For there to be real progress, we must take a step back and look at the process as a whole. Just as there needs to be an understanding from the UK as to where the EU 27 are coming from, there also needs to be an understanding from the EU 27 as to where the British people are coming from. The UK joined the EEC 40 years ago because more than anything it believed in open trade. That remains the UK’s main motivation for its current relationship with the EU, and it will be a major motivation in creating the UK’s future relationship with the EU and vice versa. So perhaps the more the EU talks about the issues that resonate with the UK, it may find that the UK is more willing to give concessions on the issues that the EU 27 care most about and prioritise. On both migration and UK negotiations, we may all find that while idealism may be a wonderful way to view the world and sequencing may appear to be perfectly logical, it will be pragmatism that delivers the solutions that we all want to see.

name: Guy VERHOFSTADT
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all, I want to thank President Tusk for his intervention, and also for the publicity he has made for my hashtag campaign. Thank you. I am a proud European, so you are also an adept of it, Mr Tusk. And I have to tell you, after the State of the Union of our President of the Commission a few weeks ago, we got a speech at the Sorbonne by Emmanuel Macron, and we now have your agenda for the coming European Councils.  I have to confess that each time I have heard these proposals – this State of the Union, your agenda – I have felt an enormous excitement. The same eagerness that I felt when I was a young boy and was browsing through the colourful catalogues my mother received at the end of every year – the 3Suisses, was that in France? I think also in Luxembourg it exists. I think it is the Otto in Germany. The shiny things in these catalogues seemed always so far away, dreams on colourful paper, and to be very honest, that is rather what I am feeling today again – that we have great plans, that we have huge ambitions, but are we really ready now in this European Union to make the radical changes needed to make it happen? Because, Mr Tusk, there are a number of structural flaws in the European Union that we need to solve.  The first, as we know, is the unanimity rule that is still applied in the European Union, and especially in the Council, which has been blocking progress for decades now. The European Arrest Warrant has taken more than a decade to implement because of the unanimity rule; with the European Patents we had to wait more than 25 years because of the unanimity rule; the same is happening for the Energy Union – we do not have an Energy Union because of the unanimity rule; we do not have a fully-fledged Banking Union because of the unanimity rule. The Americans were capable in nine months to react to the financial crisis by cleaning up the banks, with an investment programme of USD 900 billion and with quantitative easing of USD 1.2 trillion, and we, after nine years, are still debating all this because of unanimity.  Maybe it is a good moment to recall that, because with the posting of workers the Council has taken a position for once. Why? Because they did not apply unanimity. For once, they have voted in the Council and have reached a position. So that is the first thing to do. Are we ready? There is a proposal by Jean—Claude Juncker to massively use ‘passerelles’ to solve the problem. Are we ready to finish this unanimity rule inside the Council and inside our institutions?  The second flaw is structural weakness: we know that there is a long, endless list of things, of doubts, of earmarks, of exceptions in our institutions. Are we ready to finish this Europe à la carte instead of continuing it as we still do?  Finally, the third disease we need to cure is what I call the ‘Potemkin syndrome’ of the European Union: that we always make beautiful plans, but without creating the necessary instruments, the necessary tools, or the necessary budget to make it happen. Schengen without the border and coastguard; the euro without the Treasury; foreign policy without a European defence community. So the moment of truth, Mr Tusk, is coming on the day – which is coming very soon – when we will decide on the new Multiannual Financial Framework. Are we really ready to implement these ambitious plans of Jean-Claude Juncker, of Emmanuel Macron, and of your agenda? Then it is necessary that we also be ready to open this financial framework and to give more than the former 1%, which is ridiculous if we want to fulfil all the ambitions that we have today. It is not really even 1% if you deduct from that the contributions that we received from the Member States and are going immediately back to the Member States; it is only 0.14% to protect our citizens against external threats, to protect our citizens and our borders internally, and at the same time to also organise the Currency Union. With 1%, sorry, that is not possible. To those populists and nationalists who are always saying ‘oh, this European superstate’, to have a budget of 1% and then talk about the European superstate is ridiculous and makes no sense at all. But that is the moment of truth. The moment of truth will not be the whole list of summits; the moment of truth will be when we discuss the money – when we discuss the budget, and when we discuss the new Multiannual Financial Framework.  That brings me, finally, Mr Tusk, to the remark you made on the composition of Parliament and the announcement that there will be an informal summit on it on 23 February. Fantastic! Maybe there are other things that I could organise to have an informal summit about, but you have to know that the legislative initiative for the composition of the Parliament is of this Parliament and not the European Council. I have to tell you that.  (Applause from the House) What I expect is for the European Council to back the proposal that will be made by a huge majority here in the House. That is what I expect! It will be a proposal based on the reduction of the number – that is a fair point. It will be a proposal that finally puts justice in the system with degressive proportionality, so that we do not take all five years to restart the work. And it will be – if everybody is of that opinion – a proposal in which we create a European democracy with transnationalists securing the Spitzenkandidaten. If I may give you one little piece of advice – do not open again the Spitzenkandidaten. We decided here in 2014 that it is an enormous achievement of European democracy. It is because of the Spitzenkandidaten that we have our President, Jean-Claude Juncker, here, and we will not accept any more changes to this system and this achievement of European democracy.

name: Gabriele ZIMMER
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Gentlemen Presidents! The last summit took place in an environment within the European Union that made it clear that the hasty assessments just a few weeks ago - we are out of the crisis - are not correct. Since then we have had the elections in Germany, we have had the elections in Austria, in the Czech Republic, we have the crisis in Spain - with a view to Catalonia. All of this shows that a lot is still in motion, that a lot is also boiling and that we have to face this together. You have now made it clear, Mr President, how you imagine that the Council will in future be better able to meet its responsibilities. You reminded the heads of government of their own political responsibility and - as I understood you - also made it clear that your concern is that responsibility cannot be pushed off forever, that important decisions that have to be made in the Council are not in the Nirvana will disappear, according to the motto: Lost in Translation, or will never appear again in the Bermuda Triangle of the Council. You promise that, on the basis of the decision notes you have submitted, it will be possible to determine within a very short time where agreement is reached, and wherever agreement cannot be reached from your point of view, you suggest that intensified cooperation can then begin . The following questions now arise for me: Does that mean that you have taken elements out of the proposals that the Commission made in the spring for the five scenarios and are already implementing them, without there really being a broad debate with the citizens and? Citizens in the European Union in the Member States? Mr Verhofstadt and others have also pointed out contradictions as regards the whole structure of democratic decision-making within the European Union. I would therefore I would also like to know whether the approval of the Leaders'Agenda means that there is a departure from the failed intergovernmental method that was once implemented by Chancellor Merkel and on the basis of which, for example, the fiscal compact was implemented - bypassing the European Parliament - but which obliges the Commission to enforce these intergovernmental agreements? Does the commitment to the political responsibility of the heads of state and government in the Council mean that the competences of bodies that are not democratically legitimized, such as the round of finance ministers of the Eurogroup, are reduced to the extent necessary and that in future it will no longer be possible this body, which does not feel obliged to Parliament at all, is able to impose large-scale conditions on member states and to significantly influence the lives of people there? Will the council clarify who will be the cook and who will be the waiter in the future? Or is it still possible for finance ministers to tell their heads of government what to do and what to think? What ideas did the Council members develop as to how the future cooperation with the European Parliament and also the national parliaments in this very shortened debate time, which they have called for and which they propose, will be concrete? How do we get involved? What are the consequences, possibly also for interinstitutional cooperation? It is no longer just the case that you can now say: We'll do it this way, that's it, and that's it. From my point of view, that won't work. The debate about the social pillar of which you spoke also showed that there is a need for clarification here. The Council received a proposal from us, the Commission made a proposal. But then it is first discussed for months how because parliament is then involved again at the end if it is supposed to co-sign. There is a need for clarification here, and that cannot simply be through postulating proposals. Only briefly about Brexit. My group is moving two things: We would like to have clarified that the Council defines in concrete terms what the criteria are between the Council meeting last week and the Council meeting in December, so that we can see that there is now sufficient progress. How do you measure that? Or is that more or less a political bargaining chip, and we'll see where it takes us? We are sticking to two points: We do not want the citizens of Great Britain or any other member state of the European Union to be punished for failing to conclude a treaty or for a no-deal. But we want a deal that ensures that citizens ‘rights and also the rights of the citizens in Northern Ireland are ultimately enforced, and that of course also includes sensible financial settlement. One more remark on the migration crisis. I have heard that by June you assume that you will be able to make progress on certain elements of the work on the migration crisis, to reach a certain agreement. But what I miss is a very clear announcement: an end to support for Libyan coastal protection as long as it does not comply with humanitarian obligations and blocks international sea rescue and maritime law, no criminalization of flight and no criminalization of international, private sea rescue operations.

name: Philippe LAMBERTS
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, dear President Tusk, it is always a pleasure to welcome you, and I am serious, because we are all convinced here that the consolidation and deepening of the European project will not be against the Member States but with them, and it is you who chair the Council. That is why, after what was arguably the best State of the Union address delivered here by President Juncker in September, I looked forward to hearing you discuss here your vision for the future of Europe. 'Europe. I must admit to you my disappointment, because in terms of the leaders' program, what you offer us is a schedule of meetings embellished with the subjects you want to deal with, a calendar ultimately like the one that our Parliament or the Commission has been publishing for years without anyone being moved by it. And so great news - heartily - the European Council is starting to organize its work. Who knows, maybe he will soon make his debates public? But beyond the joke, I want to point out the increasingly striking contrast between the institution you chair and the one to which I have the honor to belong. I would like to take as an example the asylum and migration policy, a key topic at last week's summit, during which you reaffirmed - and we obviously expected it - the option of fortress Europe, ready to pass the most infamous agreements with the regimes, even the most detestable warlords, so that they can assure us that none of these unfortunate people put a foot or a toe on the territory of the European Union. But, as no fortress, Mr Tusk, is impenetrable, it turns out that a number of our Member States continue to face the challenge of migration - I am of course thinking of Greece, Italy, Italy. 'Spain, Malta or Bulgaria - and they are left alone to face this challenge. It is of course the Dublin regulation I want to talk about. In June 2016, the European Commission, chaired by Mr Juncker, made a proposal to correct this unfair system. Last week, after an intense work masterfully carried out by Mrs Cecilia Wikström, here, Parliament improved the initial text so that from now on the Member States jointly assume the response to the challenge of migration and the reception of asylum seekers. 'asylum. Dear Mr. Tusk, I was in the Council press room last week and I went to listen to you at the press conference. I admit that I was flabbergasted to see you blandly assert that the Council would take up the problem in December, with the idea of ​​perhaps reaching a conclusion at the end of the first half of 2018, that is to say - say two years after the proposal made by the Commission and eight months after the agreement obtained here in the European Parliament. Quite frankly, when I hear of "Leader's Agenda", I think the terms "follower's agenda" would be much more appropriate. I would like to continue by talking about the fight against unbridled tax competition. Here again, while the Commission and Parliament want to move forward, the Council which you preside guarantees a standstill whose only beneficiaries are those who should be the biggest taxpayers - I am obviously thinking of the multinationals and the big fortunes. You will tell me that, on another thorny subject - the issue of posted workers, which has plagued the European debate for years - the Council was able to reach agreement last night. I am delighted, but it is on a text that is much less protective than the one adopted by Parliament under the leadership of Ms. Morin-Chartier and Ms. Jongerius. You can be sure that we will defend tooth and nail our text, which aims first and foremost not to protect the internal market, but to protect workers from exploitation. Mr. Tusk, I see you're interested ... I see you are interested, Mr Tusk, but anyway go ahead, there is no problem. Parliament brings together people from the same countries and from the same political families as the Council. So explain to me how it is possible, in this Parliament, to deal with subjects as complicated as those you are dealing with and to arrive at agreements that are both ambitious and supported by very large majorities, something which often proves difficult, or even impossible in the Council. And I find myself dreaming of heads of state and government determined to rise to the top. Their compass would be the conviction that there is, in the 21st century, only shared sovereignty and that their mission is to protect the well-being of all and not of a minority. Armed with their courage - because after all, it is they who are vested with supreme political authority in each of their countries - they would know, whenever necessary, how to give the necessary impetus to overcome national selfishness and political pettiness. Instead of embodying the force of stagnation, they would be the ones who would push the Commission to show even more speed and ambition to find innovative solutions to the challenges of this century. I am thinking, for example, of the digitization of the economy. How do we avoid creating a “cyberproletariat”? I am obviously thinking of the question of the ecological transition of our societies, which should be the Union's main strategy. It would be the Council that would challenge Parliament to go faster to find an agreement so that we are able to negotiate. So allow me to conclude by quoting a compatriot, Jacques Brel: "To dream an impossible dream, [...] to attempt, without strength and without armor, to reach the inaccessible star, such is my quest". This is our quest! Do not tell me, Mr. Tusk, that it is futile.

name: Raymond FINCH
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I say to President Tusk that we see that yourself, Mr Barnier and President Juncker have all stated that there is some progress being made in negotiations with Prime Minister May, and that the EU will evaluate progress on each of these issues in December. However, the underlying meaning of this progress is plain for all to see. The meaning is that the British Prime Minister is conceding ever more ground to the EU, rather than standing up for that which the people of the UK voted. The people of my nation voted not just to leave the EU 28, but to regain our sovereignty. What Mrs May is doing is quietly surrendering, so that we will end up neither leaving nor sovereign. We will remain subservient to the EU, both financially and legally, a nation condemned to serfdom by its own leaders. For this I do not blame the EU or its negotiators. You are only pursuing your perception of the interests of your project. For this, I condemn the UK Government. By its supine behaviour it has forfeited the trust of the British people, whether they originally voted either to leave or to remain. More than that, it has betrayed those who voted her into power at the last election, this Conservative Party that won the election with the slogan ‘Brexit means Brexit’. The fact this government is slowly backtracking on its commitment to the British people must stick in the craw of those who voted for it. Although the EU is, in the way it is conducting these negotiations, breaking the United Nations Declaration on Principles of International Law, which clearly states that no state may use or encourage the use of economic, political or any other type of measures to coerce another state in order to obtain from it the subordination of the exercise of its sovereign rights and to secure from it advantages of any kind. And indeed its own Treaty commitments to sincere cooperation and the progressive abolition of restrictions on international trade. The fault lies with Her Majesty’s Government for not having the courage of our convictions, and saying ‘enough is enough’. The other side is not seeking negotiation but capitulation, and walking away. Whatever the financial settlement Mrs May finally agrees to pay, whether it is GBP 100 or GBP 100 billion, it will simultaneously be too much and too little: too little for those in the EU who seek to punish us for having the temerity to seek our own path. For those ideologues no punishment is too great for those who seek self-determination. And too much for those of us who wish nothing more than to be good friends, neighbours, allies and partners of those we leave behind. Because this extortion will poison UK-EU relations for years to come. For the good of us all we should now shake hands and walk away.

name: Nicolas BAY
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, dear colleagues, trade relations were largely on the menu of the European Council. Mr Juncker, you have said that you would not want, I quote, our fellow citizens to regard any trade agreement as an attack on our main interests. But it is up to you, Mr Juncker, to prevent free trade treaties from being negotiated on the sly against the vital interests of our peoples, as was the case with CETA. Today, just a few minutes ago, you told us that you wanted to do the same with Mexico or Mercosur, that is to say that you will once again place our agriculture, in particular, in a situation of unfair competition. faced with countries that do not respect any of the rules, neither health, nor social, nor environmental, thus causing the death of whole sections of our economy. I remind you that in France, there are suicides of farmers every week. It is time to put an end to these crazy politicians, who are obviously in total violation of our rights and our vital interests. Regarding the posting of workers, everyone has understood that the agreement negotiated yesterday does not constitute a significant step forward and does not resolve the root of the problem. Key sectors, such as road transport, for example, are not even concerned, and you do not question the central aspect of the payment of social contributions in the country of origin, which obviously creates unfair competition, and that the posted worker costs 1.5 times or, sometimes, 2 times less than a local worker. In this way, you organize unfair competition within the European Union, social dumping and, thereby, foreign preference in our countries. Finally, with regard to Turkey, you mention, and I quote, a reduction in pre-accession funds. I remind you that Turkey also benefits considerable sums from the European Union for controlling migratory flows, which often do not yield significant results.It is an authoritarian Islamist regime.Whatever agreements may exist, particularly in economic matters, with Turkey, our position must now be clear.Turkey is not intended to join the European Union.Pre-accession or accession agreements must be ended.Turkey is not European, neither by its geographical position, nor by its history, nor by its culture.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: - Mr Chairman! The problem of migration is failure to respect the rules of the Schengen Agreement, which I hoped would survive the inevitable collapse of the European Union. The reason is racism in the European Union. When a resident of Australia, America or, God forbid, a Russian arrives and wants to cross the Schengen border without a document, he is stopped by force, and as a last resort - even fired. And if ten thousand Somalis, Nigerians or Nigerians come, they are let in and they get all their paperwork without asking. Law gives way to force. The Union is weak in relation to the strong, it gives way to the masses. It is strong against the weak. And it is a downfall if law yields to force. And to Comrade Pittella, I wanted to make it clear that he is right. Socialism is about robbing the poor and giving to the rich. That's why rich people like Buffett support socialism, they support the left, and not, God forbid, the free market. Besides, I think the European Union must be destroyed.

name: Elmar BROK
text: - Mr President, Mr President of the European Council, Mr President of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen! Once after the two presentations by Mr Juncker and Mr Tusk, I actually became happy and a little optimistic. The executive branch and the Council are slowly beginning to understand that we can only win Europe's progress and the fight against anti-democratic populism if we make progress in certain areas - progress that our citizens also see as more security. A decent Africa policy is security policy; A decent social policy - and therefore congratulations on the Posting of Workers Directive and the social pillars - is also security, a feeling of security for the citizen. This is particularly true of advances in security and defense policy. And what we're doing with PESCO is just a lame start, but we should go ahead here. And that's why we should finally not stop at 1% of the budget, but use the full 1.24%, which in principle has already been approved. And I think that we have to make that clearer. But let me make a few comments about Brexit. I would like to thank the Council, and especially the Commission and Michel Barnier, for maintaining the mandate and showing a clear line. If the Tories are having difficulty reaching an agreement that is negotiable, particularly on financial commitments, then this is no reason for us to abandon this clear negotiating mandate in the interests of the European citizens. I think we want to have constructive negotiations. We want to have a decent result, we want to have good relationships in the future in order to keep the damage of Brexit as low as possible. But that seems to be the case that the obligations one has, Mr Kamall, to use as a trade-off for better trade relations to be a somewhat strange entry point for me.We had agreed on the sequences.I think that is why we should move now so that we can come to the decision in December that the second phase should be initiated.And I'm not exactly sure, Mr. Kamall, who is playing Robin Hood on this issue.(The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – Surely, Mr Brok, it is not a matter of right that the European Union demands this money, it is a matter of necessity. Would you not agree with me? Because you are broke.

name: Elmar BROK
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure. - Mr Coburn! When I look at household debt per capita, I get the impression that the UK is facing a bigger and more difficult problem than most European countries, because its national debt per year is higher than the average for the Member States. The second point is, if you have debts, you have to pay debts. That is part of the policy of an honest businessman. If you have placed orders with us, you have to co-finance these orders. That's a normal way of putting things apart, and I think you should acknowledge that accordingly. The European Union is not a golf club that you can just leave and get your contribution paid out. Here you have made commitments, commitments to the citizens of your country and our countries, and you must honor those commitments to the citizens. And then we are ready to negotiate fairly.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: – Mr President, the European Union needs this ambitious road map to meet the future challenges. That is for sure. We can see a promising alignment of the European institutions – Parliament, Council and Commission – but let me be clear: we need to deliver on the road map with concrete measures. This means that if we want to have a real social pillar we need to translate these into measures, making sure that all people in employment, whatever their job, can count on a decent labour contract and full access to social protection. If we want to have a real reform of the eurozone in order to promote growth and convergence, we need to provide the eurozone with the fiscal capacity to help and support Member States in this direction. If we want to have a real European asylum system, the Council should adopt the recent reform of the Dublin system just adopted by the European Parliament. If we want Europe to promote a better world order, then yes, we need to use trade agreements, but we need to push the Sustainable Development Goals together with these agreements. These are very concrete measures to deliver on the road map with credibility, but the main test will be the next European budget, because all this ambition needs to be matched by a real overhaul of the Community budget in a way that enables us to meet these new priorities. Finally, like many other groups, the S&D Group is underlining here that we see the system of Spitzenkandidaten, the choice of the present European Commission by electing him or her in the European Parliament, as a major democratic development, which must be completely respected. This is our wish and our warning.

name: Ryszard Antoni LEGUTKO
text: – Madam President, there is not much that can be said about the last Council meeting. Nothing really happened that would amount to a breakthrough, Brexit being a case in point. On the other hand, this need not be a bad thing, considering that the hyperactivity of the European institutions usually creates more problems than it solves. On the positive side, immigration seems to be treated with conspicuously more sense than in the past. The President of the Council himself has admitted that mandatory relocation was not a good idea. It took him a lot of time to admit what many governments had said right at the outset. He should have listened to us, not those he usually listens to. There is also the problem of Nord Stream 2, this notorious and politically hostile Russian—German energy enterprise. As might have been expected, the Council failed to give a sufficiently strong signal to the Commission to dump it, the German Government being clearly supportive of Nord Stream. The Commission, which so eagerly roars like a lion when confronted with weaker partners, in cases like Nord Stream seems to behave more like a sheep; pardon the comparison. I conservatively predict that it will continue to do so. Let me now reply to Mr Weber. I want to thank him for pointing out the alleged – I would say – inconsistency in Polish politics and, by way of courtesy, I would like to reciprocate though he is not here. I wonder which is the real thing: what Mr Weber, representing the ruling party in Germany says here, criticising Nord Stream or the German Government policy that relentlessly carries out this impossible and politically dangerous project? So which is the real thing? Is it confusion or is it maybe, as some say, a deliberate strategy?

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: – Madam President, migration and the need for reform of the Common European Asylum System was discussed last week in Council. This was very timely, to say the least, not least since the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs adopted, on Thursday, with a very large majority, our position on the necessary reform of the Dublin Regulation. I have managed to gather behind me and to unite this House in a very bold proposal, creating a truly European Asylum System, and we have managed to do so through long negotiations and by listening to each other. Now I think it is high time that you, in Council, do exactly the same: listen to each other and start paying respect to each other, leaving national egoism behind. This belongs to history and not to the current situation in Europe. We can never create a functioning Common European Asylum System as long as every Member State is obsessed with their own national situation. We now need to create a fair system that works for all of Europe, with all its Member States. And such a system has to include automatic relocation of asylum-seekers and must be based on the principle of solidarity, as in Article 80 of our Treaties. The goal has to be to fix the asylum system, not merely to find some watered-down compromise that can reach unanimity in Council. It is high time that you take a qualified majority vote on this, because otherwise we will never change reality. I welcome that Council has signalled that it will continue working on this and set the goal of reaching a mandate before the spring. Negotiations in trilogues will be long and difficult, but I look forward to opening those trilogues sooner rather than later. The European Parliament has delivered, and it is now high time that you do the same. We owe it to the citizens of Europe who expect this from us.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: - Madam President, it has been said in this Chamber that a problem of the European Union is the need for unanimity. That being said by Mr Verhofstadt, it does not matter that he is not in the Chamber. Mr Verhofstadt is right about his concern, but he is wrong about his conclusion, because there is a need for unanimity where Member States are not equal and, to be honest, we are not all equal in this Chamber. Using the example of the United States brings me to mind the following: have you ever heard Utah, which is an oil-producing state, protest against Georgia, which produces only peanuts? The Cypriot President came here a few years ago and suffered on behalf of and through the imposition of the Eurogroup the haircut of the Cypriot economy and came back saying: "I came to Brussels reliable and I came back unreliable." Today, Mr Schäuble congratulates him on his decision at the time. The ruler congratulates the subordinate for the fact that he complied with the instructions. Not a word has been said by Mr Juncker or Mr Tusk about Turkey. The average situation, the "in limbo" situation between the European Union and Turkey is the worst. We must be clean. Either move on or stop. The average situation sends them the message that "we work for them" and we receive the message that "they work for us".

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: - Madam President, I suppose we agree that the situation in Catalonia is important, but I am afraid that in relation to it the European Union is accumulating errors. One. At the last European Council, the issue was not on the agenda. The idea that it is an internal matter is still defended and it is forgotten that it is internal to the European Union. La Catalogna non è, come ha detto l'on. Pittella, a frattura, è un impegno di maggior democrazia. Two. The Commission applauds the measures of the Spanish Government to supplant democracy in Catalonia and direct it from Madrid as if Catalonia were a colony. Democracy is supplanted and they applaud, how is it possible? Three. As presidents of the Council, Commission and Parliament, all three have received the Princess of Asturias Award in Spain. After listening to their speeches of thanks, it is understood that they have been awarded the award, but it is not understood that they have given it to concord, what concord? Four. As an MEP, I feel unprotected by the President of my Parliament and I regret that he is not presiding. He, like the King of Spain, has abandoned his role as impartial mediator. It would be up to the president to speak and mediate with all the deputies of the different options, which are not only the Spanish. It is a pity that some of us feel so far away and it is unacceptable. For all this and much more, it cannot surprise you if the Catalan people, traditionally pro-European, begin to raise serious doubts about the Europe that you preside over. Is this the Europe that cares about citizens, diversity and democracy? It certainly doesn't look like it. Democracy must be at the service of the people to make way for more democracy without suppressing it, beating it or imprisoning it. (He agreed to answer a question asked under the "blue card" procedure (Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Stanislav POLČÁK
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Mr colleague, I wanted to ask: do you not think that the European Union should respect Spain's internal constitutional conditions in this debate?I do not think it is appropriate to add this dimension to this debate.I would like to hear your answer to this question.

name: Josep-Maria TERRICABRAS
text: blue-card answer. – First, the European Union is concerned about all Member States, and it discusses events in Hungary and in Poland first, not just those in Spain. Second, the Spanish Constitution has been interpreted in the way the Spanish Government has said, but over 600 experts have said that having a referendum in Spain is allowed.

name: Rolandas PAKSAS
text: - The most important issue facing the future of the European Union today is in Catalonia. More specifically, in the view of European leaders, that people are allegedly destroying democracy. Let us finally hear the intellectuals of Europe say that the real Europe is a community of nations with their own languages, traditions, borders. Non-imposed imperial unity, created by lies and even the use of physical force, is the future of the European Union. Not the contempt of the family as a union of man and woman, not the replacement of Christianity by a surrogate religion with a declared solidarity. But compassion and a return to the most important things that unite Europe is the only way for us to survive in the community. Let us stop saying that events in Catalonia are just a matter of Spanish affairs. Let us remember the idea set out in US President Wilson's speech about the ability of every nation to decide on its own state. Dear leaders of the European Union, sit at the negotiating table with the politicians of Spain and Catalonia and help them find the most optimal and peaceful way out of the current situation. Mr. Junker, Mr. Tusk, you can, you must do it.

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: - (NL) Mr President, every conclusion of the Council is wrong, but the conclusion with regard to Turkey is truly completely unacceptable. The Council debates Turkey and concludes that Member States should fully implement the migrant deal and demonstrate full commitment to this cooperation. What a hypocritical mess! Chairman, Turkey is an Islamic dictatorship. It is a country that is killing minorities, persecuting the free press and throwing the political opposition in prison. The conclusions should have been: the EU must stop all accession aid to Turkey, Greece must tow every migrant boat back to Turkey and the migrant deal must be thrown away. Finally, the Council should have decided to ban the foreign funding of mosques, Islamic training institutions and Islamic NGOs. And I urge the Council, Mr Tusk, to adopt these conclusions next time. (The speaker addressed a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8))

name: Doru-Claudian FRUNZULICĂ
text: blue-card question. – Taking into consideration the importance of Turkey for the European Union’s security and stability, do you not think it is better to cooperate, to have cooperation of some kind with Turkey instead of having Turkey as an enemy, or as a foe, of the European Union? Do you not think it is better to cooperate with Turkey?

name: Marcel de GRAAFF
text: "blue card" answer.- (NL) Mr President, there are many ways to cooperate with Turkey.This is about Turkey's accession to the European Union.We absolutely do not want that.Cooperate with Turkey, yes, trade with Turkey.But is Turkey a reliable military partner?Turkey has also already bought S400 weapon systems from Russia.And that is our NATO member, our NATO partner.I would say: Turkey is so unreliable that you should not do business with it.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Madam President, most of us watching from the United Kingdom were pleased to see that the Council meeting ended up in a better mood, and a better spirit, of cooperation than what we have previously seen. I welcome the progress that seems to have been made in moving towards trade negotiations, hopefully in December. The United Kingdom seeks a deal that is mutually beneficial. It seeks a deal that recognises a strong, independent United Kingdom, cooperating and working beside a European Union. That cooperation can be in areas of defence, areas of the economy and things that are important to all of us. Can I say, in respect of Northern Ireland, that I fear that these institutions are in danger of overreach? The guarantors of the Belfast Agreement are the British and Irish Governments, not the European institutions. While Europe has been enormously helpful in building peace, we need to remember who are the primary operators and the primary legislators in this particular area. It is most important.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: Mr Coburn wants to ask a blue-card question but he has already had a blue card. I am going to be a bit restrictive on this occasion, so one blue card only. I apologise but I have made my decision.

name: Janusz LEWANDOWSKI
text: - Madam President! The most desirable public good in contemporary Europe is a sense of security. This is the greatest deficit of our time and the most important field of confrontation with left-wing and right-wing populism that lives by fueling human fears. It is also the best measure of the credibility of European institutions. Reading the conclusions of the last Council in this regard, one can be moderately optimistic, because the chaos of 2015 in 2017 is turning into migration management. Instead of treating symptoms under the pressure of time and events, there is prevention, reaching the root of the problem, guessing new threats, and not just automatic relocation, which in my opinion has no great future in the European Union. I am pleased that the European Parliament is involved in making a good contribution to the reform of asylum law. Now a few words about the Leaders' Agenda in the aspect that interests me most, namely the future of the EU budget. It is not hard to see that the Leaders' Agenda calendar does not exactly match the State of the Union address and the resolution that Parliament will adopt today, which expresses the desire to complete negotiations and reach an agreement for the post-2020 period ahead of the 2019 European elections. these conversations, sharing our doubts and remembering that it has taken us two and a half years recently. But I see in this Parliament position something more than wishful thinking, I see in it the determination to show that the Union can act and compromise on the most difficult issues. It is such a European "yes, we can". Therefore, knowing that we will not do it without leaders, without heads of governments, it is imperative that scenarios be agreed between European institutions in order to go together and go fast.

name: Tanja FAJON
text: - Last year at this time, migrants woke up on the island of Lesbos in deep snow. Temperatures slipped to almost minus 18 degrees. Some of them have been trapped on the Greek islands for almost two years. And European leaders insist that the agreement with Turkey works and that you will also close the central Mediterranean route along the Western Balkan route. Instead of accelerating the search for safe and legal routes for people eligible for international protection in parallel with the funding and training of the Libyan Coast Guard, you are paying full attention to how to prevent migrants from entering Europe. Instead of doing too little or nothing, we could be working on a radical reform of the European asylum system. We adopted a good proposal in Parliament last week, according to which the burden will no longer be on the country of entry alone. We agreed on the need for a permanent and automatic mechanism for the transfer of people, in which all Member States will participate. We now also expect this agreement from European governments. Due to the non-functioning European asylum policy, we have internal border control in a number of Schengen countries. In May this year, Commissioner Avramopoulos said that Austria, Germany, Denmark, Sweden and Norway would only be able to extend internal controls once again for the last time. Six months later, Austria maintains internal control on the border with Slovenia, for which there is absolutely no reason. Therefore, your conclusions, Mr Presidency, that you are committed to Schengen are not sincere, and I am sorry that is the case.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: – Madam President, I would like to remind the House that I was against Brexit. Mr Brok, you mentioned the term ‘golf club’. Let me also remind you that the European Union was, from the viewpoint of the British, once a football club. If the management of the club changes the football club to a golf club, then I wonder who has really left whom. I think it is time that we also criticised the negotiation strategy of the Commission and the Council. It is illogical, it is dangerous, and I think it is unfair. It is illogical because the EU insists on a financial offer by the British Government before any agreement on trade. I just wonder, Mr Juncker, would you ever agree on a price for something when you do not know what you are buying.  It is dangerous because everybody here agrees that peace in Ireland must be preserved at all costs. Nowhere in the world is there a border arrangement without a trade or customs arrangement. How will you ever get such an agreement without negotiations on trade? Finally, it is grossly unfair. Mr Tusk, you have mentioned European values many times. Let me remind you of the fact that democracy, freedom of the press and human rights are not European values; they are universal values. I would also like to remind you that we have British values, one of which is fairness, and it is about time that you recognise fairness as a European value. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)

name: Elmar BROK
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr. Henkel, whoever is negotiating here, I don't want to hear from you now.But every phase of the development of the European Union - from the Single Act promoted by Mrs Thatcher, from Maastricht, from Nice, from Amsterdam to the Treaty of Lisbon - has been ratified by a qualified majority in the House of Commons.Therefore one cannot say that it was forced upon them.They helped negotiate it, and they decided it in their parliament.Don't tell stories like that from back then.

name: Hans-Olaf HENKEL
text: blue-card answer. – The British entered the European Union under three conditions: subsidiarity, self—responsibility for a country’s debts and competition. You can find all three factors in the Lisbon Treaty. In the course of various attempts to save the euro, these three principles have been grossly violated, and that led to a continuous centralisation and bureaucratisation of the European Union, and that finally contributed to Brexit.

name: Sofia SAKORAFA
text: - Mr President, I have read and listened carefully to the conclusions of the European Council and the positions of the Commission. We will discuss PESCO and security and defense issues at length in the coming months. For relations with Turkey, a proposal is made that says nothing but Parliament's repeated resolutions. As for the refugee, four pages aiming at a fortress Europe and a single paragraph with vagueness to address the causes of immigration and refugees. You describe collaborations with Libya and neighboring countries on the verge of destabilization and blackmail them with development funds, trade and visas with the aim of trapping refugees and migrants in camps. You know for sure that this is a time bomb that will soon explode and we will all pay the heavy price. Politics divides you. It divides Europe and unfortunately some continue to invest in temporary profits. So I'm curious about the vision of what Europe you will then speak to the peoples.

name: Ernest URTASUN
text: - Madam President, Mr Tusk, Mr Juncker. Listening to the Commission's spokesman - Mr Margaritis - yesterday, it would seem that you are considering the Catalan question as closed: 155 applies and nothing has happened here. Nothing could be further from the truth: we are three days away from a real disaster. The intervention of the Generalitat implies the intervention of an institution reestablished before the promulgation of the 1978 Constitution and it will lead us to a political and social crisis of enormous dimensions and, furthermore, this will be added to the arrests of two Catalan civil society people who are two unjust and arbitrary arrests. And, on the other hand, we also continue to have on the table a possible unilateral declaration of independence that does not generate consensus in Catalan society and that is also a very serious error. We are three days away from the disaster, and I tell you that there are many anguished citizens in Catalonia waiting for an answer. If our leaders are unable to dialogue, to speak and to reach a consensus that establishes a negotiated solution, the citizens of Catalonia expect from the President of the Council, his Council and its European Commission a suitable response.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: – Madam President, I would briefly like to say something about the asylum policies. Mr Tusk very proudly announced that they will, at some point in 2018, agree on border control, but that is actually not the same as a proper asylum policy. Fortress Europe: that is what the Council is trying to build – keeping people out – and it is remarkable that this House, with 751 MEPs representing more than 200 political parties, is able to come to agreement. We are one legislator and the Council, with 28 individuals, is totally unable to reach agreement on one of the most important challenges of this moment.  I think that is totally irresponsible and only shows the total bankruptcy of the intergovernmental method. I really hope that the Council is now going to move forward on the files that have been adopted here – Dublin, the reception conditions – because we have been waiting. We voted on reception conditions almost half a year ago. The Council is completely paralysed and we cannot wait until next summer for a solution. We need a decision by the Council now; it is their responsibility.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: - Madam President! As for the composition of Parliament, as Donald Tusk mentioned, I agree with Donald Tusk when he says that fewer countries should also mean fewer seats. It is common sense, and it is appreciated by the people as well. The summit in Gothenburg is at the door, as we know. I think you all know that I am deeply critical of the European Union, but I am also a pragmatic person. As long as my country Sweden is a member, something must be done to stop the social dumping we see in the labor market. Those who say that we have order and order in the Swedish labor market, they have probably not been out for quite some time and visited the Swedish labor market. Nor have they probably seen how the domestic transport market, for example, is being smashed by foreign players who are dumping wages on Swedish companies. The construction industry is flooded with rogue actors who exploit labor in a ruthless way. People are sacrificing on the altar of profit, and I cannot support that. I would like to see Sweden leave this house and cooperation, but as long as we remain here, we must still make sure that we get an end to this circus. Feel free to come to Sweden; when you are in our country, you must compete under the same cost picture as the swedish companies have.

name: Harald VILIMSKY
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! If we now look back to the debate in the Council on October 19 and see that migration was once again one of the dominant issues, then all we can say is that there is a lack of determination, there is a lack of assertiveness and there is also a lack of it Independence, because again you rely on Turkey, knowing that Turkey is not a reliable partner. It would be much smarter if one finally strives to implement the plans that have existed for a long time to look for childcare options in the regions themselves. It came from Germany, from Interior Minister Schily, from Interior Minister de Maizière; the Commission was considering finding childcare facilities in the regions themselves. You don't do it.
