For example, let's look at Libya, where more help is needed, let's look at Lebanon, where more help is needed. Let's see if we can create agreements with Tunisia, Algeria, and Morocco to keep the people in the region and not to enable a policy of exodus from Africa to Europe. Second point: Turkey, which was also an issue. 640 million in pre-accession aid will be paid; I think that by 2020 it will be over four or four and a half billion euros, although Erdoğan himself says he no longer wants to go to the EU and here too the call to break off the negotiations is growing ever stronger. Therefore: Please follow the call, break off negotiations between the European Union and Turkey about membership in the European Union!

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Madam President, Halloween is nearly here and, on cue, the European Union rises to the occasion with two positions and two leaders. Truly, European Union Jekyll and Hyde politics is alive and kicking. What have we learned in the last couple of weeks? We have learned that insufficient progress should be translated as ‘give us more money’. With Ms Merkel looking to finance budget matters, trying to handle a EUR 100 billion deficit in her own country and knowing that no Member State will cover the deficit created by the Brexit negotiations, it is no wonder that is happening.  Then we get this document and all those arch-federalists here, I am sure you are delighted with the fact that Mr Juncker and President Macron have authored this. For anybody proud of their country and proud of sovereignty, this is not the document that Brexit supports and, thankfully, Brexit will happen.

name: Franck PROUST
text: - Madam President, the last European Council showed that Heads of State or Government understood the messages that we have been sending for months. The agreement reached last night in the Council on the revision of the directive on the posting of workers shows this. The fight against social dumping and unfair competition is the priority in Europe. We will achieve this thanks, in particular, to the work carried out by our colleague Élisabeth Morin-Chartier. As regards the control of migratory flows and the fight against illegal immigration, it is a matter of insisting on the strengthening and application of readmission agreements with foreign countries and, above all, of making European aid conditional on results. tangible, because third countries also have some responsibility. Strengthening the resources of the European Border and Coast Guard Agency is also fundamental in order to continue to better protect our borders. Citizens also expect concrete results for their security. The Commission recently announced the mobilization of a fund of more than 100 million euros to finance equipment to fight threats in public places. We should be happy about it. This increased security will also require the construction of a European defense worthy of the name. However, in order to be effective, the permanent structured cooperation launched last June must be a reality shared by all the Member States, in parallel with the development of a European industrial development program in the field of defense. I regret, however, the lack of clarity in our external relations. In the Council conclusions, only one line is dedicated to our relationship with Turkey. Although common interests unite us, too many fundamental differences separate us from this country. Let’s finally get out of the ambiguity and hypocrisy. Citizens and economic players expect clarity. Let's say once and for all that the partnership with Turkey will not go through membership of the European Union.Finally, for Brexit, there is certainly diplomacy, but also a political dimension.Let’s fully respect our red lines and, most importantly, divorce first before stabilizing a future relationship.It is by being clear about who we are and what we want that we will move a Europe forward with coherence.

name: Victor BOŞTINARU
text: – Madam President, the EU’s security and defence is not only PESCO, but PESCO is certainly an essential element of today’s European security and defence and is a powerful tool to help in the long path towards truly integrated European defence. This is why we strongly welcome what we hope can be considered a promise that, by the end of this year, PESCO will become a reality.  Until recently, the logic of national sovereignty prevailed over the logic of integration in the defence field, but in the current circumstances the EU can no longer afford this. Now that all the necessary work has been done to prepare the framework for PESCO, it is time for the Member States to take the final step and notify their readiness to take part in permanent structured cooperation. As I will never stop repeating, we are well aware that some Member States are more ready and more capable of joining PESCO from the outset, but that must not prevent the others from joining as soon as they are ready, on the basis of the same predetermined criteria applying to all forms of enhanced cooperation. Accordingly, I will invite the national parliaments, firstly, to debate and follow the implementation of the common security and defence policy and PESCO with a view to defining space for further progress on integration. Secondly, I will invite the European Parliament to strengthen its partnership and cooperation with the national parliaments in the area of defence and PESCO.  I have one final question for President Tusk. When will the Council implement the Commission’s proposal to invite Romania and Bulgaria to join Schengen as soon as possible as full members? This is becoming a sort of Carthage for Romanians and Bulgarians.

name: Sander LOONES
text: Thank you, Madam President. My mailbox has recently been full of messages about Catalonia and Turkey. Last week there was that summit of the European government leaders in Brussels and there was talk about Turkey and about the fact that Mr Erdoğan cannot join the European Union. A good thing. Finally I would say. Although it could be a bit more. But not a word has been said about Catalonia, about Catalonia. In Europe, however, often and many expensive words are used about freedom of expression, about political refugees, about democracy, about respect for the rule of law. European politicians are often among the first to teach the world lessons. Finger in the air. But today the rule of law is under attack under our noses, in the European Union. People are being imprisoned politically here in Europe. And not a word about that. Not a word in the conclusions of the European Council. Not a word on the agenda of this Parliament in Strasbourg this week. Well, in veiled terms, a statement from Mr. Tusk just now - fortunately. But for the rest mainly very selective indignation. And that shows the hypocrisy in these European institutions. There is only one term for that: shame!

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: - Madam President, the results of last week's meeting of the Heads of State and Government of the European Union do not constitute a substantial step forward on the open issues facing the Union. The results of the meeting are mostly general repetitions of known policies, at a time when problems are exacerbated. In particular with regard to immigration, more courage and more solidarity is required between Member States. Immigration and refugee flows are not just a problem in Greece or Italy. It is Europe 's problem and Europe must manage them centrally. However, I would like to welcome President Tusk's statement that the Council has authorized the Commission to consider limiting Turkey's pre-accession funding. The Erdogan regime is moving further and further away from democratic principles, and Europe must react accordingly.

name: Laura FERRARA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, in the years 2016 and 2017 almost 300 000 migrants, more than half of those who arrived across Europe, disembarked in Italy and around 60% of them are not entitled to some form of international protection . In addition to the usual statements of principle of the European Council, it is not possible to make any concrete commitment on how the solidarity welcome between Member States must be divided, especially due to those countries that close their doors and raise barriers, while in Parliament it is propagated as revolutionary a Dublin reform that cancels only on paper the principle of the country of first arrival. With the introduction of criteria and filters that will leave economic migrants in the first countries of arrival, of a relocation mechanism that will neither be immediate nor automatic and which will be activated only after security checks and after the prior examination of the asylum application , without the provision of the unemployment rate to redistribute asylum seekers, this European disunion misses another opportunity to fully implement the principles of solidarity and fair sharing of responsibilities provided for in Article 80 of the Treaty.

name: Gerolf ANNEMANS
text: - (NL) Mr President, with the somewhat bombastic term "Leaders Agenda", Mr Tusk has explained its most important principle here: the preservation of unity. Allow me to say that it is a totally outdated and sclerosed vision, that preservation of unity. The new era, which I advocate, is one that is opposed to centralization and bureaucratisation, and which harks back to the origins of European cooperation, namely starting from its own identity and cooperation on the basis of subsidiarity. The differences that make up Europe's strength must take precedence over this weird, somewhat weird unity. So, on behalf of more and more peoples, I oppose the acceleration that you have declared here after the French, after the Dutch, after the German elections. You forget for a moment that Austrian and Czech elections have now also been launched, all illustrating one thing: the power of the new era. You should not oppose this. You must go along with that and you must have less European Union instead of more.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: - Madam president. Thanks for your schedule, Mr. Tusk. Europe has been built from politics and ambition, and only with politics and ambition can we have a secure future. Sixty years after the signing of the Treaties of Rome, we Europeans are still different, but now we are the same. We have learned to live and coexist under the same laws, with the same rights and even with the same currency. We have learned to call ourselves citizens rather than enemies; we have learned to listen to each other rather than to accuse ourselves and we have learned to build bridges instead of building walls. Nothing happens because we recognize that we have done well. However, today - and this is politics as it was a hundred years ago - we have to face the specter of popular nationalism, which poisons everything, as is happening today in my country, Spain. Today, as a hundred years ago, there are foolish politicians capable of putting their citizens at risk for sovereignty and ethnic supremacy. Today, as a hundred years ago, we hear again about new frontiers, new cultural segregations and new linguistic divisions. Of new nations. That is why today, as in 56, we must remember that the prosperity and well-being of Europe depend on peace and security, but that there can be no peace or security without laws and the rule of law; that democracy is only true when all citizens can vote and that institutions, however legitimate they may be, are not an end in themselves: they are there to serve citizens. Democrats fight for the Europe of integration and the euro; of the Erasmus program; that of the Schengen area; that of the twenty-four languages ​​of this Parliament and the one that leads social spending in the world. Since the human being has existed, no one has had the quality of life that Europeans in the 21st century enjoy. We must build that Europe, continue to build that Europe, so that in the future it does not become a dream that has not ended. If we are not aware of the danger that national populism entails, there will not be a mistake from the past that we will not make again.The future of Europe is more European Union and no more nationalism.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen!The last summit will not go down in history.Once again it is true that when there are big questions about where the self-promoters cavort in the spotlight - as with migration - nothing goes on.The four pages of conclusions are disappointing: nothing more than a listing of the unsuccessful efforts, no future prospects, and no sensitivity to what is going on.The word refugee does not appear once.The result is completely different with questions about the statements on digital Europe, where the work is in the foreground.Here, concrete steps are specified, perspectives formulated, such as with the questions of fair taxation of IT companies or with cybersecurity.This result-oriented pragmatism takes us further.It would be good if there was less actionism and more pragmatism when it came to the spectacular questions.

name: Bas BELDER
text: - Madam President, two comments from me on the Turkey discussion at the last meeting of the Council. First, the European Union wishes to continue to seek talks with Turkey. In that case, I expect that from the European side the freedom of religion of Turkish Christians will be put on the agenda, because the pressure on them is gradually increasing - I heard that last week - including recent attempts at church closures in Izmir. My second comment, Madam President, is more of a question and points to a contradiction in European policy. How consistent is a European policy that on the one hand - understandably enough - wants Turkey to cut back on pre-accession funds or to convert it to civil society because of - I quote Chancellor Merkel - the absolutely unsatisfactory human rights situation, and on the other hand that Turkey generously provides financial assistance through European banks in the construction of the trans-Anatolian gas pipeline? The Council will have to address these inconsistencies, as will the Commission.

name: Matt CARTHY
text: – Madam President, the Good Friday Agreement recognises that there are unique circumstances that require special arrangements regarding the North of Ireland. That Accord essentially conferred a special status regarding the political and constitutional framework on which the six counties of the North operate. That Agreement is the basis on which we have been building peace in Ireland. Anyone who now says that there must be no special provisions for the North of Ireland in any Brexit deal is not only ignoring the realities of the Good Friday Agreement, but is in fact trying to undermine it.  It is disappointing that the British Government is cherry-picking the Peace Agreement, but it would be worse, it would be a travesty, if EU negotiators allowed them to do so by agreeing to the removal of European legal protections for the North of Ireland. As someone from the border region, I tell Parliament today, I tell the Council and the Commission that our community will not accept any return to the days of physical manifestations of the border in Ireland, knowing as we do the economic, political and social catastrophe that that would be. All of Ireland must remain in the Customs Union and the single market, and all of Ireland must have the protections of EU law. The EU must stand firm on these positions.

name: Laurenţiu REBEGA
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, when you created the European Union, God thought of giving the three main institutions the following qualities: science, power and will. But the devil came and said to him, "Lord, it is too much." And God said, "Well, then have only two of these qualities." The European Council has power and science, but unfortunately it has no will. Last week's work demonstrated this. In the Digital Europe case, yes, some progress has been made. As regards PESCO, only good intentions have been expressed. In the case of refugees, as in the case of Brexit, there is talk of progress, but it is acknowledged that they are not significant. However, we have nothing to do with the reform of the European Union. Or, this is our main problem. A roadmap was discussed before the works. Very well, but the problem is that we don't have this road yet. Until we all decide: the Council, the Parliament, the European Commission, to build this road, the Union will take the plunge, and the road will start with a reform, no matter how hard and expensive it may be.

name: Paulo RANGEL
text: – Madam President, I have three messages: one for all colleagues, one for President Tusk and the other for the Commission. I will be very sharp, very loud and very clear. To all colleagues, I am shocked and ashamed when I hear that there are in this House Members of this Parliament who think that there is no respect for fundamental freedoms in Catalonia. Only a person who does not know Spain, who does not know Catalonia, can think there is no strict respect for rule of law and fundamental rights. I would like to live in a global world where human rights are as well respected as they in are Catalonia, even today. The second message is to President Tusk. I am very worried about this idea of an extraordinary Council on the composition of the European Parliament. This is a competence and a power of our Parliament that then has to be approved by the Council, it is true, but we have made huge progress. I, as a professor of constitutional law who teaches his students about the English revolution, say that we will not give up, we will not resign, and we will define our own composition because we feel we are the sovereign representatives of the European people. The Council should be aware of this in any case. Finally, the third message. I would like to say to the Commission that I put all my hope in establishing a European civil protection force. That should be a body like the coast guard that could be a cornerstone of our future defence framework.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - On the occasion of the celebration of the Hungarian Revolution and the War of Independence in '56, let me quote the lines written by Albert Camus in October 1957: It is difficult for us to be worthy of so many sacrifices, but we must try, forgetting our debates, revising our mistakes, multiplying our efforts, our solidarity in a Europe that is finally uniting. ” And now Schengen: it is legitimate to be outraged by the European citizens who are directly affected by the maintenance of internal Schengen border controls. Everyone understands the concerns of each country, but let us notice that one of the most important achievements of the European Union is constantly being damaged here. While the European institutions do not state unequivocally and, in fact, acknowledge that the current situation is sustainable indefinitely, citizens perceive that everyone can enter at the external borders and reintroduce border controls at the internal borders. If states are unable to guarantee security at freely interoperable internal borders, a serious flaw has slipped into the system somewhere. The accession of Romania and Bulgaria to the Schengen area is still opposed by some Member States, while in the field of secure control of external borders, it is not these countries that are underperforming, but those that are already members of the Schengen area.

name: Birgit SIPPEL
text: - Madam President! Displacement and migration are among the great challenges of our time - also for us. After difficult negotiations, this Parliament has agreed on a reform of the Dublin system: more shared responsibility, not leaving states with external borders alone. But the Council is missing a position. The impression: too many give in to the loud calls of populists and extremists. Publicly recognizable: foreclosure, fences, Turkey deal, agreement with Libya, demands on transit countries. With a view to poverty migration, we must work with the countries of origin to ensure that they take their citizens back and fewer people leave their country in search of prospects. I agree with the advice. We must find new solutions in dialogue with these countries in the areas of development, trade, visas and other areas. The Council could perhaps make specific proposals. So let's shape our future for ourselves and for our neighbors.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: – Madam President, I’m here supposed to talk about Brexit, and I will do that, but before that I would like to make a short comment about the basis of our community identified by Donald Tusk. And yes, we are a territorial community; yes, we have a cultural identity; yes, we are a political community. I also would like to stress and reiterate that we are seen in the world as one of the most civilised jurisdictions, because of our social model: the social market economy - a market economy but not a market society. Europe is a place where every child goes to school, every sick person has health care, every elderly has a pension, and labour rights are protected. This is always fundamental to recall for us. On Brexit, we welcome the Article 50 conclusions of the European Council, which are fully in line with our Parliament resolution. We recognise the progress and the new dynamic put in place by the Florence speech of Theresa May, but also we see that we are not yet there to open the second phase, as sufficient progress has not yet been reached. We look forward to the next weeks and months of negotiations in order to arrive there, and that requires to fully recognise the UK financial obligations, to fully safeguard the rights of citizens, and to fully agree on the common principles on the Irish issue. We are at touching distance, yes, but we also need to arrive to a conclusion and we encourage our UK counterpart to be constructive at the negotiations table.

name: Luděk NIEDERMAYER
text: – Madam President, I came here mostly to listen, not just to speak for 90 seconds, and these were two hours very well spent. Let me just remind you of a few words that were said in the debate. Let me start with three words said by our three Presidents. These were: values, unity and solidarity. I guess that most of us believe that this is the essence, the core of our common Europe, and we must find a way to convince more national politicians and, more generally, as many people as possible to see things the same way. How can we do this? We know it is not easy, but let me borrow two words that were said by the heads of two of our parliamentary groups, the words are visibility and results. We must find a way to reach the results that will be visible and that will allow people to understand the benefits of the European Union. Lastly, let me also mention two words whose results are more difficult to grasp. These are pragmatism and unanimity, also used by the Chairs of our groups. Concerning pragmatism, let me say that sometimes it is a good thing, but I don’t think that it is good for the sake of so-called pragmatism to obey the rules, the principles and common sense. And this is, I guess, quite important. Unanimity is also a tricky word, because we must find the right balance between unanimity and unity in order to reach the visible, optimum results that will ensure our Union has support in the minds of its people.

name: Knut FLECKENSTEIN
text: - Madam President, President Tusk! I wondered for hours who you could mean when you presented a Leaders' Agenda: Parliament or the heads of the Commission - until I found out that you mean those who are sitting in the last car on our European train and are always dragging along with them Need to become. Now I agree with those who say that it is not enough to always scold the advice. That is why I also appeal to us here in Parliament: We must also conduct the domestic political discussions at home in order to convince our governments in Berlin, in Budapest and who knows where that they are going down this path with us. We cannot rely on the fact that it is enough to make wise decisions on our own, so to speak. And if that happens, then I am sure there is a better chance in the Council too. And that is why I would ask you not to worry about us in February, but rather to use this special date to solve the questions you have listed yourself.

name: Andrey KOVATCHEV
text: - Mr President, Mr Tusk, Mr Timmermans, I understand Mr Tusk and I sympathize with you very often in the fact that you have a very difficult task to find a compromise between countries that have different wishes, especially when we have a unanimous decision-making procedure, which stops quite good initiatives and makes the European Union quite inefficient. It is fair that those countries that want more integration in a certain area should have this opportunity to do so, and those that do not want not to stop the countries that have the opportunity or want to move forward in a certain area. Europe at different speeds, only when they are voluntary, and any country that has met the relevant criteria can become part of the relevant integration step, be it Schengen, the Eurozone, the Prosecutor General's Office, be it the Defense Union, the Banking Union, just to name a few from them. Bulgaria and Romania must be admitted to the Schengen area, and this will increase our common security, not reduce it, as such rumors are heard somewhere. I called not only here, but also for the new government in the Netherlands to take the appropriate step, both by water and by air, in 2018 for Bulgaria and Romania to be part of this space. One word about the Eurozone. The same criteria should apply to the euro area. Countries that have met the criteria want to join the IRM 2 mechanism, and this will happen to them as well. Such a country is Bulgaria. By the way, all countries except Denmark and the United Kingdom have stated politically that they will join the Eurozone. With regard to defense, I am here for much more serious, effective action with regard to the Common Defense Union. If this European defense community had happened in the 1950s, we would not be talking about it now and we would be able to pool our defense capabilities so slowly.

name: Richard CORBETT
text: – Madam President, it was decided as expected that insufficient progress had been made in the negotiations. This was a statement of the blatantly obvious. Yet when this Parliament said the same thing just two weeks prior to that, with most British MEPs voting in favour of Parliament’s resolution, two Conservative MEPs were suspended by their party for daring to tell the truth.  This gives us a clue as to why progress is so minimal in the negotiations: the divisions within the governing Conservative Party. Theresa May spends more time negotiating with her party than negotiating with the European Union. And some of her party actually want Brexit without a deal. They present this as a negotiating tactic. If Britain threatens to leave without a deal the EU will give us what we want. Yet, as everybody knows, this will be hugely economically damaging to Britain. That tactic amounts to holding a gun to your own head and saying, give me what I want or I will shoot myself. It will not work. But they do not actually want it to work. Those people want a Brexit without a deal because they want to create maximum distance between Britain and its neighbouring countries. No matter how damaging that is, no matter how costly that is, that is what they want.  Nobody should have any illusions as to where the responsibility lies and I think that President Tusk was quite right when he said it is up to Britain. In his words: ‘It’s up to Britain to choose a deal, no deal or no Brexit’. You were right, President Tusk.

name: Othmar KARAS
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen! I would like to pick up where Mr Verhofstadt, Mr Rangel, but also Mr Fleckenstein have contributed. The special summit that you mentioned for February, President Tusk. If you have a special summit on this issue, then you should convene one to strengthen European democracy. We need to talk about the future of European democracy. We need to strengthen the separation of powers. One problem with the separation of powers is that in the Council the governments are on the one hand the executive and on the other the legislature, and that unanimity and intergovernmentalism weaken the national parliaments and the European Parliament. And so we need to talk about how we can work together to strengthen the institutions so that we can live up to our democratic obligations. The question of the Africa Fund, the question of external border protection, the question of migration policy are also related to the fact that they are primarily national competence, but we have a common European problem. So yes to a special summit on the future of European democracy and a discussion about what we have to change in the Council so that the European Union is more capable of acting in the interplay of the institutions and can actually implement the decisions quickly. I would therefore also like to say: we not only need money for Africa, we need a common foreign, security, defense, development and investment policy. Yes, we need external border protection, but we need European expertise, money and staff for this. I ask you to take care of that.

name: Nicola DANTI
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, what is the unit of measurement by which we evaluate the results of a European Council? The strategic vision, the speed of decisions, the resoluteness in dealing with problems, the solidarity between the Member States? If these were the criteria we are far from being satisfied, starting with the issues of immigration where, in addition to consummate and by now useless expressions of solidarity, progress appears imperceptible. You have the opportunity, Mr President of the Council, to contradict me, by approving the reform of the Dublin regulation, not in biblical times, as Parliament did last week. A step forward is also needed on digital, despite the first fruits of the strategy launched in 2015 by the European Commission. In this sector, vision, speed, resolve and solidarity will be needed, starting with the definition of a fair tax regime for web operators. In this sense, we welcome the initiative of some countries, Germany, France, Italy and Spain in the lead, but to which others have already joined, and we look forward to a rapid and even more ambitious response at Union level.

name: Dubravka ŠUICA
text: - Madam President, peace, freedom, democracy are not taken for granted. They are the fruit of our common aspirations and the fruit of enjoying European and common common values: Schengen, the eurozone, 24 languages, the principle of solidarity - these are all values ​​we want to continue to enjoy. Mr. Kovachev mentioned Bulgaria and Romania, I will mention Croatia. We also want to be a member of Schengen and I hope that we will succeed together. I cannot but express regret once again about Brexit, but also, when it is already there, I want to express that a fair separation is needed and that the financial commitments and all other commitments that have been made need to be respected. I also cannot but express regret over the situation in Catalonia. Mr. Tusk, after Juncker’s speech on the state of the Union, after Macron’s interesting speech, comes your Leaders ’Agenda. I am very optimistic, you are announcing a lot of topics, but it is also necessary to find real solutions to the real problems of our citizens in order to feel what we are all doing together, to solve problems, and the biggest problems at the moment are fear of security or insecurity. then migration, but also unemployment in Europe, which still reigns, especially in some new European countries. I therefore look forward to discussing the topics you have announced: the euro area, migration and asylum change, which we have adopted here in our Parliament, a new asylum policy. I also expect other topics, especially the topic of common European defense. I hope that together we will succeed and that you will find a compromise within the Council.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: - Madam President, in addition to economic or other interests, the greatest interest is the effective implementation of European legality and the rule of law. This is the core of our existence in the European Union. At the last European Council, however, Turkey passed unscathed again. We are just planning to cut a few million, but at the same time we are providing several billion. Mr Juncker (who is not here but will be asked), do you continue to support the upgrading of Turkey's customs union without even fulfilling its European obligations, which include the recognition of the Republic of Cyprus? This is a key question. Mr Tusk, in the Council, in your own statement later, you said that you heard the concerns of the Cypriot President about the new violations of the rights of those trapped by Turkey in Cyprus. I ask you: I too can hear anyone's concerns. What are you doing as the rule of law of the European Union is being violated in the occupied part of Cyprus?

name: Elly SCHLEIN
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, President Tusk, on Thursday in the LIBE committee we approved by a large majority an ambitious Dublin reform, which Parliament leads to negotiations with the Council challenging national selfishness, but with which we also send a strong signal to the citizens Europeans. At least one of the three institutions has common solutions based on solidarity. The biggest breakthrough is that we have finally canceled the hypocritical criterion of the first country of access and replaced it with a permanent relocation mechanism, in which all Member States must participate. We are ready. Council, where are you? What elements did you agree on? It is shameful that the discussion on Dublin is postponed into spring and that you have spent a year and a half with the Commission proposal on the table dealing only with externalizing our borders, while on internal solidarity you have not been able to take a single step forward. Do me a favor, President Tusk: you said you will remind governments that by signing the treaties they have also signed Article 2. Remind them that it also applies to Article 80, which wants solidarity and fair sharing of responsibilities. Do you want to be the guardian of European unity, as you say? So make Parliament's proposal your own, because there is no unity without solidarity. It is not quotas that have no future, President, but a Union based on unity of mere facade.

name: Tonino PICULA
text: - Madam President, I congratulate the Presidency on its impressive results in digitization, hoping to adopt directives that will enable the whole of the European Union, urban and rural areas, mountain areas and islands to share a digital future with equally accessible content and services. I welcome the Council's support for the "return of Schengen". Joining Schengen is Croatia's strategic goal. I hope that, once we meet the criteria, the European institutions will prevent a possible political blockade of our entry. The credibility of the European Union also depends on whether the barbed wire that was stretched to our borders by our neighbors - the member states of the European Union - will be removed. I support the start of PESCO and additional defense coordination, especially the stronger involvement of small and medium-sized enterprises in joint projects financed by European funds and programs. It is good that the next meeting of the leaders' program will be dedicated to social Europe, jobs and growth. The EU-Western Balkans summit is also welcome, but discussions should focus on enlargement, not just on helping these countries in the event of a new migrant crisis.

name: Kati PIRI
text: – Madam President, after a three-hour discussion by EU leaders on Turkey, the only sentence that made it to the conclusions was: ‘The European Council held a debate on relations with Turkey’. On such an important topic, it would have been good to start seeing strategic thinking on the part of our Heads of State. It is clear what EU leaders do not want – no opening of accession chapters, no modernisation of the Customs Union, no lifting of the visa requirement for Turkish citizens, no harsh words on fundamental human rights abuses – but all these noes do not add up to a strategy on how to make an attempt to keep Turkey anchored to the EU.  On the eve of the Summit, another low point was reached in Turkey with the arrest of Osman Kavala, a leading activist in building a more tolerant and open Turkey. How is the EU showing its solidarity with civil society in Turkey and with millions of citizens who are going through very difficult times? Cutting back on pre-accession funding is no more than logical in the light of current events, but a good signal would be to use that money to help Turkey’s democrats. They are the ones who deserve our fullest support.

name: Iratxe GARCÍA PÉREZ
text: - Madam president. Today no one can deny that Europe is facing great difficulties and also threats, threats such as selfishness and lack of solidarity. Lack of solidarity with outsiders, with those who knock on the doors of Europe fleeing hunger, fleeing wars and find a part of Europe that does not understand that common measures are necessary to face these challenges, challenges of immigration and refugees. But also selfishness and lack of solidarity within the European Union itself, because today, in Europe, there are those who take advantage of social fractures created to lift borders, to attack the fundamental principles of the European Union, of solidarity, of cooperation. And against that, there is only one position. Against those who want to raise borders - and above any other difference - there is only one position, and that is the defense of the democratic, social and legal state. The European Union and those of us who support this project must be in that position.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: - Madam President, dear friend, President of the European Council, Mr Tusk, we are really pleased that you are emphasizing the European principles and values ​​that are the foundation of the European Union, and that the strength of the European Union is based on its principles. But Turkey is grossly violating these principles and values. There is one member state of the European Union, the Republic of Cyprus, which is suffering from human rights violations, is being threatened by Turkey. You know very well from the information provided by the President of the Republic of Cyprus that they even banned humanitarian aid to those trapped. Turkey continues to challenge in all directions and we as the European Union must defend our principles and values. And defending principles and values ​​means that we must not accept and accept Turkey's blackmail and threats to any member state of the European Union. We must not approve pre-accession funds for Turkey and reward it. We must not upgrade its customs union and no chapter must be opened if Turkey does not adhere to these principles and values. We are glad because you and Mr. Timmermans, who are present, know very well that in the last attempt to resolve the Cyprus problem, Turkey bears full responsibility, despite the efforts of the President of the Republic of Cyprus to resolve the Cyprus problem.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Madam President, Vice President Timmermans. I have listened carefully and with concern to the debate on the Council's conclusions on migration, because everywhere there is rejection of migration under the stigma of its irregularity, and especially the obsession with the return of irregular migrants, that even goes so far as to incite reinforced cooperation with Libya, ignoring that it is a non-existent State and that it is the starting point of a tragedy towards the Mediterranean and the point of arrival of a no lesser tragedy in the desert that leads to the illicit traffic of persons. And all this in a continuous suspension of Schengen, and without any reference to refugees, nor to the legal channels and channels that are still necessary, linked to the resettlement policy, but above all with the establishment of humanitarian visas. Schengen still suspended, sine díe, extending it until 2020? There will not be a Europe that citizens can appreciate and reward with their vote if there is not a defense of the free movement of people and of social Europe, which is conspicuous by its absence in these Council conclusions. And citizens will vote in 2019. Let's not lose sight of it.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, Mr Tusk, you mentioned the issue of unity and solidarity, but there can be no solidarity at the moment with the European Union when you have this attitude towards Turkey. Turkey, which violates Greek airspace, violates the territorial waters of Greece, threatens Greece with casus belli, has occupied 37% of the territory of the Republic of Cyprus. So are we talking about solidarity anymore? What decisions did you make at the last European Council? It is a given that there must be an immediate halt to Turkey's accession negotiations and a freeze on all European Union funds. Furthermore, what is the solidarity of the refugees for Greece? The relocation process must continue, because the program is over and has only been executed by 1/3. Both France and Germany only 1/3 implemented this program. Other countries at all. The relocation program needs to be continued and expanded. Greece can not stand other refugees and illegal immigrants.

name: Hilde VAUTMANS
text: - Chairman, Chairman Tusk, Commissioner, proud to be a European! So am I. A proud European. But I would be even more proud, Chairman Tusk, if we could move faster and much further forward. You said, "If we want to go fast, we have to go alone." No, I would like to move forward quickly and further together, towards a safer Europe, with solid external borders, with a European defense union, - as far as I am concerned - a real European army, towards a real European asylum and migration policy, colleagues, the Dublin reform, highlighting child immigration. I have not heard that here today. Ten thousand migrant youths in Europe are still missing, in appalling conditions in camps. We need to do something about that. And colleagues, many have said it here, this Turkey does not belong in the European Union. Colleagues, let us use this moment and Brexit to reform Europe, towards a smaller Commission, away from the unanimity rule and of course with one seat for the European Parliament.

name: Neoklis SYLIKIOTIS
text: - Mr President, the results of the Summit unfortunately show that the official policy of the Union continues to circumvent the proclaimed principles of solidarity and to pursue policies against the interests of the peoples. In immigration, the obsession with creating a fortress Europe, promoting deportations, and supporting military operations continues. Instead of giving practical support to the countries receiving the largest waves of refugees, the full implementation of Turkey's unacceptable reward agreement, which has already been given 2.9 billion euros, is called for. Instead of supporting neighboring countries, they seek to become border guards. Instead of proposing investment to boost the real economy, to develop social policies to fight poverty and create new jobs, the Council is calling for speeding up the process of further militarization of the Union, strengthening the defense industry and funding the European Defense Fund. The proposals put forward will not only not benefit the peoples of Europe, but will support new wars with catastrophic consequences for the peoples and nations of Europe.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, once again the European Council has discussed the serious issues facing the European Union, but without having a pragmatic proposal to be able to resolve them. That, after all, is one of the reasons why these issues have stagnated. No progress in the Brexit negotiations. No progress on immigration. A unique and sad ending is that Greece has been transformed into a concentration camp of unfortunate people who believed that they came to the Promised Land and have become living in miserable conditions, because it is simply financially ruined but can no longer bear them. Turkey continues to challenge. It continues to send new waves of illegal immigrants to Greece. It does not recognize the Republic of Cyprus. However, the European Union does not have the courage to close the door on it and stop funding it. Finally, at a time of economic crisis in which more than 120 million Europeans, mostly in the South, are on the brink of poverty or below, we are talking about increasing military spending to address the threat of cyberspace. A situation, an excuse that only brings smiles ironically to both those who know from defense and those who do not.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: - The European political community presupposes understanding and responsibility between Europe's different peoples and cultures, and seeks to preserve Europe's cultural differences and cultural identity.And it is up to us to carefully protect this for future generations.Efforts to increase control of the external borders and reduce illegal flows along the Mediterranean route need to be consolidated and refocused on a long-term vision.Therefore, cooperation with countries of origin and transit will need to be strengthened.The common asylum system needs to be regulated together with a digital future for Europe, which must be more than just a digital single market.Europe needs to prepare for the challenges of digital technology.We need to remove all the barriers and constraints faced by citizens and digital and start-ups in order to make the most of the full potential of digital development.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr Tusk, I am glad to hear that you want unity, you want one European Union, not two, not three, not more. But the ball is yours: the President of the Commission, Juncker, has openly stated here that only one Union is wanted, that we want the Member States that meet the conditions, Romania and Bulgaria, to be in Schengen. Parliament voted on a resolution. So, are you coming to give us advice? President Juncker said that it was good for words to be followed by deeds, and we are waiting for that. We must never forget that in order to be a united, not divided Europe, there must be social cohesion, and I think we need to do more. The European Union is a territory that needs to be defended and therefore needs to be a single space. And, Mr Tusk, I think we need to see that these states, which are discriminated against, are at the top of the list of pro-European countries, and it is good to take that into account. We must respect pro-European citizens and fight Euroscepticism. That is why I believe, Mr Tusk, that it is important to have unity in the Council and not to tell us what we need to do. Don't give us advice. Regarding the number of mandates, of course, it was said here, it is the Parliament that will decide, but, this time, I agree. A state is leaving, we need to reduce the number of parliamentarians. Thank you.

name: Izaskun BILBAO BARANDICA
text: - Mr. president. As Mr Verhofstadt said, the moment of truth has come. We are building a new reality that requires an in-depth review of political concepts and forms of organization that we must overcome if we want Europe to be everyone's home. Building the ECSC seemed utopian, but it did away with the danger of going back to bayonets. Let's not forget it, because today national egoisms return, they make their way into increasingly stale concepts about identity, nation and sovereignty, about citizen participation that block solutions up and down. We need another institutional structure to stimulate the union of the energy market, to end internal social dumping or organize the reception of refugees. We need more European values ​​in the face of Brexit or in the face of a problem like Catalonia. If we believe the motto "United in diversity", is a military intervention on European soil better, because it is authorized by the Spanish Constitution, or to help resolve a political problem by speaking? How to add that diversity without resolving your own? These are the questions that you also have to answer, Mr Timmermans.

name: João FERREIRA
text: - Mr President, the cynicism of round words does not hide the true meaning of the so-called pragmatic approach to the situation of migrants who continue to try to reach Europe. Expulsion of refugees, disregarding norms of international law and revealing how deep the European Union's commitment to human rights goes, complacency or even complicity in the face of the brutal attacks that many of them are victims of at the borders of the European Union and the blackmail towards countries Africans - either do the dirty job of stopping those fleeing misery and war or the European Union turns off the tap on you. As for Economic and Monetary Union, the strategy remains to wave the carrot and hide the stick. The carrot that never comes, be it the third pillar of the banking union, which now, unsurprisingly, has fallen apart, be it a wonderful European Monetary Fund. The stick, that is certain, an even greater concentration of power, usurpation of sovereignty, economic dependence and political subordination. One last word in relation to the fires mentioned by Jean-Claude Juncker, in Portugal. Solidarity is due, yes, sir, but solidarity requires additionality and not a mere reprogramming of the Structural Funds.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, what our citizens expect of us is that we provide European answers where European answers are necessary, that we provide the answers that will allow them to regain control of their destinies individually and collectively, that we provide the answers for issues that are manifestly beyond the control of individual Member States. That is our mission. If we are to be successful in our mission we, the three institutions represented here today, need to act collectively. If we are successful in providing answers that work for our citizens, Europe will be rewarded for it. If we are not successful in providing these answers we will all share the blame. The blame-game here – saying ‘Parliament did the right thing’, ‘the Commission did the right thing’, or ‘the Commission failed’, ‘Parliament failed’ or ‘the Council failed’ – is useless because our citizens do not distinguish between our institutions. They will say that Europe has failed. So, in that sense, we are in this together. Two of the institutions now represented here today only have limited time left before the next elections and before the next Commission will come in. We need to make the best use possible of that limited time. That is why in a moment I will go to the College meeting to decide on the Commission Work Programme for next year, and then present that programme here in Parliament this afternoon. I think the work programme will contain the concrete steps that will allow us to deliver on the promises we are making to our citizens, and it will allow us to use the 18 months that we have left in our mandates to effectively show that Europe can come up with answers when it is called upon to do so.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: President of the European Council. – Mr President, I would just like to clarify a few misunderstandings. The leaders’ agenda is not an alternative version of the State of the Union address. It is a plan on how to organise the work of the European Council in the next two years. The leaders’ agenda is not about changing the Community method. It is an attempt to speed up decision-making processes under binding rules while respecting the competences of all institutions, and that includes the competences of the European Council.  According to the Treaty, when it comes to the composition of the European Parliament, we – this House and the European Council – must work out a common solution. It is not our pleasure or ambition, but our formal obligation. I am the last one to want to violate the Treaty and our rules. By the way, the composition of the European Parliament will not be the only topic for the extraordinary European Council in February. We will also deal with the MFF. I personally consider the MFF to be an even more important part of our meeting in February.  As for the Spitzenkandidaten, the European Council was not the weak link in 2014. Jean—Claude Juncker was elected by 26 to 2 votes in the European Council, whereas in Parliament he got 422 out of 729 votes. So it is easy to imagine a situation in which it would be more difficult for the winning Spitzenkandidat to win sufficient support in the European Parliament than in the European Council.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: I thank the President of the European Council.The discussion is closed.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: in writing. - The clear victory of the populists in the recent elections in the Czech Republic tells us that the "window of opportunity" opened in the aftermath of Brexit and announced by President Juncker in his State of the Union address will not be long-lasting. I welcome the adoption of the Leaders' Agenda, which organizes the timing of the work for the next two years. What does not convince me is the way in which the issues are dealt with. Immigration will be with us for a long time yet, but further efforts are needed to establish a permanent EU presence in Libya and provide adequate and targeted funding for migration-related projects in North Africa. Parliament is speeding up on changing the Dublin regulation. There is not the same commitment from the Member States. The openness to the United Kingdom also puzzles me. At present, the recognition of the debt by Prime Minister May has not yet translated into a firm and concrete commitment to honor these obligations in their entirety and right now we cannot afford any misunderstandings.

name: Lidia Joanna GERINGER DE OEDENBERG
text: in writing. - On October 20, the European Council of 27 member states took stock of the state of negotiations with the United Kingdom and decided to start preparations for the second stage of Brexit talks. I welcome the progress made so far, although it is not much, but after a series of completely unsuccessful meetings, even a small compromise step is pleasing. Nevertheless, further efforts are needed to safeguard the rights of citizens, both EU and UK citizens, and to address the UK's financial obligations to the EU, without losing sight of Ireland's sensitive "Brexit" situation. The European Council asked the UK authorities to ensure legal certainty and to guarantee all citizens and their family members adequate legal and social assistance. I am glad that Great Britain declares its willingness to meet its obligations, including financial ones, taken during the membership in the EU. Negotiations are ongoing. I hope that at the December summit we will be able to move on to the next phase of talks, which will bring more concrete solutions.

name: Ana GOMES
text: in writing.- European leaders are deceiving and deceiving citizens if they think they are managing the influx of migrants by shifting responsibilities to the failed state in Libya and pouring money into oppressive African regimes, migrants and refugees: one of the most supported and funded EU dictatorships is inways to disintegrate Ethiopia, with dantesque consequences for Africa and Europe, and no one in the EU even notices ... European leaders are deceived, and deceive, if they want to provide security and protect citizens, but at the same time maintain neoliberal policiesderegulators that allow criminal mafias, including terrorists, to take advantage of the tax jungle in the EU, holes in the VAT system, offshore and onshore tax havens, to make money, launder capital and capture governments and institutions.The cowardly murder of journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia shows that evil is inside.And it is not confined to Malta!

name: Tunne KELAM
text: in writing. – The positively pragmatic approach by the Estonian Presidency has focused on the main issues the EU has to tackle (digitalisation and migration among others) and on providing practical suggestions to meet the challenges and needs. The spirit of the Tallinn digital summit finds a strong response in the conclusions, endorsing the list of conclusions and suggestions made by the Estonian Prime Minister. Specially important is the call for boosting the development of e-governance in Europe, following the already existing principles of Estonian e-society, such as once-only, one-stop government, and ensuring accessibility. In a joint effort between all the institutions, this has to be put into practice in the shortest time possible, as it would provide the best service to citizens. It is vital that current negotiations on legislation, i.a. on geo-blocking, the Audiovisual Media Services Directive (AVMSD), and future negotiations for example on e-privacy, are led in a practical, consensual manner to enable real solutions in near future. The digital single market should mean losing all digital barriers for citizens and businesses. I look forward to seeing the free movement of data as the fifth freedom decided at the next Council.

name: David McALLISTER
text: written.- At the beginning of the Brexit negotiations, the European Union agreed with the United Kingdom that substantial progress on key issues related to the separation would be necessary before the future relationship could be negotiated.In particular, on civil rights, the border situation between Ireland and Northern Ireland and the financial obligations of the United Kingdom, this progress has not yet been made.The British government must now put concrete proposals on the table as to how it envisions the separation.As the European Parliament, that is exactly what we called for in our resolution of 3 October.It is now important to look ahead together and, where possible and necessary, to build bridges so that the second phase of negotiations can begin in December.

name: Ivan ŠTEFANEC
text: in writing - I welcome the fact that the positions of the countries of Western and Central Europe on migration issues are beginning to converge.We need to continue negotiations and find an acceptable solution so that we can address issues that will move the European Union forward, such as digitization or energy cooperation.Digitization will bring us a number of benefits, such as growth and higher employment or global competitiveness.The European Council calls on the Member States to speed up the legislative process in this area.Significant progress has also been made in the area of security and defense, where PESCO's structural cooperation is becoming increasingly realistic.In the field of external relations, more attention needs to be paid, in particular, to relations with Turkey and the DPRK, where we are not indifferent to the issue of its nuclear program and compliance with the agreement on Iran's nuclear program.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: in writing. - It is a legitimate, albeit belated, ambition for European leaders to respond to common challenges by speeding up and better thematising decision-making, as has now been undertaken with the adoption of the Leader's Agenda. However, the answer to the slowness of decision-making and the occasional political paralysis is not to increase the number of summits, but to restore and maintain EU unity, strengthen the Community method, and make majority decision-making universal. In this House, too, we have repeatedly called on the President of the EiT and the representatives of the Council to look for a real obstacle to common political will and action within the EU: anti-European, nationalist, self-serving. in the form of heads of government as leaders of the current Polish and Hungarian regimes. Unfortunately, they may be the case in the future and, like the obstacles to a common migration policy, they may be obstacles to European construction on other important issues that determine our common future. You need to find a strong political and institutional solution to this in the EiT, at the highest political level, which European citizens, through the EP, will increasingly demand. The next such test of EU unity is very close: the Gothenburg Summit and a truly historic issue for the realization of a social Europe.

name: Carlos ZORRINHO
text: in writing. - The European Council addressed, at its meeting on 19 and 20 October, key themes for the consolidation of the future of the European Union, such as the adequacy of the migration policy taking into account the experience of its application, the progress in the process of concluding the Economic and Monetary Union, the negotiating position within the framework of Brexit and the assessment of the level of achievement of the Digital Union. He also took bold and ambitious positions, which I stress, of solidarity and support for Spain and Portugal, in the context of forest fires that occurred in those countries. I underline, in particular, the Council's commitment to materialize the European Monetary Fund and the Banking Union by June 2018 and the European Commission's commitment to supporting the legislative processes that will make it possible to achieve the Digital Union and the Digital Single Market, as well as give practical content to the European Union's social pillar. I also underline the decision to maintain a position of unity and defense of the interests of EU citizens in the negotiation process associated with the UK's withdrawal request.

name: Antonio TAJANI
text: As President, as a citizen and as a journalist I want to express my indignation at the brutal murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia. (Applause) She was a brave woman, a great journalist. She interpreted the essence of this profession: to investigate to discover the truth about the facts, without being afraid of anyone, and she was not afraid to do her duty to the end, with consistency. In thirty years of career she has never lost heart, she has continued to shed light on her opacity, going straight, answering only to her readers, the only ones to whom she felt she had to be accountable for her. . In this spirit you have published more than twenty thousand articles, denouncing abuses of power, corruption and bad governance. Like any true journalist, she was the sentinel, the soldier on the front line in the defense of our values. It is only thanks to a free and independent press that we can have and defend democracy, the rule of law, freedom of expression and all the fundamental rights on which the European construction and our own civilization rests. Our Union is much more than a market, a currency or a bank. It is the reflection of these values, of our identity, with the dignity and freedom of the person at the center. To defend it every day, inside and outside the Union, we must affirm the independence of the press. I am proud of this Parliament, which has always taken a strong stand on this front. Daphne's murder must not go unpunished. With what credibility could we continue to defend the world's journalists if we fail to give them protection and justice in our own home? I expect the Maltese authorities to make every effort to shed light on this matter. Every lead must be followed, and I believe it is also necessary to involve Europol in the framework of an international investigation where all the police forces can make their contribution to having the guilty arrested and sentenced. (Applause) This is it international involvement that I solicited during the last meeting of the heads of state and government of the European Union. The example that Daphne has given us must not be forgotten. This is why the Bureau decided last night to name the press room of the European Parliament here in Strasbourg after Daphne Caruana Galizia. (Applause) We have her family here in the stands. I want to express our closeness to her husband, her three children and her daughter-in-law, together with that of thousands of Maltese who took to the streets on Sunday to ask for justice and remember her commitment. Alongside these Maltese there are half a billion European citizens. (Parliament, standing, applauds the family of journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia) This applause, dear family of Daphne, represents a very clear message: the European Parliament will not stop dealing with the murder of his wife, your mother, his mother-in-law until the truth is found out. We will not remain silent until the instigators and murderers of this murder are discovered. I now ask all of you to stand up as a sign of respect for this woman and to gather us in a minute of silence in memory of Daphne Caruana Galizia. (Parliament stands, observes a minute of silence)

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: – (inaudible as microphone not switched on) ... EUR one million for finding, killing or handing over to the police the murderers of Ms Daphne Caruana Galizia.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Many thanks to Mr. Colleague Korwin-Mickey.

name: Virginie ROZIÈRE
text: - Mr President, one clarification: we have just paid tribute to Mrs Galizia and we are all terribly affected by this assassination.This tribute was necessary, but perhaps the tribute we could truly pay him is to turn words into action.In a few minutes, we'll be voting to protect whistleblowers.Amendments were tabled to deprive whistleblowers of protection when speaking to the press.If we really want to protect the press, let's vote against amendments 2, 3 and 4 in a few minutes.(Applause)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item is voting time.(Voting results and other details of the voting: see Minutes.)

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Commission. – Mr President, the Commission would like to underline that the Aviation Agreement with Morocco has already been applied for more than 10 years and has never given rise to practical difficulties. Its entry into force will guarantee that both parties will apply the same level of high standards and will benefit from the new market opportunities. The wording used in this Agreement is similar to that used in the EU-Morocco Fisheries Agreement signed around the same period.  The question on the geographical scope of the Fisheries Agreement and the validity of the conclusion of that Agreement are currently sub judice and only the Court of Justice can determine these matters with binding force.

name: Mihai ŢURCANU
text: rapporteur.- Mr President, first of all, thank you to the colleagues present today for this important vote.I would like to refer to the application of Rule 59a of the European Parliament's Rules of Procedure, namely the referral of the mandate to the committee responsible for interinstitutional negotiations.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The voting time is now closed.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Mr Chairman!We voted today many important issues: socially, economically, economically, politically, but this vote should be considered very important because it concerns young people aged 15-25, i.e. at a time when a young person is being shapedvery often it remains for the rest of life.So the issues related to science, education, upbringing, and finally work are of crucial importance at this time.Therefore, it is particularly important that the EU program, the youth employment package, including the Youth Guarantee, is used effectively.In recent years, we have led to a radical drop in unemployment among young people from almost 24% to less than 17%, of course, thanks to EU support, but also thanks to economic development.This is the direction we look forward to in the future and we should ensure that this decline is even deeper.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in Europe 17% of young people do not have a job and this percentage, unfortunately, is more than double in some regions - mine for example, Sicily. Youth unemployment is the greatest political and economic emergency that Europe, in my opinion, must face. The Youth Guarantee is one of the European Union's most important programs for creating job vacancies, a program which, however, often works better in theory than in practice. I voted in favor of this report because the implementation of the Youth Guarantee must be improved through strategic choices, aimed above all at the good use of funds. The data, in fact, show us that internships in companies, even if formative, almost never create real employment, because at the end of the fixed period the companies do not hire young people. Instead, programs on self-employment are effective, just to give an example, on start-ups. Improving Youth Guarantee spending therefore means ensuring that administrations make strategic choices to offer genuine support to the employment of young people.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Mr President, in 2016, 4.2 million young people in the European Union did not have a job, so they were unemployed. This means that we need to change the legislation on the use of funds to help these young people find a job. Those who do not benefit from these funds are especially those who do not attend a school or a professional development program, do not have access to information and do not know what to do. Another solution that I think would lead to a decrease in youth unemployment is admission to vocational schools or colleges - so specialization - based on criteria of merit, ability, dedication, talent, because we are different and we can not do all the same things. Some are good at medicine, others are good at being engineers, others have talent at being teachers and dedication at being teachers, and that way when you finish college, you definitely get a job because you go to an interview. where it shows that you are talented and want that job. Otherwise, we may have too many in a certain category, who obviously will not find a job. Thanks.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, vótáil mé leis an 451 feisire a vótáil i bhfábhar an moladh seo inniu agus an ceart againn is dóigh liom. Dar ndóigh, tugadh an scéim seo isteach i lár cúlú eacnamaíochta nuair a bhíomar ag déileáil le fadhbanna móra: a lán daoine as obair agus go háirithe an t-aos óg. Bhí orthu, mar shampla i mo thír féin, dul ar imirce, mo mhac féin san áireamh, mar ní raibh jabanna ar fáil acu. Ansin tháinig an scéim seo isteach, agus gan dabht ar bith chabhraigh sé go mór lena lán tíortha chun rudaí a fheabhsú. Chímid go bhfuil na daoine óga a chuaigh thar lear: tá seans acu teacht ar ais, go háirithe i mo tír féin agus tá áthas orainn faoi sin.  Ach ag an am gcéanna, tá sé róluath chun deireadh a chur leis an scéim trasna na hEorpa ar fad, agus mar a deirtear anseo, caithfimid na constaicí atá ann a dhíbirt agus seans a thabhairt do chuile duine jab lán aimseartha a fháil.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: - Mr President, today in Greece the data on employment were given and the news is not good at all. 1/3 of the employees receive a salary of 394 euros and 22% of them are up to 29 years old. So despite the fact that statistics show that since the implementation of the "Guarantees for Youth" program, unemployment fell from 23.8% in April 2013 to 16.6% in April 2017, Greece unfortunately remains the champion in youth unemployment. To this is added the flight of hundreds of new qualified people abroad. It is time, then, to respond to what in Greece is called the "generation of 360 euros". It's time to give them a chance to have sustainable jobs, exploring how this can be done. With practice, practice, in a sustainable way and in a mutually beneficial way, both for young employees and businesses. With sustainable jobs, with incentives for companies, with a reduction in costs per employee and with a final increase in their pay. It is essential that we finally have a sustainable productive model based on these young people, not only because they deserve an opportunity, but because they deserve a great European future.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Mr. President, this report is extremely important because it gives a clear message that the Youth Guarantee is a cost-effective program.Of course, we are also asked to increase its efficiency, to have as many young people as possible long-term employment and to be its main result.However, proof that it is profitable is 14 million young people who have undergone new forms of education, additional forms of education, two million young people who have managed to get a job thanks to the activities of this program.One should always strive for a better and better result.So, of course, we need to further strengthen small and medium-sized enterprises, and encourage young people to self-employment and education that will allow them to get a job immediately, and not to get an education only when they finish school and start working.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: - Sir. Chairman! In any case, I welcome the fact that we are examining whether the programs funded by the European Union also live up to their purpose. This applies not least within the youth guarantee. All too often we experience how reports from the Court of Auditors criticizing the various programs are just packed away and not executed; that one does not take cutlery from them and that one does not follow up on the criticism that is raised. There is no one who can benefit from it, neither the young people, who in this case need funds to go out into the world and learn both about life and about their education, but least of all the taxpayers who experience that their money is not used efficiently for the purpose for which it is set aside. This is completely unacceptable, and therefore we should follow up much more on the criticism that comes in, especially from the Court of Auditors, but also from everyone else who is working on these programs and knows how things are going in real life.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - I voted in favor of the report on the control of expenditure and monitoring of the cost-effectiveness of European Youth Guarantee schemes. Indeed, an important result is that the proportion of youth unemployed has fallen by more than 7 percentage points in the four years of the guarantee. However, I share the rapporteur's concern that in mid-2016, 4.2 million young people under the age of 25 still did not have a job in the EU. I agree with the statement that the Member States must increase the efficiency of local public employment services and involve youth organizations in decision-making as soon as possible. I also support the Member States providing a comprehensive picture of the costs of implementing the Youth Guarantee. Finally, especially considering the situation of education and youth policy in Hungary, I consider the proposal to correct the shortcomings of the national education systems to be crucial, as the problems related to the structural labor shortage can clearly be traced back to erroneous education policy decisions.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Mr President, the Youth Guarantee has played a key role in combating youth unemployment at European level. There are still 17.2% unemployed young people in the European Union, and this percentage is not small at all. The report of the European Court of Auditors warns that at the moment it is difficult to give a realistic assessment of the results achieved, there are no monitoring systems and mechanisms for monitoring the participants who leave the youth guarantee scheme. The same report finds that the youth guarantee is mainly used by highly qualified young people at the expense of the less educated and disadvantaged. In Bulgaria the situation is similar. The data show that the measures so far are mainly aimed at young people with secondary and higher education at the expense of the low-skilled, who do not register with the labor offices. I believe that a realistic assessment should be based not only on quantitative but also on qualitative indicators. In order to have real added value, the youth guarantee must first and foremost be inclusive.

name: Michela GIUFFRIDA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the drug market, unfortunately, is evolving really fast and thanks to e-commerce, new drugs, psychoactive substances, synthetic drugs are born every day, not yet banned because they are conveyed, precisely, through aworld that runs faster than laws and sanctions: the world of the web.And it is in this limbo that crime does business.I voted in favor of this regulation because drug trafficking, more than any other, has an international and cross-border character and for this reason law enforcement actions must certainly be European.It is necessary to move forward with measures to ban the production, manufacture, making available on the market, import into the Union and then transport and export.We need to improve the rapid alert system in the event that drugs are transmitted on the web and criminal law regulations are needed to punish producers, suppliers and distributors.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - The European Medicines Agency tells us that, this year alone, more than five hundred young people have become addicted to psychoactive substances, which are very easy to obtain. That is why their number increases every year, every month. Psychoactive substances must be defined as drugs and must be banned. The report calls for minimum sanctions, ie their minimum sanctioning of sanctions, and uniform application in the Member States. Here I have a different opinion from the rapporteur, in the sense that before sanctioning and condemning those who are only consumers, we must provide medical care and medical treatment, because the goal is to do them good, not necessarily to go to jail or be punished and then continue to take drugs. I emphasize another good aspect of the report, namely the cooperation between Europol and the Member States and the European Drugs Agency, obviously, through which information is exchanged for these types of offenses. Traffickers, however, must be punished, not consumers - they must be medically cared for.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: - Sir. Chairman! I think everyone warmly welcomes the harsh crackdown on drug trafficking and the abuse of young people, especially around the Union, and I would like to add my voice to the fact that we are now updating the list of narcotic drugs. It is extremely important that both we as Member States but also as the Union do everything we can to protect ourselves against this substance. However, I cannot help but say that with the open borders and the general ban on border control between the countries, the drug traffickers have been given a huge helping hand. We all know very well that the external border is not as secure as it should be. There are just not many in this House who dare say that. But that is a fact. And the fact that one does not have a national border control is therefore a gift to those who want to make a living by illegal trade in drugs, weapons or human trafficking, or whatever it may be, and then it does not help that the lists are updated, if the market is otherwise fully accessible and there are gaps at the external border. That's what we need to know when we talk about these things.

name: Stefano MAULLU
