text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that never more than now is it appropriate to talk about drugs: about drugs that are beyond the control that agencies and governments can carry out, about drugs that undermine the health of our children and that, above all, create a instability in society. They are drugs that often find their place through the black market and also through the web, which becomes the simplest tool to be able to buy them, and this without age limits and without any effective control. I believe that this provision, and above all the categorization of these drugs, placing them under this real profile, is one of the most immediately acceptable measures by this Parliament precisely in order to ensure that the just repression goes to the end, especially to safeguard the weak of society, which are often those who fall prey to these illegal markets, markets which then become instruments not simply of death, but of profit.

name: Rosa D'AMATO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the report was born from the desire to increase the use of organic fertilizers, thus contributing to the development of the circular economy, and to reduce the European Union's dependence on fertilizers imported from third countries. We have asked to extend the choice of European farmers to fertilizers from recycled organic materials, but even on such an important issue, Europe is late. As much as 50% of the fertilizers currently on the market are excluded from the scope of the existing legislation. This House could and should have dared more: to legislate in favor of farmers in a clear way and to offer them the possibility of recycling nutrients in a more sustainable way. Fertilizers for organic farming must be clearly classified, avoiding misleading the user with complex labels. I tabled amendments in the Agriculture Committee to emphasize the specific nature of their nature and use by farmers, underlining the difficulties in identifying the exact percentage of substances harmful to health and the environment. I asked for the introduction of a green label for fertilizers that are particularly low in pollutants, pollutants that impoverish the soil and expose our agriculture to various plant diseases, as in the case of CoDiRO, erroneously known as Xylella fastidiosa. For these reasons our support was not there and therefore we had to vote against.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, my vote was in favor, because it is a fundamental initiative to improve the safety standards of fertilizer products and to reduce the limits of heavy metals, especially cadmium, which are a real and proven health risk. human and animal. Fertilizers provide significant benefits in terms of crop yields, but we must not forget that there are important challenges in terms of the environment, public health and food security associated with their use. The current regulation does not address environmental issues associated with the contamination of soils, inland waters and marine waters and, ultimately, the food chain. This proposal introduces harmonized cadmium limits for phosphate fertilizers, in order to minimize the negative impact of the use of fertilizers on the environment and human health. I am convinced that the adoption of this proposal will make it possible to provide a better level of protection for human and animal health, food security and protection of soil and water.

name: Morten MESSERSCHMIDT
text: - Sir. Chairman! I am often accused by my opponents, none of whom are at least from the Danish delegation present in this House, that I am never for anything in the EU. That is why I am pleased to announce that I have actually voted in favor of this report. It makes good sense in an internal market to have common CE rules that say which goods may be traded and which goods may not. In fact, I think that if the EU had stuck to regulating only one internal market, then I think the EU would have been a great success. I almost think I could have been persuaded to vote "Yes" back in 1972, when the Danes voted on the matter, if I had obviously been born at the time, because an EU as an internal market - where you can trade together, where goods, capital and workers can move freely, while respecting the differences of individual countries, but not interfering in foreign policy, foreign policy, fiscal policy, border control, etc. - would have been a great success. In its current form, the European Union has become its own worst enemy, because it wants everything that is not Europe but the nation states. Had one adhered to what this report is about, much would have been avoided.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - At present, the legal framework for the availability of fertilizers on the internal market applies almost exclusively to fertilizers made from mined or chemically produced inorganic clays. The draft proposal replaces a piece of legislation and will cover a wider range of crop products, opening up the single market to the free circulation of crop products made from organic or secondary raw materials. All this by harmonizing the rules at EU level. At the same time, I underline that we also need to keep health and food safety aspects and sustainable food production in mind when it comes to fertilizers. Of course, these substances are essential for agricultural production, but like everything else, they can be overdosed. That is why we need to keep the precautionary principle in mind and strengthen precision farming. The report also emphasizes the Commission's proposal in this area, which is why I voted in favor.

name: Urszula KRUPA
text: - Mr Chairman! Of course, I voted in favor of the report, which includes new psychoactive substances, and also introduces an early-warning system and outlines procedures for penalisation. However, human ingenuity can be directly proportional to the length of the banned substances lists. Therefore, using the opportunity to explain the vote, I would like to recall the achievements of Iceland in the prevention of addiction in creating healthy alternatives, which in the case of this country have brought surprisingly good results. Drug abuse has fallen from 42% to 5% in 2016 over twenty years.This was due to the introduction of a nationwide preventive program, cooperation between parents, teachers and scientists, education, but also promotion of extracurricular activities and sports, and giving children more attention and time , application of controls, prohibitions, financial assistance. This case should inspire everyone in the field of prevention.

name: José Inácio FARIA
text: - Mr President, I voted in favor of this resolution in recognition that there is a need to fight relentlessly against new psychoactive substances, which represent a serious health threat of cross-border scope. Its consumption compromises health and causes the death of millions of people every year, affecting their mental and cognitive processes, according to the World Health Organization. Substance use among young people is an important worldwide public health problem. , aggravated by the fact that there is an increasing number of new psychoactive substances available, launched on the European Union drug market. It is estimated that more than 450 substances are being monitored by the European Monitoring Center for Drugs and Drug Addiction. The rapid increase in new psychoactive substances poses new challenges for societies and there is an urgent need to strengthen the Union's surveillance and early warning system, simplifying procedures to ensure greater effectiveness and speed in combating this threat. The increasingly important role of the Internet in offering and marketing these drugs and social networks, which are increasingly active in the purchase and sale of drugs, pose new challenges that imply new and agile responses, as this resolution is an expression of this.

name: Jasenko SELIMOVIC
text: – Mr President, when the UK leaves the EU, it will leave a hole of 14-19% in the EU budget. It will be a major shock for some countries, especially net receivers. Some governments in these countries, for example in Hungary, are almost unwillingly part of the EU. They don’t like the Union and they don’t like the criticism we are delivering from here, but they are laughing all the way to the bank. The question is, what will they do when there is no money in the bank? Will they continue to laugh or will they reconsider their membership and, by doing that, cause the next crisis in the EU? There is no doubt that we have to reform the EU budget. We do not know the missing numbers, but we know that we cannot do business as usual. Somebody was saying that we have to do less, but I beg to differ. We probably have to be more efficient and focus more, but it is time to start doing that now. The sooner, the better.

name: Diane JAMES
text: – Mr President, unsurprisingly, as a Brit and as a United Kingdom Brexit supporter I voted against this. I was able to do so because, if you look at the European Court of Auditors’ report of 2016, it highlights all sorts of issues which are best summarised as: ‘bloated’, ‘running out of control’, ‘high levels of financial mismanagement and criminality’, and ‘eye-watering levels of bureaucratic costs’. And the detail is there for you to look at yourselves: 3.1% of total payments made in error, meaning that EUR 4.2 billion went missing. A huge increase in the amount of money allocated to administering the EU – up to EUR 9.4 billion. And then it talks about the future of EU obligations and it talks about a figure of EUR 238.8 billion, but admits it could actually be as high as EUR 262 billion.  When you look at a paper that merely says for the EU that ‘we’re going to pat ourselves on the back for a job well done’, stresses the minimal impact of EU contributions and overlooks all of the financial mismanagement, it is not a paper you can support or vote in support of.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: - Mr President, the future of the European Union's finances should be of concern to us, because although we are almost in the middle of the current multiannual financial framework, the data are particularly unpleasant. First and foremost, we have countries that have not yet emerged from the crisis, such as my homeland, Greece, and need support with direct investment that will include European financial instruments. Then there is the integration of refugees, which seems to be creating significant financial problems in many Member States. Thirdly, we have the outcome of the Brexit consultation, which has not yet been seen and which will probably create a vacuum in what has been promised. In this context, it is essential that we prioritize our priorities. First of all, to safeguard cohesion policy in conjunction with the Juncker plan and attracting investment from the private sector. Then, to link the course of corrective change with rewarding countries in crisis. And, thirdly, remember: all those who do not succeed rely on community resources to retrain and find work, to send their children to kindergartens, to have a minimum income. For our common future, we must now take care of our finances.

name: Petras AUŠTREVIČIUS
text: – Mr President, I take it as a privilege to be the last speaker on this issue. Since we really need to rethink very comprehensively EU finances so we can more effectively address the emerging crisis in the EU and the EU neighbourhood, better match the political goals of the European Union and its actual needs, a wider debate on the future for the European Union budget and its purpose is still very much needed. Although I would like to support the Commission’s claim, reiterated by Parliament, and the EU budget first and foremost needs to reflect the future of the EU priorities, our citizens’ priorities, having said this, I hope that cohesion policy and agricultural policy will remain among those priorities.  Moreover, I welcome the claim that the EU budget should be based on such principles as EU value, added value, transparency and flexibility, in addition, taking into account the amount of the EU challenges, foreseeable future priorities and the UK’s withdrawal.

name: Igor ŠOLTES
text: - So is it not enough to put whistleblowers on the dock and victims are needed, such as the murder of a great journalist recently, the case of Malta and Panama papers.So, will new victims also be needed before we move and adequately protect whistleblowers in Europe as well.As early as 2016, the Greens proposed the adoption of a directive that would regulate whistleblowers and provide them with adequate legal protection, anonymity and appropriate mechanisms, which would also mean greater security in their operation, because whistleblowers detect more than 40 percent of all cases of financial fraud..Therefore, the principles of the right to know are a very important factor.And that is why I once again call on the Commission to adopt, as soon as possible, appropriate legislation to protect them, which the European Parliament will be able to approve, in order to prevent new victims and new harassment.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Mr Chairman!The topic we are discussing now is important because there is no doubt that honest whistleblowers, acting in good faith and, above all, selflessly, should be protected.However, for this to be the case, the possible legal norms should be precise and narrow, not broaden.Unfortunately, the proposals that were submitted to the European Parliament are solutions that could lead to many pathologies, without any consequences.Therefore, I think that it might be better for this important and right idea if the European Commission prepares and presents to the European Parliament a legislative proposal on this matter.Perhaps then we will have a more balanced, more rational basis for discussing this topic.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: - Integrity whistleblowers, as they are called and known all over the world, are employed in public or private institutions and are people who want to comply with the law. They want to report to the state institutions or to the investigative journalists all the legal violations in the institutions where they work. The state is the first to be interested in finding out about the illegalities in an institution, especially since these illegalities concern public procurement, money laundering, corruption and so on. However, there is no protection. Most people lose their jobs. We also have rules on paper in the European Union, but life is made a mess for them, they are moved, they are taken on sick leave and so on. Why don't we protect these people - the ones inside who give us information just to recover from harm, get rid of criminals and punish them? These people, I repeat, must be protected and the care of the state must be the first, the state is the first interested in protecting them. This is not the case in many Member States or in the European Union. Let's start the new year with a horizontal regulation for all Member States with whistleblower protection.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - I voted in favor of the report on legal measures to protect those who disclose confidential information of companies and public bodies in the public interest. Knowledge of the Hungarian government's activities also confirms the fact that corruption is one of the EU's most serious problems at present. As the report notes, it costs the European Union EUR 120 billion a year. It would therefore be important for the Commission to respond to the call in this report, following an assessment of the appropriate legal basis, before the end of this year, with a view to establishing a comprehensive common legislative framework that will ensure a high level of protection for whistleblowers in national and European institutions, including relevant national and European organizations, offices and agencies. It is frustrating that the physical integrity and life of those who have been looking for abuses will be in danger at some point. That is why I would like to draw particular attention to the importance of the role of the European Union in protecting whistleblowers, especially whistleblowers from Member States where corruption permeates public enforcement bodies and the government as a whole.

name: Alex MAYER
text: – Mr President, I welcome this timely debate and vote on minimum income schemes, not least when the British Government is making such a hash of universal credit, a policy meant to help but which, in reality, is forcing people further into poverty, debt and even homelessness, a policy that is disincentivising work. It needs to pause and think again. In contrast, a couple of weeks ago I was delighted to visit Rapid Drop in Peterborough in my constituency. From Wembley Stadium to Zagreb Airport to Tivoli Gardens you can find the products of this thriving fire sprinkler business, which does not, however, only improve safety in buildings. It cares about the security of its employees too and is proud to be a living wage company, paying people enough so that they can really get by. Its subcontractors, cleaners and maintenance workers get the same treatment too. According to the Living Wage Foundation, more than half of living wage employers report that the scheme has improved both recruitment and retention. It is good for business, good for employees and good for society. A win-win-win situation.

name: Eleonora FORENZA
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favor of the Agea report as it is in continuity with the 2010 resolution on minimum income.It is a step forward, but certainly there are still many steps ahead, both by Parliament and by the Commission which, instead of explaining and making explicit a fragile social pillar, could issue a directive on minimum income.I will not stop fighting, as I have done since the beginning of this legislature, for an income of self-determination, as the feminist movement authoritatively calls it, so that on this continent the right to existence is guaranteed in an unconditional and universal way.Self-determination income and the European minimum wage are the preconditions for a European social citizenship and for the European project to have a future.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: - Mr. president. I think this report is to be congratulated, and I voted in favor because a minimum income system in all the countries of the Union is a basic tool, a tool of any social and welfare state and of an advanced democratic society. And it was about time, a position of this House on the matter was already being missed that allows better coordination. As the report itself recognizes, poverty and social exclusion are not individual problems, they are collective, social problems that must be tackled collectively. The minimum income is a tool to fight against poverty and build more just and egalitarian societies, but also a tool that benefits society as a whole. For the economy to work, people have to be able to consume: it's that simple. The wheel has to turn or it will stop for everyone. In my country, last month, the Popular Party in the Government presented an amendment to the whole before a popular legislative initiative to fix a minimum income benefit of 426 euros. We hope that Europe's voice will hear it, not only when it serves as an excuse to cut back and dismantle our public services, but also when a clear message like today's is sent with this report.

name: Adam SZEJNFELD
text: - Mr Chairman!Human activity, including work, ensures an equal participation in society, it is primarily the engine of his personal development, but also the basis for the success of his family.So there is nothing worse than inducing passivity or maintaining human passivity in society.Distributing money, without the obligation to study, without the obligation to work, without the obligation to be socially active, may therefore induce passive and demanding attitudes.A side effect of this type of proposal may also be an additional migration impulse.Therefore, although the idea itself is noble - to everyone equally, regardless of whether they deserve or not, because they are human, because they are citizens, because they are citizens of Europe - should nevertheless be assessed negatively.

name: Thomas MANN
text: - Mister President! The Agea report is not about the minimum wage; this is determined by the Member States and negotiated by the social partners. This is about minimum income, so that poverty can be successfully combated, so that integration into society succeeds, so that social participation takes place. That is why I voted for the report. Those affected need real opportunities to get into the world of work; it must be ensured that they have qualification measures. And at the national level we need improved rules for social assistance and social protection. Above all, however, it is about fair tax policy in the member states. And there it is really still a bad thing: measures against tax avoidance, measures against tax evasion. That is why we made key demands last week in the final report of the Panama Papers committee of inquiry, of which I am a member. And finally, the actors must be able to exchange ideas on successful practices within the framework of the European Semester, from social investments to easier access to quality services.

name: Seán KELLY
text: – A Uachtaráin, Vótáil mé i bhfabhar na tuarascála seo, dar ndóigh, agus molaim go mór an rapóirtéir, mo chara Derek Vaughan ón mBreatain Bheag as an dea-obair a rinne sé.  Meastar go bhfuil suas le 120 milliún duine san Aontas in ocras agus deighilte amach ón saol sóisialta de bharr an cúlú eacnamaíochta. I mo thír féin, ceaptar go bhfuil suas le trí cheathrú milliún duine sa bhfadhb chéanna. Dá bhrí sin, ní féidir linn a bheith sásta faoi sin agus go háirithe ós rud é go bhfuil an cúlú eacnamaíochta taobh thiar dínn anois, tá súil againn. Caithfimid tús áite a thabhairt don fhadhb seo agus cabhrú leis na páistí, mná, daoine le máchail, daoine dífhostaithe atá sa bhfadhb uafásach seo. Tá na scéimeanna bunioncaim an-tábhachtach agus i mo shaol féin tá mo pháirtí, Fine Gael, agus an rialtas ag déanamh a ndíchill chun cabhrú leis na daoine seo agus déanfaidh siad níos mó amach anseo. Ach i ndeireadh na dála, caithfimid bunioncam a tabhairt dóibh agus, freisin, saol gníomhach nádúrtha sóisialta a bheith acu chomh maith.

name: Maria SPYRAKI
text: - Mr President, I fully endorse what Mr Kelly and Mr Mann said a moment ago. It is really necessary to have the minimum guaranteed income in our societies and especially in my homeland, Greece, I will tell you two numbers: 274,000 households benefit from the minimum guaranteed income, 611,000 of my fellow citizens. Unfortunately for us, however, these numbers are increasing and here we really need to see the priority of our policy. It is an indisputable priority to support those affected by poverty and social exclusion. At the same time, however, it is necessary to encourage their social reintegration, with unhindered access to the labor market, and it is necessary to promote policies of lifelong learning, retraining in new skills and qualifications that will accelerate the reintegration into the labor market of people who feel that work rejected them. Only in this way can we achieve sustainable results in tackling the phenomenon of poverty. Only then will these programs, even the minimum guaranteed income, be able to take on the character of a social investment.

name: Rupert MATTHEWS
text: – Mr President, this report started life as a perfectly reasonable study into the levels of poverty across the European Union and ways in which they might be alleviated. Due to amendments, the report now demands that a centralised European Union fund be set up to run an EU-wide minimum income scheme which would be laid down centrally. It is yet another power-grab by Brussels at the expense of the Member States, this time set up as a policy against poverty.  The report fails to recognise that each Member State needs to have different measures in order to meet its own unique challenges and different causes of poverty, which is why I voted against the motion.  Once Britain is outside the European Union we will be free to take such measures for ourselves. Just one more reason why I believe that Brexit will be a success.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission statement on the Commission work programme for 2018 ((2017/2746(RSP)).

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I have just come from the College meeting where we agreed on our Work Programme for 2018 and I am pleased to be here to present it to you straightaway, this afternoon. The Work Programme is the Commission’s commitment to you, and to Europeans, about what we will do in the coming year. It is a crucial period because together we have just over 18 months to show results before our citizens go to the ballot box to re-elect this House. There are no surprises in what we announce today. The Work Programme reflects fully the ambition, content and tone of Jean-Claude Juncker’s State of the Union speech and the letter of intent we sent you in parallel. At the same time, our Work Programme has certainly been enriched by, and builds on, the fruitful exchanges we have had in this Chamber with the Conference of Committee Chairs and the Conference of Presidents, as well as on our exchanges with the Member States in line with the Interinstitutional Agreement on Better Law—Making. We have also discussed with the Council and have had contributions from the Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions. I would like to thank you for the excellent cooperation we have had and continue to enjoy. We need to build on this in the decisive months to come. I think we have now established, after three years, quite a routine in doing this and it is working well. The Work Programme sets out an agenda for a more united, stronger and more democratic Europe. It has a twofold focus. First, we set out a limited number of new proposals, which we will deliver by May 2018 so that the legislative work here and in the Council can be finished before the elections. The Commission has already tabled more than 80% of the proposals needed under the 10 priorities set out by President Juncker in 2014. Now we will focus on getting the remaining proposals on the table and working with you and the Council to see them adopted. Our focus is on the limited number of proposals needed to complete the strategies we have set out. To boost jobs, growth and investment, we will pursue work to deliver on the circular economy action plan and to complete the digital single market, the energy union, the capital markets union and the banking union. We will propose the creation of a dedicated euro area budget line within the EU budget, along with other measures to complete the economic and monetary union, including transforming the European Stability Mechanism into a European Monetary Fund.  To create a deeper and fairer internal market with a strengthened industrial base, we will present an initiative on fair taxation in the digital economy and a proposal to improve the EU food supply chain. We are – like you – looking forward to the proclamation of the European pillar of social rights next month.  We will follow up with a social fairness package that creates a European labour authority to help address labour mobility and social security challenges. We will improve the rules requiring employees to be properly informed about their contracts and will present an initiative on access to social protection so that everyone who works, whether in traditional or new jobs in the gig economy, can contribute and have access to social protection.  We will also table targeted new measures to complete the security union, in particular as concerns the fight against terrorism and ensuring the interoperability of stronger and smarter databases for our border migration and security needs. We will strengthen the Union’s Civil Protection Mechanism so that we are better prepared to help in situations such as the tragic and devastating forest fires we have seen recently in Portugal and Spain. We will continue to work on our comprehensive approach to migration with an emphasis on returns, protecting our external borders, solidarity with Africa, opening legal pathways and, above all, agreeing on Dublin reform and the Blue Card proposal. We will set out our ideas about how to modernise our visa policy. We will keep up the focus on migration management in our relations with third countries and we will deliver on the global strategy, whilst also pursuing a balanced and progressive trade policy to harness globalisation. The second focus of our Work Programme is more forward-looking and aims to shape the Union until 2025. This vision is based on three principles which must always anchor our Union: freedom, equality and the rule of law. A more united Union will require opening the Schengen Area fully to Romania and Bulgaria, as well as a credible enlargement perspective for front-runner candidates in the Western Balkans. By the way, the Schengen area should also be opened to Croatia if it can fulfil the requirements. To build a stronger Union, we will table a proposal for the future multiannual financial framework, including own resources. We need a budget that helps us to meet citizens’ expectations of an EU that delivers on the things that matter most and that contributes to the long-term sustainability of the Union. We will also propose more efficient decision—making for the single market and certain foreign policy decisions. We will adopt a reflection paper on a sustainable European future and a communication on the future of EU energy and climate policy and propose an extension of the tasks of the European Public Prosecutor’s Office to also tackle terrorism.  For a more democratic Union, we will make proposals for the creation of a permanent and accountable European Minister of Economy and Finance and an initiative on further enhancing subsidiarity, proportionality and better regulation in the daily work of the European Union. We will also propose an initiative on strengthening the enforcement of the rule of law.  Furthermore, since what matters is results on the ground, the Work Programme sets out the Commission’s commitment to step up its work on the enforcement of EU law, working closely with national authorities and the various European networks. In parallel with our Work Programme, we are also presenting today a communication on completing the Better Regulation Agenda. Our work here is grounded on strong stakeholder involvement, including the input of the REFIT Platform. Given the forthcoming European Parliament elections, we are now firmly in a period where we need to deliver. Priority legislative files need to be adopted and, where possible, implemented before the end of Parliament’s mandate. The Joint Declaration on EU legislative priorities, signed by the Presidents of the three institutions last December, has proved valuable in helping us to find shared priorities and stick to them. The Commission looks forward to an agreement later this year on the new Joint Declaration shaping our common work for 2018 and we can then also take stock of what we did on the basis of the Declaration of 2017.  We need to use the current momentum to ensure real progress in order to finish what we have started and to deliver on our positive agenda because, when you rise for elections in a year and a half’s time, the success of the EU will not be judged on the number of proposals that the Commission has launched. We will be judged collectively on the answers we have delivered and how we have responded to the big challenges like climate change, globalisation, the security of our citizens, migration, jobs and growth, on which Europeans expect effective European solutions.

name: József SZÁJER
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Madam President, I would again like to thank First Vice-President Timmermans for the gesture of immediately coming to us with the adopted Commission Work Programme. I am saying this because I am sure that some of our other colleagues will tell you that we do not do anything about this, except what you have said, but I think it is much worse if you know it from secondary and later sources, and we will definitely be able to learn about the details later on. However, on the general lines, I think it is very important in this last point to make some of the points of procedure clear.  This year, Parliament failed to adopt a joint declaration on the Commission Work Programme, so you had to do it without Parliament’s help, in a way. Next year – because it is close to the election year – and the year after there is no need, according to the interinstitutional agreement, to have such a resolution. I think it is a very difficult and tiresome exercise, but we should use these two or three years to rethink what is the best way. Would it be best to influence Commission decisions and to have a general resolution on the whole thing every year with tiresome negotiations and with no consequences? It depends on us (I am saying this to the colleagues here), but we can also maybe find other, more flexible ways to influence this. The EPP welcomed the Commission’s proposal that less and better regulation is better for the legislation than in previous years, and I appreciate the discipline which the Commission brought to this process by really restraining itself. Having this figure which you mentioned – 80% – is really remarkable. Never before has the Commission, with such a high level of complacency, already reached the level of the programme which they were putting forward at the beginning of the term. That also goes to show that there is a clear attempt – albeit not always successful – to concentrate on the most important things. On behalf of the EPP, we agree on the content in most cases, especially in the area of jobs: that we still have to deliver to enable companies to compete in domestic and global markets. In the area of migration, we are still in the midst of negotiations and resolutions here in Parliament. But to concentrate on fighting the root causes of migration and to use the private sector in the financing of this kind of migration crisis is key in achieving development objectives, as is much closer cooperation with the neighbourhood. In the area of longer-term goals, the debate on the future of the European Union has started. It was launched by the Commission, and I would like to thank them for that. I would just say on behalf of my Group that we are happy to engage in this debate in the future.

name: Maria João RODRIGUES
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Madam President, the presentation by the First Vice-President of the Commission on the Commission Work Programme is welcome, because we need an ambitious road map for the European Union. But we also need to have it really delivered, and delivered with credible solutions.  We all know that this is the last shot for this European Commission, and let me be precise on what our demands are: to have real, fair and credible solutions. Yes, we do need a European Social Pillar, but let me be precise: the pillar needs to be translated in outstanding measures, notably making sure that everybody in employment – in whatever kind of job – can count on a decent labour contract and on full access to social protection.  When it comes to the reform of the eurozone, we need a eurozone not only with stability, but with roles and conversions – this means having a European semester working in this direction, a fiscal capacity supporting investment and supporting upward conversions, and a Minister of Economy and Finance who should be accountable to this European Parliament.  On migration, the long—term crisis in front of us and behind us can only be responded to via the proper reform of the European asylum system, legal corridors for legal migration, and a much stronger partnership with Africa. We also know that when it comes to the role of Europe in supporting the multilateral system and an open world order, a lot depends on the kind of trade agreements we are able to do. The kind of trade agreements that we are pushing for are those which should be inspired by sustainable development goals, and all these must be translated into to the European budget. This will be our last chance to redirect the European Union. This is our expectation.

name: Anneleen VAN BOSSUYT
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - I think everyone will agree that Europe's priorities are indeed jobs, security and migration. On migration, we finally expect action from Commissioner Mogherini in connection with the conclusion of the readmission agreements, which have been talked about for a long time. When it comes to security, we need more European cooperation. I am thinking of tackling cybercrime. After all, half of crimes today are cyber crimes and this is a major concern for many Europeans. In addition, we need to cooperate more closely on defense. The industrial development program for European defense is a good example of this. In terms of jobs, there are still many opportunities in the further development of the digital internal market. Here we await, among other things, the proposals from the Commission on the business-to-business platform and for further cooperation from the Commission in the completion of the dossiers on geo-blocking and online sales. I also hope that the Commission will make more money available for European research in the proposals for the new multiannual financial framework. Because 1 euro invested in this yields an economic added value of 11 euros. So that seems like a good investment to me. Let us focus on these issues and not on issues that no citizen cares about, such as a European finance minister or transnational lists.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, thank you, and thank you, Commissioner. I have only just received the text, so I have not been able to read all the details yet, but I am going to say something which may shock you. Indeed, I intend to praise you for what you have just said – yes, I know you are going to need months of therapy to get over it. Nevertheless, we do seem to be past the stage of thinking that delivering results lies in scrapping red tape. What you have just told us here sounds like a vision for the future, and, unlike some other people, I do not believe that you need to see an eye doctor if you have vision. On migration, the Commission has done what it needs to do. Parliament has done its homework. It is actually those who are absent who have not done their homework. As we said this morning, migration is more than Fortress Europe, for the question is not only how we keep people out, but also how we are going to process people, the rapid inflows of migrants. I am very, very pleased to hear that you are going to work on a mechanism for the enforcement of the rule of law: that is, of course, most welcome, but in the short term there are also things that we need to do. For example, I would be really, really pleased if the Commission were to reinstate the corruption reports: we have just seen last week in Malta what corruption and in particular those who are investigating corruption can do. We urgently need a strong tool for investigating corruption and also the rule of law – in Poland, for example. What does it mean if the Commission has more or less concluded that the judiciary in Poland is no longer independent? What does that mean for cooperation? What about the European arrest warrant, ECRIS, the Schengen Information System – are we going to use Polish material? What are we going to do? And finally, I am very curious to see the details of your proposals for a Minister of Economic Affairs and Finance, which, to my mind will contribute greatly to a more accountable and transparent European Union.

name: Dimitrios PAPADIMOULIS
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, Mr Timmermans, citizens are no longer content with wish lists, they want specific actions with measurable results in their lives. They call for actions that enhance employment, that reduce inequalities, that enhance social cohesion. They call for the European Social Charter to have a real meaning and bring results to their lives by reducing unemployment, precarious and low-paid work, and fighting poverty and social exclusion. And, so far, both the European Social Charter and the European Social Pillar are just a label. They want the Growth and Employment Pact to become a real Growth and Employment Pact and not a dogma of obsession with unilateral austerity and fiscal rigidity. They are calling for a single European asylum policy and a Europe of solidarity with refugees, which will not burden Greece and Italy in my country, leaving countries like Hungary and Poland, which refuse to honor their commitments, unharmed. If we move in this direction, and you have a great responsibility to put it into practice and not just words, this will be the best answer to the European far right, which seeks a weak, divided Europe, held captive by nationalisms with ever-increasing social and regional inequalities.

name: Ska KELLER
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Madam President, we are very much looking forward to Commissioner Timmermans’ proposals and I am sure, Commissioner Timmermans, that on a lot of them we will work together with you. A few others we might not like so much, but that’s life! I still want to point out some of the areas where we think that we absolutely need more progress and some of them have already been mentioned by colleagues.  Number one: the rule of law. We have a dramatic situation in a couple of Member States. I think we all agree that we need to stand firm and that we need to be coherent in what we are doing if we want to achieve a good result and we should never let go, we should never give up on such a fundamental thing as making sure that the safeguards against arbitrary leadership, and even despotism, are not endangered in Europe, and this goes to the very heart of the European project.  In Parliament we are currently working towards asking for Article 7.1 to be triggered against Hungary and I think that the Commission must do the same now also with regard to Poland. So you will come to the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs – we are looking forward to your report – but we need to get active on that as well. As has been mentioned, I am glad that you are also taking that up, to look too into other measures, measures that have been proposed by Parliament in the past and which are more sophisticated, more varied as well, and I think we need to go ahead with that to make sure that we are firm and strong on our European core principles and values.  I also would like to mention the whole issue of sexual harassment because no woman should ever have to put up with such treatment – not on the street, not at work and not in this House or in any European institution. I really would like to applaud all of the women who in the past weeks have taken the courageous step – because it is an incredibly courageous step – to go out and say ‘this is what happened to me’. We must make sure that it is not just a matter of individual courage but that we actually also do something against sexual harassment.  I would also say generally about sexism because sexism is what enables sexual harassment in the end, and there we really need to do more. We need to do more, we can do more as the European Union. I would like to see this play a part in the Work Programme too, that there will be initiatives, because I think we should not just have a debate and then say ‘okay, well, next time we will have another debate’, but we should really get serious about this and say we do not accept it any longer.  Next on social justice, and colleagues have also mentioned that. I think social justice is absolutely key if we want to take the European Union further and I think most of us here want that. We want to protect European citizens but that also means social protection. To have a proclamation on the European Pillar on Social Rights, as is envisaged, is absolutely great and fantastic but proclamations alone are simply not enough.  I think, for example, that the Commission should propose a framework directive on an adequate minimum income for all Europeans or different minimum incomes. We Greens have also proposed an EU sustainability and prosperity pact for the European Monetary Union (EMU) and the EMU must go hand in hand with a binding roadmap for social, economic and environmental convergence. I think the issue of tax justice also forms part of the whole social justice package; the income part, so to say. All companies must contribute their fair share to welfare in the European Union and therefore we also need to look at minimum tax for companies and common tax instruments because tax fraud and evasion must be fought with all consequence.  Lastly, on climate change, we do need much more effort. If we want to reach our targets then we have to get serious. We have to adjust our targets upwards and that is, I think, what we need to do because, as you rightly said, this is the last year before the European elections. We want people to vote and we want them to know why we make a difference.

name: Peter LUNDGREN
text: for the EFDD Group. - Madam President! Yes, there are 18 months left until it is time to hold European Parliament elections again. I could not help but see that a publication has now been produced that was out here. Among other things, they write in it about a more democratic Europe, they want to create that. 33 percent say they have a positive image of the EU. It is a deterioration compared to the 42 percent who participated in the last election, and I am sure that it will be a bad election this time. It has a list to make the EU more popular, with eleven points. You leave out, of course. You only include PPE, S & amp; D and ALDE. You do not include ECR and the green ones and of course not EFDD or ENF. And how do you justify Macron being highlighted as the EU's new leader, or is he already campaigning to replace Jean-Claude Juncker in 2019? This is so bad, I have to show what I think about democracy in this House, and it's this [the sound of a torn paper]. There is no democracy in this House anymore.

name: Olaf STUGER
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - Today we are talking about the Commission's work program. But what actually works? Of course, we see Mr Juncker at work: clearly tipsy kissing and tapping as if the whole me-too-hype doesn't exist. We see Mr Timmermans busy, punishing the countries that stand up for their own people, such as Poland, Hungary and Slovakia. Mind you, Mr President, these are democratically elected leaders who are being reprimanded by people here for whom no one has voted. Nobody. Climate is another subject where the crackle in your glasses jumps when you read that. We will combat global warming by a few thousandths of a degree if we reduce CO2 emissions by half. That costs hundreds of billions in tax money. That doesn't work either. I conclude with the unfortunate plan to work on a European finance minister. We see the disastrous consequences of a failing euro in the various countries. The coin is artificially propped up by printing 80 billion a month. That is of course an untenable construction. If the euro has to stand on its own two feet again, then all hell will really break loose and the suffering will no longer be foreseeable. This also only works in the fantasy of the people in the front of the benches. All that's really going to work is shutting down this failed experiment and putting decision-making back where it belongs, namely in the democratically elected parliaments in the Member States.

name: Lampros FOUNTOULIS
text: - Madam President, I am convinced that 2018 will be exactly like all the previous years of this Commission. Announce a lot again, analyze big plans and goals. But again the results will be lower than our expectations. As in previous years, so in 2018, you will not solve any of Europe's great problems, but you will certainly continue to accuse those who are ideologically opposed to you as populists, and the people of Europe will continue to suffer the mistakes of politics. your choices. After so many years of economic crisis, growth has not returned, austerity continues and the European Union tends to become a two-speed Europe. Illegal immigration is still a huge problem, especially for the countries of the South. The European Union remains an organization reluctant to impose restrictions even on acceding countries, such as Turkey. On the contrary, Erdogan seems to be able to exploit and devalue European politicians at any time. Finally, the only positive thing so far has been that your irrational and ideologically militarized policy has persuaded the people of the United Kingdom to finally get rid of the shackles of the Union. We hope that the other peoples of Europe will follow them soon.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: - Madam President, Mr Vice President, Dear colleagues, we all have an obligation to protect human life. I know that the competence of civil protection is in the hands of each Member State, but the European Union must also help. And I hope that, in 2018, there will be a rapid intervention force in the area of ​​civil protection. Prevention is also urgent and the Structural Funds available in each Member State are important for that same prevention. Solidarity, a solidarity fund to deal with damage, is urgent that it works quickly, not least because that solidarity has to be felt. Also in 2018, Mr. Vice-President, there will be a proposal for the presentation of the new multiannual financial framework. It is a multiannual financial framework that must live up to its objectives and that means that it must have financial means in line with the objectives it proposes. We need these means and we also need something else: new priorities must have additional funding. I hope that there will be a multiannual financial framework for more than 7 years, to provide predictability, with the flexibility that is required to respond to unforeseen events. I also expect a new line for security and defense, and I would also like, in conclusion, that the Vice-President would tell us, if he already has this information, regarding the line set out in the budget for the euro area and for those who they want to join the eurozone, what is the amount foreseen for that budget line that will be within the budget of the European Union.

name: Udo BULLMANN
text: - Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen! One of the foremost tasks of this commission in the coming weeks and months will be to defend the European Union as a democratic project. Why am i saying this? Yes, of course our group is in favor of making progress on deepening economic and monetary union. Of course, we want a European monetary fund. But that cannot become an intergovernmental matter. Or do you want to regulate with 19 finance ministers - or better still 27 - how we should react to the shocks of this world and what kind of measures we coordinate where and how long it should then take? We saw this nonsense at the Troika. We have seen how much nonsense comes into the world - well meant but badly done - when there is no parliamentary control. We are at your disposal because we want this deepening. We want to improve our economic policy instruments. But the Commission must stand up and defend its own role. Nor do we want the Member State finances sheet to leave the Commission; she belongs on the commission. Your boss is called Juncker and not Regling. We have elected you here and Mr Juncker and the fellow Commissioners. But we did not choose Mr Regling here. It needs democratic control - it needs the European Parliament. We would like to support you here, today and in the future; thank you for that. I would like to say one last sentence, perhaps also on behalf of my colleagues. I would like to thank the interpreters for the occasion. You are doing a great job. Not only do they do this today, they do it all year round. Thank you very much for that.

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: We can agree with that as regards the interpreters. Our thanks to them.

name: Peter van DALEN
text: - (NL) Mr President, Europe must rely mainly on its soft power and the strongest soft power instrument Europe has is trade. Globally, Europe is really a very important player in trade. The trade preference system is specifically designed to encourage countries to improve respect for human rights. Above all, let's not forget that specific goal. One of the countries currently enjoying the GSP + trade advantage is Pakistan. Unfortunately, human rights are being flouted in Pakistan, including by the government. After all, why is there still the death penalty for blasphemy? And why has Asia Bibi been on death row for 7 years? I call on the Commission to make a serious assessment of Pakistan's trade benefits and I estimate that these benefits have unfortunately failed to make the difference. If so, then that GSP + status should be frozen or revoked. Finally, I believe that the mandate of the Special Envoy for Freedom of Religion should be renewed next spring.

name: Cecilia WIKSTRÖM
text: – Madam President, as the Chair of the Conference of Committee Chairs I would like to thank you, Vice-President Timmermans, and all of the Commissioners for a very good and fruitful cooperation that has improved throughout the years. On a practical note, I hope that the Commission will expedite any remaining legislative proposals and present them to the co-legislators at the latest by April 2018 to give us a fair chance to conclude before the end of this mandate.  It is abundantly clear from the Eurobarometer of May this year that citizens expect the Union to deliver in areas like migration, defence, the environment and foreign affairs – more than two—thirds of citizens have asked the European Union to deliver on that. We also know that 81% of citizens underline the importance of the free movement of citizens in the Union: speaking about migration, last week this House managed to unite 751 MEPs from five Groups that consist of more than 200 political parties. Council, though, was not present here today. They could not up until now unite 21 Ministers. I find that quite remarkable, and I urge the Commission to give them a push in the right direction when it comes to pushing this area to a qualified majority vote.

name: João PIMENTA LOPES
text: - Madam President, once again, the Commission insists on presenting the same proposals and the same paths: loss of economic, monetary, fiscal and banking sovereignty to the benefit of the great European powers, austerity, impoverishment, exploitation, concentration of wealth for some, misery and uncertainty for others, more investment in the war industry and in security measures and the suppression of asylum and refugee rights. More of the same, without drawing lessons from the policies that they have imposed and want to continue imposing. These needs are clear and evident: the reinforcement of funds for cohesion, countering the growing asymmetries, the need to defend democracy within the framework of the sovereignty of States, the defense of progressive development policies that respond to the needs of peoples and to make use of resources and capacities to their own advantage, support to countries affected by disasters and directed towards prevention mechanisms, the need to support the recovery of the productive sectors in countries like Portugal, with support directed to fishing, agriculture and industry, support that is channeled primarily to micro, small and medium-sized enterprises, support and policies that favor necessary public policies in strategic sectors, such as energy, transport and communications, support and policies based on the provision of free and quality public services , in sectors such as health, education and justice, supports that reinforce scientific production capacity research, policies that promote job creation, work with rights, collective bargaining, increased wages, reduced hours and public and universal social security.

name: Yannick JADOT
text: - Madam President, Vice President Timmermans, it has not escaped your notice that we are not done with the far right and the nationalism of the left and the right. They claim to bring together - we know - the losers of globalization and the losers of the European Union, but Europe of today also disappoints the most convinced. How can you blame them? Neoliberalism as a horizon, austerity as a solution and technocracy as a method inevitably disappoint all European citizens, including the most convinced, and make our institutions hateful. The question of globalization - as we know - is a major issue of sovereignty. Obviously, without Europe, we will be swept away by globalization, but when the European Union becomes a small liberal globalization and that through its free trade agreements, it puts in competition the employees, the territories and, today, increasingly, the choices of society, it puts climate, health, the environment, the protection of personal data and public services within gun range of a few multinationals. Obviously, at this point, Europe is not fulfilling its mission. Mr. Timmermans, we must change our trade policy so that social, environmental and human rights take precedence over trade and investor rights. If we do not succeed in this, Europe will be diluted in its very essence. Europe is a community of law. If the citizens are not co-actors of this right and it is the multinationals who decide, there will be no more Europe.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: - Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, on immigration the only thing the European Union proposes to us is the reliance on extraordinary personalities such as Erdoğan on the one hand and the gentlemen of the Libyan militias on the other, who should guarantee the safety of European citizens. Nice program and best wishes! We Eurosceptics usually attack the European Union by saying that it is a construction that is foreign to the feeling of the peoples. We have proof of this: it happened in Catalonia and, a few weeks later, in another of the more productive areas - such as Catalonia - of honest people, who work and produce: in Lombardy and Veneto millions and millions of people go to vote, they want a referendum. It is a great demonstration, just like that of Barcelona, ​​of a desire for freedom, direct democracy, participation and representation. There is a great crisis of representation in this Europe, which you say is projected towards more democracy. But if we don't talk about it now, if in your document you don't even remotely examine the Catalan question, the question of northern Italy and the question of minorities asking for representation, what would this new democracy be? You do not have the courage, you are far from hearing and the only solution is the Europe of peoples and regions, not that of bureaucracy, banks and multinationals that are very dear to you.

name: Janusz KORWIN-MIKKE
text: - Madam President! Mr Verheugen said in an interview two days ago that we need to increase our competitiveness because we are losing out to the Far East countries. Well, I am reading this program of the European Commission. I listen to these statements. They all go in exactly the opposite direction. After all, if - as my anti-colleague wants here - we want social and human rights to take precedence over economic laws, it will obviously be impossible to compete with anyone. Truth? You must understand: Europe used to be a leader. We were the driving force behind the development of the whole world thanks to the fact that European values ​​ruled. They are exactly opposite to the EU values. If we want to return to the leading position, we must throw away all acquis communautaire. We must reject democracy. How can you believe that most - more dumb than wise - will make sound decisions? After all, you see the results not only of the last elections, but also the results of decisions made by democratically elected governments. We must go in exactly the opposite direction. I believe that Europe will be reborn, that it will abandon the occupation of the European Union and that a free Europe will arise again.

name: Lambert van NISTELROOIJ
text: - Commissioner, Vice-President Timmermans. I would like to compliment you on your progress story, but I would still like to extend an invitation to you. 2018 will be the year of the MFF with dozens of implementing regulations to be presented for the post-2020 period. What is our experience? In the past period, we have seen that they arrived too late to actually start at the beginning of 2014, 2015 and 2016. For example, in a number of areas, such as cohesion policy and the second pillar of agriculture, this has meant that expenditure has only started very late. That should be better now. That must now be faster. This can also be done if the regulations are presented in one go, mid-2018. If we don't, then we get a repeat of what we have seen, which is that expenses are made very late in the period, in the 5 or 7 years. We saw last time there was a great pile of unpaid bills. We can already see that EUR 8 billion will be returned to the Member States in 2016. This will also partly happen this year and we will have a tremendous avalanche of bills, later in 2019 and 2020. And then not talking about Brexit. So indeed, better regulation and also timely regulation to be able to show in 2019 that Parliament is really taking that direction. It cannot be the case that in mid-2019 we will get together in a situation of debates that have not been concluded and that 2020 and 2021 will be bad years. That is my call: timely regulation. .

name: Jeppe KOFOD
text: – Madam President, the Commission’s annual work programme is a key tool to addressing shared European challenges. Sadly, I have to say tax fraud, tax evasion and money laundering remain an enormous shared problem in Europe, costing EU Member States what amounts to EUR 2 000 on average per citizen in lost taxes every year. I therefore welcome the initiative on taxation of the digital sector, but I think we have to do much more. I have spent the last few years working as a co-rapporteur for the Parliament’s inquiry committee into the Panama Papers. Our investigations show how unregulated intermediaries in Europe and in offshore tax havens help the super-rich hide their wealth in tax havens. We have to stop this shadowy industry of tax dodging, and also stop the corrupt global elite that are doing this. That is why we, the Socialists and Democrats, want to break new ground to put an effective end to tax fraud, money laundering and tax havens by introducing a common EU licence for wealth managers, tax advisers and other intermediaries, so that licences can be instantly revoked throughout the EU in the event of illegal actions. Only a common system with EU licences will make sure that we can put an effective stop to the industry of tax fraud in Europe. I hope that the Commission supports this idea in the next year’s work programme.

name: Zoltán BALCZÓ
text: - Jean-Claude Juncker met with the leaders of the Visegrad Four at a working dinner before the EU summit.It would be very important for the Commission's work program to understand the position of the so-called renitent countries, to acknowledge that these countries do not accept the Commission's migration policy.As early as 2014, when no one had heard of the so-called “Soros Plan”, Jean-Claude Juncker made it clear that he saw the solution for Europe in the face of depopulation in resettling migrants.And the EP report emphasizes that migration should be seen as a positive development.If so, why impose mandatory admission quotas?Based on the October state elections, President Juncker will need an ever-increasing table for dinners on this subject.But it would also be good if he could digest what was served in front of him there.

name: Albert DESS
text: - Madam President, Mr Vice-President! I welcome the Commission's proposal that all expected legislative proposals should be submitted by May next year at the latest. This must also include the proposal for the post-2020 MFF so that extensive inter-institutional negotiations can start immediately. The aim must be to successfully conclude these negotiations by the end of the current parliamentary term. Every effort must be made to avert a new payments crisis, including through a decision on the appropriate level of payment appropriations in the coming budgets. A structured dialogue on the overall budget, the political and financial priorities, the design and flexibility provisions of the future MFF is essential. A position on the life of the financial framework needs to be reached. The EPP Group has clearly spoken out in favor of the Commission bringing forward a legislative proposal on the food supply chain. I am therefore very pleased that this request has found a large majority in Parliament and the Commission and that it is included in the work program, in the legislative proposal. The proposal must contain a framework at EU level on unfair trade practices, and the President-in-Office has been very involved in this. I also ask the Commission to come up with a legislative proposal to further develop the common agricultural policy. A constructive dialogue is also necessary here. Mr Timmermans, agriculture ensures that there are over 41 million jobs in Europe. We spend 32 cents per inhabitant and day to ensure that we secure these jobs and that over half a billion people receive enough food every day. I think that is a small amount that must be earmarked for this in the future as well.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: - Madam President, Mr Vice-President, next May the Commission will present the draft multiannual financial framework for post-2020, in order to allow for a fruitful and shared debate on the financial future of the Union. However, the famous leaders' program presented by the Council provides for the negotiations to be concluded at the end of 2019, to the contempt of Parliament and the Commission, because, in agreement with Commissioner Oettinger, we had drawn up a timetable which opened up the possibility of a agreement between Parliament and Council at the start of 2019. I would remind you of Article 312 (5) of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union: “throughout the procedure leading to the adoption of the financial framework, the European Parliament, the Council and the Commission shall take all necessary measures to facilitate this adoption ”. The Council is not meeting its obligations by considering a conclusion of the negotiations when the Parliament and the Commission are in full reconstitution. He does not respect Parliament when he imagines that its consent will only be a formality. I therefore appeal to the President of the Commission to say, along with Parliament, to the President of the Council: "Amend your program!". Let us not give the feeling of a Union which always waits for the last moment. I appeal to the Commission, guardian of the treaties, to do everything to ensure that the negotiations are democratic and fruitful.

name: Bogdan Brunon WENTA
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! Here, in brief, the position of my political group on the priorities of the European Commission's 2018 Work Program from the perspective of the activities of the Development Committee, DEVE. We support the establishment of mechanisms to supervise the implementation of the SDGs by the European Union and the Member States, in line with the new European Consensus on Development. We are aware of the current limited capacity of the European Development Fund to support security and development initiatives. We are in favor of establishing a new financing instrument that will comprehensively support activities in the interests of democracy, good governance and the protection of human rights. Referring to the postulate concerning counteracting the causes of migration, we reiterate our support for innovative methods of solving the migration crisis, proposing and promoting cooperation with the private sector, enabling the solution of economic problems underlying migration. From the perspective of the European Union's relations with African, Caribbean and Pacific states, as we know, the next year is the moment when we should start negotiations on a partnership that will replace the Cotonou Agreement. Our cooperation with African partners should involve greater regionalization and support for state resilience, and should be based primarily on political dialogue and support for development and trade.

name: Pervenche BERÈS
text: - Madam President, Mr Vice-President, we are here to talk about the Commission's work program for the year 2018. I am somewhat uncomfortable because, during this time, President Tusk has proposed to the Council European roadmap, not in order to be in harmony and implement this work program - to use it - but by giving the impression of wanting to implement a parallel agenda. I would like to say that the same thing seems to be found at the level of the proposals that you are going to make in the economic and monetary field, where you propose to transform the European Stability Mechanism into a European Monetary Fund - a proposal which should be on the table on December 6 - while the President of the Eurogroup has just been recruited by the European Stability Mechanism itself to reflect on this reform, which nevertheless raises questions as to the credibility of the institutions in their respective roles. What will the proposal be on the table? I warn you against what we feel is coming: a proposal in which the Commission would ultimately relinquish its powers in terms of budgetary supervision to the benefit of the European Stability Mechanism, the Commission remaining, it alone, competent to implement structural reforms within the framework of macroeconomic conditionality that this European Parliament has always refused.

name: Andrzej GRZYB
text: - Madam President! Commissioner! I would like to thank you for this presentation of the Commission's goals for 2018. There are many important issues that the Commission has raised, proposing as if to be great on big things, such as for example the Energy Union, the continuation of this project, the Defense Union, including the defense of the European Union's borders or the Digital Agenda and related cybersecurity to it and the Defense Union. I am very pleased that there is a declaration on the enlargement to the Balkan countries, at least one of the Balkan countries, and work on it. And there is something that is more - so to speak - divisive or controversial - that is the issue of a special budget line for the euro area. We have to discuss this. But also, among other things, the "mobility and climate change" package was proposed, which is necessary but also raises a lot of controversy, as future emissions regulations should be correlated with a long-term vision of transforming the car sector towards zero emissions. Here, we need a certain roadmap to electromobility, which is important, necessary and future-proof. However, it must also take into account the development of the domestic European car industry - in my country there are over two hundred thousand jobs and they would like to know what this transformation project should look like. And perhaps a small matter: it is a question of the 2001 Parliament and Council directive on summer time. In my country, for example, there is a discussion, and there is great approval for approaching the abandonment of this annual double clock shift. It is not only a matter for my country but also, for example, of many other European countries that are raising legitimacy. It seems to me that since this debate has started, it should also be referred to.

name: Roberto GUALTIERI
text: – Madam President, I welcome the Commission Working Programme on the EMU and also the key choice that has been made for the Community method. This has a number of implications, and I would like to focus on them, in particular on two implications.  First, the ESM integration into EU law is really essential. It is essential because with Article 352 of the Treaty we will have full EP involvement via the consent procedure; it is essential because it will ensure EP scrutiny to the new body; it is essential because this is the only way to obtain the meaningful budget line that is in your programme; and it is also essential if we want to fully safeguard Commission competences on economic policy coordination and budgetary surveillance, including by avoiding to building up a parallel capacity to do Article 4 reports by the ESM. Second, on the Fiscal Compact incorporation: incorporation requires reform which means also that full co-decision procedure and double legal basis are necessary.

name: Miriam DALLI
text: - Ir-riforma hija ta 'importanza assoluta, u t-triq għal Unjoni li hija aktar magħquda, b'saħħitha u aktar demokratika tista' titqies bħala pass poţittiv biss jekk l-Unjoni Ewropea u l-istituzzjonijiet kollha tagħha, inkluži , igawdu l-fiduċja tal-pubbliku. Qiegħda nitkellem b'mod partikolari dwar l-iżviluppi riċenti dwar il-glyphosate u anki dwar endocrine disruptors għaliex dawn iqajmu tħassib serju dwar il-mod ta 'kif qegħdin jaħdmu l-aġenziji tal-Unjwi uwi anwi anwro certainty. Xogħolhom għandu jkun li jipprovdu data xjentifika li hija indipendenti u konklużjonijiet li ċ-ċittadini jistgħu jafdaw dwar is-suretà tal-kimiċi li niġu f’kuntatt magħhom. Id-dipendenza tal-ECHA u anki ta ’EFSA fuq studji li jingħataw mill-industriji qed joħolqu sfiduċja serja u dan qed iqajjem mistoqsija dwar l-indipendenza u anki l-affidabilità ta’ dawn l-aġenziji. Fil-fatt l-aġenziji qegħdin jgħidu li huma jsegwu r-regoli. Jekk dan huwa l-każ, allura għandna nerġgħu nħarsu lejn ir-regoli, u l-programm ta ’maidma tal-Kummissjoni 2018 għandu jindirizza dan.

name: Claude MORAES
text: – Mr President, clearly, such a big proportion of the Commission Work Programme lies in the field of migration, fundamental rights and security because that is where our clear challenges lie, and it is appropriate that Vice—President Timmermans is here today.  On migration, after all the difficulties of relocation and after all the work we have done with the Commission here in Parliament, we now need to seize the challenge of Dublin. Let’s get the mandate from the Council and let’s get the mandate from the Member States. So much hard work was done here. This will also release the asylum package qualifications, the Asylum Support Office, and all of the files that come behind this and create a package in the run—up to the European elections in 2019. That is a prize that is worth seizing. On fundamental rights and the rule of law, we want to see a proposal for a democracy, rule of law and fundamental rights pact, and that is something that I know the Commissioner will also want to see. On security, which is also close to the hearts of our citizens, ETIAS, ECRIS and SIS II must also have impact assessments to make better implementation key. We want quality legislation. We do not want legislation just in name, but in quality that will last and that will have privacy at its heart, but which will also be effective for the security of our citizens.

name: Bernd LANGE
text: - Mr President, Vice-President Timmermans! Point 15 of the work program says: Delivery of the Trade for All strategy. I think we can't just extradite. We also need to add a little spice to trade policy. Not just a normal pizza, but a spicy pizza has to come out of it. Three points should be mentioned. The trade agreements that are also listed are not to be assessed in terms of quantity, but in terms of quality. I think nowadays we also have to bring in the issue of tax avoidance, the issue of corruption, so that in the end it is a good deal and not just the number of deals that counts. Second, we have a proposal for a multilateral investment court. We really have to push that so that we can achieve reform here. But it also means, Mr Timmermans, that we are reviewing the 1,200 existing European investment agreements and changing them accordingly, especially the Energy Charter, because otherwise we are not credible if we have two standards. Third: we have to enforce enforcement. It cannot be that conditionalities are not taken into account in the financial support - the Court of Auditors has presented a report - and workers' rights must also be enforceable. You said that in a speech in May: Enforcement is the third right step to spice up trade policy.

name: Cécile Kashetu KYENGE
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, a few months ago President Juncker, addressing this House, illustrated a scenario on which to build the foundation of our Union: freedom, equality and the rule of law. Today his words go in the same direction and instill in us a cautious optimism. You confirm that your vision of Europe corresponds to ours and that the months that separate us from the end of the legislature will be decisive for consolidating the foundations of a more united, stronger but also more democratic Europe, capable of truly influencing the international scene and, above all, to face with its allies, together, the main global challenges that await us a few years from now. Mr President, consider this House your main ally, but above all we have already shown you that we never back down, especially after we have approved Dublin. I make an appeal here to continue on the path of ... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Olga SEHNALOVÁ
text: - Mr President, a few weeks ago, I welcomed the words of the President of the Commission here in plenary that there must be no second-class consumers in the European Union. The Social Democrats expect the European Commission to move from words to deeds in the announced package of the new consumer policy. I will start by fighting with double quality products. Thanks to the efforts devoted to describing this practice, we already know that double standards exist. Supervisors now need clear and effective tools to deal with it. We want better public measures to enforce consumer rights. Illegal practices of all kinds require a swift response, and I believe that the regulation on cooperation between supervisory authorities will play an important role here. Another problem is the limited remedies. It is therefore time to present a proposal for a system of collective legal protection for consumers. We must also finally address the imbalance between businesses in the food chain. Unfair trade practices between the various actors have long been a serious problem here, which requires legislative action at European level, and I am glad that you mentioned this issue.

name: Momchil NEKOV
text: - Mr President, Mr Timmermans, Mr Juncker has repeatedly stated that young people are a top priority in his work. It is natural to expect concrete initiatives in this direction in the Commission's work program for 2018. What does this mean in concrete terms? First, a proposal for a new Youth Strategy to address the real needs of European youth. Although declining compared to 2014, to date youth unemployment remains unacceptably high.
