Every young European should have the chance for professional realization here in Europe, not outside it. Secondly, speaking of professional realization, we cannot fail to mention the digital skills deficit, which is a serious obstacle. I would expect Commissioner Gabriel to focus her efforts not only on providing digital infrastructure, but above all on developing the digital skills of European citizens. Given that 40% of Europeans do not have basic digital skills, who will this digital single market work for?

name: Enrique GUERRERO SALOM
text: - Mr President, Mr Vice President, when you look back at 2014, you see how part of the Commission's initial program has been altered by the succession of crises that have shaken the European Union: low growth and high unemployment, crisisdebt, immigration and refugees, terrorism and insecurity.Today it seems that some of these clouds are disappearing and that the horizon is somewhat clearer;That is why the Commission is presenting proposals for the future, and in those proposals for the future there is a common link: security.But nothing offers citizens more security than a robust social protection system.For this reason, the proposal that he has put forward regarding the social pillar sounds good, the music is good.It is necessary for the letter to accompany it but, above all, that the pace of application is intense enough so that, before going to the next elections, citizens check that Europe thinks of them and protects them.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: We come to the catch-the-eye procedure, and unfortunately I have to tell you that I have about twice as many reports and therefore have to reduce something.I ask for understanding.Catch-the-eye procedure

name: Mairead McGUINNESS
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank Vice President Timmermans. The line that caught my ears, and indeed my eye, was about the food supply chain. A few of us, many years ago, started talking about unfair trading practices, and this chamber voted by 600 Members for the Commission to take action. So you did listen, and I am really looking forward to seeing the details of that proposal. I hope as many Members support the initiative, which I believe has to be very strong and very tough.  I also want to take the opportunity to say that we are doing things in this House which are having a negative impact on food production and conventional agriculture, like the votes on plant protection products and on other technologies around agriculture and our trade policy is also having an impact. So when we look at the food supply chain initiative, which I welcome, we are going to have to take a holistic look at what we want for food production in Europe and how we intend to support that type of food production and be careful how we advance.

name: Maria GRAPINI
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, of course, I agree with what you have presented, it is very important what the Commission is doing as a program for 2018, because the end of the mandate of this Commission is approaching. I, as a Romanian citizen, would be happy that in 2018, when my country has two important events (it celebrates its centenary and is the year before the presidency), the citizens of my country should enjoy all the rights of European citizens. On the other hand, as you said, Commissioner, we need a more united Union. This is very important; it is, I think, the main goal, because we can do it all if we are united, if we have the same goals: a Europe where we can have a better social cohesion, to have less poor, uneducated, sick population. These are priority objectives for us, for the group I belong to. We want an ethical European Union, as you said, fair, but for that we need concrete measures to measure the result. I'm glad you talked, Mr. Timmermans, about fairness. People are waiting for this, and European citizens want greater border security. Thanks.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, Mr Timmermans, I will focus on relocation. On Sunday, October 22, I went to Samos, one of the Aegean islands. About 20,000 refugees and illegal immigrants are currently trapped in the Aegean islands. Also, in Greece there are a total of about 70,000 refugees and illegal immigrants. The issue of relocation has not progressed, because the program was implemented only in the third, that is, out of the 17,209 people that Germany had to take, 4,447 have been relocated. In France 3,948 have relocated, while it had to take 12,599 people. You understand that it is necessary, in the legislative action taken, to extend the relocation program, not to stop, to continue, because only in this way can there be a decisive and effective solution.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: Thank you very much, Mr Marias.I would like to point out that in parliament it is not customary for expressions of approval, approval or disapproval to be given from the visitors' gallery.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: - Mr President, Mr Timmermans, you will agree with me that there is no democracy without a good economy. There is no "rule of law" with unemployment, with so many millions of Europeans below the poverty line and poorly paid jobs. There is no "rule of law" when you can do nothing against states that behave so selfishly towards other Member States. And I am referring, of course, to Poland and Hungary, with their unacceptable behavior on the issue of immigrants. You have proposed the creation of the institution of the Minister of Finance. But to whom will it be accountable? Like the Eurogroup, which has no accountability to the European Parliament and the elected representatives of the peoples? What will be its democratic legitimacy? What is the role of the European Parliament towards this person that you will appoint?

name: Jaromír ŠTĚTINA
text: - Mr Vice-President of the Commission, in July we voted on a European Parliament resolution with an impetus for the Commission's work program. Unfortunately, this resolution was not adopted. In your speech, you mentioned important objectives, such as the digitization of the internal market or a comprehensive approach to migration. At the very beginning, you talked about a more democratic Europe. For me, this goal is also the alpha and omega of all efforts. Some third countries and non-state actors are making increasing efforts to challenge the legitimacy of democratic institutions within the European Union through the means of hybrid warfare, including misinformation. In our resolution, we called on the Commission to significantly strengthen its resilience to hybrid threats and to improve its ability to respond appropriately to false reports and misinformation. The European Parliament has repeatedly called for this in many reports and in various fora. However, the corresponding response has not yet occurred. I believe that will happen in the near future.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: - President! I believe that the effectiveness of the Juncker Committee's entire mandate will be best determined by the formulation of opinions in two areas that I believe are of most interest to the majority of European citizens. One is the package of institutions for social Europe, such as the launch of the EU's social pillar, which I think we are all looking forward to, creating the conditions for fair and balanced European labor markets, improving and standardizing the social and legal situation of workers, setting up a Union employment authority, and the completion of a series of initiatives and tasks that have long been advocated by the European left and are now a priority for the President. The other is to take concrete and effective Community action to guarantee respect for fundamental rights and the rule of law and to make them work in practice. The same applies to all Member States, including enforcing EU solidarity where necessary and sanctioning its lack.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I have listened very carefully to the contributions from this House on the Commission Work Programme for next year, and I retain a few things from our discussion.  First of all, I sense that we share a sense of urgency – that we understand that the challenges Europe faces are daunting – and I also see that the vast majority of this Parliament wants to act, and wants us to try and help our citizens regain control over their destinies with measures at a European level that can no longer be taken only at the national level. There is a part of this Parliament that believes in fleeing in a form of nostalgic nationalism, talking people down all the time as though we are on the brink of extinction; as though everything is going wrong, etc. Yes, the challenges are daunting. Yes, we are coming out of a deep economic crisis that has increased disparities in Europe, and that has not led to the convergence we want. But we do have a new sense of shared destiny, which was expressed also in the European Council.  But one thing that perhaps did not get enough attention in that European Council is that if you want that sense of purpose to be translated into concrete measures, you need the co-legislators. You need someone to make a proposal, and you need Council and Parliament jointly to take a decision so that you can implement it. And that is why the Commission Work Programme is not just a bureaucratic exercise; it is a concrete translation of the ambitions that are formulated in this House, in the European Council, and in the Commission. I believe speeches will not solve problems; even the most brilliant speech does not solve a problem. Concrete steps forward on social policy, on the digital single market, on completing the internal market and the banking union, on making sure that the very fundamental issue of the rule of law is something we strengthen in Europe and do not weaken in Europe, and on the fact that we need to deliver concrete results – and we do not have much time left until the next election – that is what we have reflected in the Commission Work Programme.  Yes, there are disagreements amongst us, but this is the Commission’s proposal, and we will look for a majority in this Parliament in a debate. That is how democracy works. I even heard somebody say that the only legitimate democracies are at the national level. What nonsense: every single Member of this House has been elected directly by European citizens and therefore has a mandate to decide with the Council on legislation that affects every single European citizen, and I think we need to understand this responsibility we have. We need to be able to face our voters in 2019 with something we have accomplished and with a plan for the future, and for those of you who have raised the issue of governance in the economic and monetary union, saying that this cannot be a bureaucratic process: that is exactly why the Commission has made this proposal. This should be discussed and mandated in this Parliament if we take these major decisions.  So that is the gist of our proposal for next year, and let me end on one thing: I believe it is also a matter of honour that we acknowledge that some of the problems we face are very, very complicated to solve, but we will not let them go. I refer to what the honourable Member Mr Marias has said: the situation on the Greek islands is still unacceptable, completely unacceptable, and this Commission will never let go of its responsibility to make sure that we solve it. And I do agree with those of you who have said that this requires pan-European solidarity by all Member States. I believe we are in our full right to demand this responsibility in Member States. And responsibility also means that we adhere to the truth, that we do not tell fairy tales about a secret plan to ‘Brusselise’ – or whatever they call it – European populations, or about a secret plan to force people to take migrants. This is not the case.  The only plan we have is to provide European citizens with the tools so that they can shape their futures and their destinies on the basis of their values, and we need to do this collectively. Globalisation will not go away if we take refuge in nation states only. Globalisation can only be harnessed if we as Europeans, act together with a common sense of purpose.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The debate is closed.Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Vilija BLINKEVIČIŪTĖ
text: in writing. - Vice-President of the European Commission, presenting the 2018 The Commission's work program noted that the Commission intends to present next year a social justice package, which will include a proposal to set up a European labor force to address labor mobility and social protection issues. I very much welcome this Commission initiative, which is an important step towards creating a European social pillar, and I look forward to it, but I do not think that is enough. I would like to emphasize that Europe does not need a declarative but an effective European social pillar to ensure that all workers, regardless of the nature of their work, have a decent employment contract and adequate social protection. However, I also miss some of the other important initiatives that the Commission has been asking to draw up and present for many years. For example, although I have been calling on the Commission and the Member States for many years to create a European Child Guarantee, which would provide concrete, financially sound measures to tackle child poverty across Europe, this is not the case for next year's program. There are also no measures to tackle the gender pay and pension gap. This is a problem that we have been talking about for many years, and we ask you to take initiatives to help overcome these differences at European level.

name: Soledad CABEZÓN RUIZ
text: written. - The program reflects the content of Jean-Claude Juncker's State of the Union speech and the letter of intent that the Commission sent to Parliament. It sets an agenda for a more united, stronger and more democratic Europe. With a limited number of new proposals, which will be delivered in May 2018 so that the legislative work in the EP and in the Council can be finalized before the elections. The Commission has already submitted more than 80% of the necessary proposals under the 10 priorities set by Juncker in 2014. They will now focus on pending proposals, to boost jobs, growth and investment, to create a more internal market. deeper and fairer with a strengthened industrial base, and in new specific measures to complete the security union. The second approach of the work program is more forward-looking and aims to shape the Union until 2025. Three principles that must always be the anchor of the Union: freedom, equality and the rule of law. A more united Union will require the full opening of the Schengen Area to Romania and Bulgaria, as well as a prospect of enlargement for candidates in the Western Balkans.

name: João FERREIRA
text: in writing. - Reflecting the crisis of an exhausted capitalist integration process, which has little to offer workers and peoples but more than the same - more social setbacks, more injustices and inequalities, more economic divergence, more attacks on democracy and the rights of peoples decide their destiny in a free and sovereign way -, the European Commission presents a Work Program for 2018 that is not a surprise, but that, nonetheless, is still a cause for concern. The general meaning is that of the continued loss of sovereignty on the part of states, especially peripheral states, to the benefit of the great European powers that control the EU institutions. More neoliberalism. More single market. More investment for the arms industry; a militaristic and security drift, with consequences in terms of suppression of rights; continued attack on the right of asylum, refugees, the most basic values ​​of solidarity and humanism. Forgotten is what was truly necessary. Strengthening cohesion and its instruments. Support for the productive sectors of the countries most affected by the divergence - agriculture, fisheries and industry. More employment with rights. The defense of public services and the social functions of States. Investment in disaster prevention, the environment, science and technology.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: written. - The program reflects the content of Jean-Claude Juncker's State of the Union speech and the letter of intent that the Commission sent to Parliament. It sets an agenda for a more united, stronger and more democratic Europe. With a limited number of new proposals, which will be delivered in May 2018 so that the legislative work in the EP and in the Council can be finalized before the elections. The Commission has already submitted more than 80% of the necessary proposals under the 10 priorities set by Juncker in 2014. They will now focus on pending proposals, to boost jobs, growth and investment, to create a more internal market. deeper and fairer with a strengthened industrial base, and in new specific measures to complete the security union. The second approach of the work program is more forward-looking and aims to shape the Union until 2025. Three principles that must always be the anchor of the Union: freedom, equality and the rule of law. A more united Union will require the full opening of the Schengen Area to Romania and Bulgaria, as well as a prospect of enlargement for candidates in the Western Balkans.

name: Krystyna ŁYBACKA
text: in writing. - As part of the Commission's work program for 2018, I draw attention to the role of the European Union in supporting Member States in reforming and modernizing education systems. In line with the subsidiarity principle, the Union should be more involved in this process and work with Member States to identify and implement major reforms that will equip Europeans with the skills and qualifications necessary to function in a dynamic, rapidly changing socio-economic reality. The key goal for us should be to offer a high level of education throughout the Union. Contemporary education, also academic, is not only the transfer of knowledge and scientific achievements, it is also teaching the ability to select and use knowledge in practice. Striving to improve the quality of education is a continuous task that requires the involvement of all stakeholders, improvement and adaptation. New didactic solutions supported by digital technology are important, allowing for a personalized model of education favoring interdisciplinarity. It is also necessary to change the management of the education system aimed at promoting high-quality education and social inclusion. I also pay attention to teachers' support and the pursuit of teaching excellence. Ultimately, a quick and effective integration strategy is also needed in connection with the influx of refugees.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: written. - Today we are discussing the last important work program of this legislative period. And the citizens of the EU expect one thing above all else: That we finally tackle! Europe will or will not be social. The headings of the social pillar must be filled with concrete legislative proposals, because Europe needs more than a non-binding social etiquette. This includes a framework directive for decent working conditions, basic security for children in poverty, the anchoring of social policy in the European Semester and the creation of European minimum standards. The European labor market authority is an important step here! We also have to force the multinationals to pay their taxes. The discharges from the Panama Committee of Inquiry must serve as a roadmap for the Commission. The withdrawal of the European I-Group from the work program is a huge success. It was only through pressure from us Social Democrats that we were able to build up resistance in the EU Parliament and thus bring the Commission to its senses. Commission President Juncker warned us that there should be no second class citizens in Europe. So let's get down to it so that we can keep the promise of prosperity for everyone again!

name: Ivo VAJGL
text: in writing. - Ladies and gentlemen, when reviewing the European Commission's 2018 work program, I can see that it largely reflects the needs of the times and faces the challenges that await the European Union next year or in the future. In any case, it should be emphasized here that the program does not meet the expectations relating to demographic change in Europe, intergenerational cooperation, an aging society and, of course, the position of the elderly in society. In this part, I assess the program as not ambitious enough. In the European Parliament, I am pleased with the trend that more and more MEPs are realizing that demographic change and the rights of older people in Europe are an area that will be one of the biggest challenges for the Member States and the European Union. Unfortunately, this trend is not seen in the European Commission's 2018 program. The rights of the elderly are about dignity and basic human rights, which are universal or, if you will, European. Therefore, the principle of subsidiarity cannot be a reason for not doing what EU citizens expect in this area at European Union level. I therefore call on the European Commission to pay more attention to the challenge of an aging society and, together with the Member States, to finally draw up a strategy for responding to demographic change at European level. Older people deserve it!

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: in writing. - The European Commission presents a Work Program for 2018 that is not surprising, reflecting the crisis of an exhausted capitalist integration process, which has little to offer workers and peoples but more than the same - more setbacks on the social plane, more injustices and inequalities, more economic divergence, more attacks on democracy and the peoples' right to decide their destiny freely and sovereignly. The general meaning is that of the continued loss of sovereignty on the part of states, especially peripheral states, to the benefit of the great European powers that control the EU institutions. More neoliberalism. More single market. More investment for the arms industry; a militaristic and security drift, with consequences in terms of suppression of rights; continued attack on the right of asylum, refugees, the most basic values ​​of solidarity and humanism. Forgotten is what was truly necessary. Strengthening cohesion and its instruments. Support for the productive sectors of the countries most affected by the divergence - agriculture, fisheries and industry. More employment with rights. The defense of public services and the social functions of States. Investment in disaster prevention, the environment, science and technology.

name: Rainer WIELAND
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Siegfried Mureşan and Richard Ashworth, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the Council's position on the draft general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2018 - all sections (11815/2017 - C8-0313 / 2017-2017/ 2044 (BUD))

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to welcome Minister Kivine from the Estonian Presidency and Commissioner Oettinger to the European Parliament. The position of the European Parliament on the 2018 budget of the European Union which we are going to vote on tomorrow proposes to you a realistic and honest budget of the European Union. We propose a budget which is innovative, which is future oriented and which enables the European Union to provide the prospect of prosperity and safety for its citizens.  The priorities of the budget for next year in the eyes of Parliament should be firstly growth and jobs, and secondly, the safety, the security of citizens. We want to achieve this by investing in research and innovation, infrastructure, small and medium-sized enterprises, the Erasmus programme; we want to strengthen measures on combating youth unemployment, we want to stand by the side of young farmers. In order to provide for more security, we want to strengthen the agencies of the Union which have responsibility for justice and home affairs, these being: the European Union Agency for Law Enforcement Training (CEPOL), Eurojust, the European Asylum Support Office (EASO), Frontex, Europol.  We want to do more in terms of defence at European level because it makes much more sense to spend money once at European level for defence and then share the benefits of our work, of our cooperation, amongst 28 Member States, many of us being also in NATO and NATO saying it is good that the European Union does more on defence together, that Member States of the Union are also cooperating together. This is a new task for the Union. It is a future-oriented task.  Commissioner, I believe that the draft budget which you presented at the end of May is a very good starting point for the upcoming negotiations between Council and Parliament that will start tomorrow with our vote and which will go on for 21 days. The draft budget is a very good starting point because the Commission is the institution best placed to evaluate the implementation of projects and the real needs on the ground. Beyond this draft budget, in order to achieve the priorities of Parliament which I have just outlined, the European Parliament proposes to increase financing by EUR 22.5 million for COSME. This is the programme which is financing small and medium-sized enterprises. It is there that the job creation process is taking place.  We propose to finance the European Research Council by EUR 15 million more; the SME instrument by EUR 10 million more because there is a very high demand, it has a very good implementation rate; the Marie Curie Excellency Research Programme, because there are many good research projects applying, by EUR 10 million; and EUR 32 million for Erasmus. As we know, 80% of research and innovation programmes under Horizon 2020 would not take place unless they were financed at European level, so there is a clear added value there. In terms of strengthening the agencies of the Union we want EUR 10 million for Europol, EUR 26 million for EASO and EUR 3 million each for Eurojust and CEPOL.  In terms of external relations, because it is in the fundamental interest of the Union to be surrounded by safe countries, we believe we have to allocate our resources primarily to the immediate neighbourhood. It is there that the big risk for the Union is coming from. So we propose to use the resources existing in the budget to finance the southern Mediterranean appropriately and to increase funding there by EUR 120 million. We propose EUR 27 million more for the Eastern Neighbourhood and EUR 35 million more for the Western Balkans.  When it comes to our relations with our partner Turkey, with which we have jointly managed to overcome the migration and refugee crisis, I want to say the following very briefly: as long as Turkey is drifting apart from European standards, we should make sure that particularly the pre-accession funds targeted at supporting political reforms in Turkey should be reduced because, in terms of political reforms, Turkey is moving for the time being into a direction which is completely opposite to European standards.  I am looking forward to the debate, and to the upcoming negotiation with the Council and the Commission in the coming three weeks.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I want to put on record my thanks to my co-rapporteur Siegfried Mureşan, and I want to compliment him on his very sensible approach and the excellent work that he has done. I also want to record my thanks to the shadow rapporteurs for their continued support throughout the process. Members will recall that, in April this year, this House agreed to increase the European Parliament budget for next year by 2.3%. Bearing in mind the effect of inflation and the cyclical cost of preparations for the 2019 elections, I thought 2.3% was reasonable and responsible. It has therefore been my intention that an increase of 2.3% be taken as the benchmark against which all other institutions would be measured, and the level be the target for the overall budget increase. I was particularly pleased to note that the Council followed our lead when they too set their budget at an increase of just below 2.3%.  However, it has not been possible or indeed desirable to peg all individual institution budgets at that level. I have had to take into account a number of exceptional cost demands for 2018. First, the Court of Justice and the Court of Auditors. Both have significantly increased workloads, as well as a number of significant security issues which will have to be addressed. Second, the Data Protection Supervisor. He has been tasked with a new role for which we will have to make provision. Thirdly, the question of strategic communications. I am aware that many in this House consider this to be a key priority, and I know that this view is shared by a number of the Member States. So, to meet that expectation, we shall have to oppose the cuts which are currently proposed by Council when it comes to the coming negotiations. Finally, the EU Special Representative. Both Parliament and the EEAS have been pressing for some time to transfer the cost of special representatives over to the EEAS budget. Clearly, this would be budget-neutral, and so in our proposals Parliament has indicated that it is willing to make provision to cover this transfer in the 2018 budget.  I recommend to Parliament that these cost increases are both reasonable and justifiable, but I would, however, wish to remind Members of the importance of exercising fiscal discipline in order to keep public expenditure under control. To that end, I have identified a number of areas where cost savings could be made. Specifically, I would give the example that I propose a freeze on the budgets of the Committee of Regions and the Economic and Social Committee, and while I am grateful to those groups who have supported this initiative, I am disappointed that the larger groups were not prepared to do so.  Colleagues, in voting on this budget and resolution, this House will set the mandate for the forthcoming negotiation with the Council. I look forward to that negotiation and I look forward to reporting a favourable outcome in November.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, it is a great pleasure and opportunity to address you for the second time during this budget process, as I did on 12 September. I wish to reiterate the same main points I made at the time: that the Council will continue to prioritise the highest European added value points in its 2018 budget proposal, as it has already been doing. And we intend to do that during those three weeks that, Mr Mureşan has already highlighted, stand ahead of us. We stand to stimulate jobs and growth, bolster security and work with migration. At the same time, as you have noticed, the Council has expressed a clear determination to see sufficient margins in the 2018 budget, as this is only prudent. In its deliberations, the Council has scrutinised the implementation capacity extremely carefully to ensure the realistic and efficient use of EU citizens’ funds. Consequently, after the Council adjustments none of the priority areas will see a drop in funding relative to the 2017 budget. I will take, and I have taken, due note of various amendments to Council positions that Parliament has discussed and will discuss. Allow me to make a few very brief remarks in this connection. We are extremely pleased to see that the financial gap between the Council position and Parliament’s position is lower than in many previous years. The Council is, however, extremely concerned about significant increases to certain appropriations proposed by the European Parliament that go beyond the ceiling fixed in the Multiannual Financial Framework. Second, the alarmingly high rate of under-implementation of the Union’s budget, as confirmed by the last amending budget of 2017, and the payments forecast for the next year, as recently published by the Commission, argue for taking a very frugal approach in order to preserve the credibility of both the budget process and the participating institutions. That said, our course of action over the coming weeks has been set out in order to reach a balanced and satisfactory agreement on the 2018 budget. The Council is set to keep to the schedule agreed between our institutions on budget negotiations and to reach an agreement within the deadlines laid down in the Treaty.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, dear Minister Kivine, dear rapporteurs Mureşan and Ashworth, honorable Members, ladies and gentlemen! I would like to express my appreciation to the two rapporteurs for the quality of their preparatory work. You have achieved a broad position in Parliament to an impressive extent. Thank you also for the changes you are proposing, because your changes could avoid cuts in the Commission's draft, and in some areas they even go beyond the budget proposed by the Commission. I believe we have all set ourselves two priorities with this 2018 budget, which will perhaps be the last normal budget that has not yet been touched in any way by Brexit: growth and employment - we should do everything we can to ensure that the delicate ones Plant growth in most European regions and more jobs in many regions - and, secondly, to successfully tackle the issue of migration and external and internal security at European level. If you take the differences between Council, Parliament and the approach of the Commission, an agreement on a 2018 budget in the Conciliation Committee should actually be possible within the next three weeks, given the goodwill of all parties involved. In some programs, Parliament and the Council have different ideas about the financial needs. On the one hand on the subject of competitiveness and research, on the other hand on the employment initiative for young people and on the third on the subject of European external aid. The higher approaches of the parliament are understandable for us. Nevertheless, we want to mention here that there are agreements between the Council and Parliament, especially with the mid-term review, which should not be abandoned in the 2018 budget either. The top-ups: first, competitiveness. Parliament presents an increase of EUR 1.4 billion in heading 1A for the competitiveness programs. We strongly support this because we can demonstrate in the budget implementation of the last few years that, for example, Horizon 2020 or the Connecting Europe Facility are highly efficient investment programs with which we can demonstrate added value at European level in the interests of the Member States, our economy and our people. That is why I am expressly interested in this increase. You want to secure and increase the necessary funds for growth and employment programs. This is also to be welcomed. We should still think of previous agreements here and stick to them. The measures to support young people: For all of us, the further reduction of the excessive youth unemployment that has started in most regions remains a key objective. That is why we decided in the mid-term review to extend the employment initiative and to increase the funds in 2017–2020 by a total of EUR 1.2 billion. We should examine further means in the next few days, based on the existing unemployment rate and the absorption capacity in the member states to use and implement the money sensibly. In the case of the European Solidarity Corps, Parliament is proposing not to enter any funds at the moment. We respect this, as the legislative process is not there yet and so we have to wait and see. In any case, we should do everything we can to ensure that there is no interruption in the start-up phase of our European Solidarity Corps, and so that young volunteers who have registered and who want to take part can redeem and realize their willingness to volunteer without interruption. External Aid of the European Union, Heading IV - Europe in the World, Global Europe: Here we go into the causes of flight and migration at. Here, too, the increases are understandable. At the same time, you propose certain moderate cuts in the pre-accession program and pre-accession aid for Turkey. I can understand that politically. It is very important to me that we remain able to act on the subject of the Turkey-EU agreement. You will have read that six Member States - Austria, Denmark, Finland, France, Sweden and Germany - have now asked us to allow the EU-Turkey refugee agreement to continue. I can tell you that the three billion that have been made available to us through reallocation in the European budget and through fresh funds from the Member States are now largely exhausted in the form of commitments; the payments follow step by step. But if we want to remain credible, if we want to co-finance human dignity for the refugees from Syria, Iraq and Afghanistan who currently reside and live in Turkey, then we have to talk about the next three billion now. This will certainly be a focus of our discussions in the mediation process in the next few days. All in all: I don't see any fundamental contradictions, but rather a good will to come to an agreement. I should also like to mention that our letter of amendment number 1 of October 16 relates to agricultural expenditure and that we have planned certain reallocations here for reasons of updating, including an increase in the amounts for young farmers. I am looking forward to a debate today and then to good deliberations, Minister and honorable rapporteur, under your leadership over the next few weeks, with the aim of having a stable budget for next year in a few weeks.

name: Barbara MATERA
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I speak as draftsman of the opinion of the FEMM committee. We have succeeded in allocating a separate budget line for Daphne III under the "Rights, equality and citizenship" program. The Daphne program allocates financial resources to the protection of children, young people and women against all forms of violence and aims to achieve a high level of protection of health and well-being. Especially in the light of the violence suffered every day by so many women across Europe, there was a need to focus on budget lines and the attention of colleagues in the European Union's Committee on Budgets. In our committee, the majority of colleagues expressed themselves to continue to finance the Institute for Gender Equality as well, so as to be able to use all its skills and resources for the establishment of a European Observatory on Femicide and Violence Against Women. women. Finally, to encourage female participation in the economy, we shared the need to allocate funds to support female entrepreneurship in the COSME program.

name: Barbara SPINELLI
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. – Mr President, I am intervening on behalf of Ms Hübner, Chair and Rapporteur of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, who unfortunately cannot be present. I am very pleased that in its reading on the 2018 Budget, Parliament is defending the spending for programmes that encourage citizens’ participation in the democratic life of the Union, such as Europe for Citizens, the European Citizens’ Initiative and the line dedicated to communication of Commission Representations with citizens. 2018 is the year where preparations for the European elections in 2019 will be in full swing, and we should take this opportunity to inform citizens of their rights and the impact their vote carries for themselves and for Europe as a whole. This was the main concern of our committee, and I am glad the Committee on Budgets took our suggestions into consideration.

name: Charles GOERENS
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Development. - Mr President, I have little sympathy for the Council, which reduces the budget dedicated to development aid by 90% for commitment appropriations, and by 20 million for payment. In addition, Member States are accused by the Commission of contributing too little to the Trust Fund for Africa. However, in 2015, at the international conference on the financing of official development assistance, the European Union, in accordance with the Council's conclusions of the same year, renewed its commitment to increase public aid to 0.7%. development by 2030 at the latest. This commitment is an empty promise, contradicted by the facts. This promise does not bind its authors, but those who believe in it. This behavior is unacceptable, and all the more so since it is at odds with recent declarations of the EU within the framework of the European Consensus for Development, or during the European Days for Development. It would be wise, Mr President, to require Member States which do not keep their commitments to come and explain themselves to the European Parliament's Committee on Development.

name: Morten LØKKEGAARD
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. - Sir. Chairman! We support the approach of freezing the funds allocated to the European Solidarity Fund from Erasmus +, which the Commission has proposed until the necessary regulatory basis is presented. In addition, we find it necessary in the committee to add DKK 50 million. EUR as envisaged for Erasmus + already in 2018. To address the chronic underfunding of both the cultural sub-program under a Creative Europe and Europe for Citizens program, I support the rapporteur's approach of boosting funding for these programs. I would also like to support the allocation of more money to the budget line for multimedia measures to ensure an understatement of independent coverage of sufficiently high-quality EU material. Finally, I would like to reiterate my intention to introduce the activities of the very successful preparatory activity A New Tale of Europe within the Erasmus program as a youth program.

name: Cristian Dan PREDA
text: draftsman Opinion Committee on Foreign Affairs.- Mr President, I was the draftsman of the opinion in the Committee on Foreign Affairs for the 2018 budget. The Commission and the Council have called for half a billion euro cuts in foreign policy.Our committee was against this position and I thank my colleagues in the Committee on Budgets who supported the AFET position.In AFET we have highlighted three areas of great importance: the first is to support the European Union's neighborhood both in the east and in the south;the second area is the proper financing of the common foreign and security policy;and, last but not least, the third priority: supporting enlargement policy in the Western Balkans.As for Turkey, the AFET Commission has been very clear: we want some of the accession funds to go to civil society so that we can make sure that in the future we can have a democratic Turkey at the table.

name: Alain CADEC
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Fisheries. - Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, like every year, the budgetary procedure is an opportunity for parliamentary committees to present pilot projects with a view to improving the Union's public policies. This year the Committee on Fisheries has proposed a pilot project to improve the management of sea bass in the Atlantic. This fish is caught not only by professional fishermen, but also by recreational fishermen. It is therefore important to put in place management measures adapted to this reality, which allow all players to have their place in this fishery. The pilot project of the Committee on Fisheries will test innovative means of control for recreational bass fishing. This will allow lawmakers to consider introducing a monthly logbook for recreational fishermen to replace the current daily limits. This pilot project will also improve data collection on seabass stocks. It should also support the establishment of multi-year management plans. Concretely, this involves programming long-term fisheries management measures in order to ensure the necessary visibility for professional fishermen. This is essential to achieve the objectives of the common fisheries policy.

name: Tibor SZANYI
text: Rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Agriculture. - President! I assisted the report as rapporteur for the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. Thus, together with colleagues in the field, I strengthened the key role of agriculture and rural development in the budget. This area, so the agricultural area, contributes to the EU's fundamental objectives, which is why we cannot allow any budget cuts or redeployments. Areas such as active farmers, producer groups, the fight against unfair commercial practices, the issue of market observatories, phytosanitary measures and the smart approach provide significant security and outbreaks in Europe's depopulated rural areas, while ensuring Maintaining Europe’s food production capacity. I must emphasize in particular the role of pilot projects and preparatory actions, which are particularly important in setting political priorities and preparing new initiatives. We can develop permanent EU activities and programs through them, such as the concept of “Smart villages”.

name: Deirdre CLUNE
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs. – Mr President, the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs reached political consensus on the opinion that lines should be maintained at the level that has been proposed by the Commission and as has been said, 2018 will be a pivotal year for the Union. As we approach the end of this mandate, we must ensure that we leave a good framework in place. That means funding must be maintained for important employment lines like the European Social Fund (ESF), and the year-on-year increases that have been proposed in smart and inclusive growth and indeed in economic, social and territorial cohesion are welcomed.  In particular, the Committee wanted to ensure that youth employment initiatives were protected and that funding for the Youth Guarantee has been held and that funding increases for the Youth Employment Initiative are agreed as a matter of urgency. The proposal for establishing the European Solidarity Corps was welcomed by the Committee which made it clear that the funding should not come from established priority funds like the ESF but should come from the global margin for commitments. We also welcomed the proposed increase to the maximum envelope of the European Globalisation Adjustment Fund (EGF). However, we would stress the need for flexibility in this area, in its applicability criteria, because unemployment numbers can affect smaller rather than larger Member States to different degrees.

name: Jerzy BUZEK
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. – Mr President, this is the last budget of the EU 28 and we need successful implementation of our ambitious policies because there are citizens’ expectations. So, in this context, the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy regrets the significant cuts in Horizon 2020. We cannot expect the EU to be more innovative and competitive when our framework programme is used as a financial source for other projects, no matter how important.  Another issue: cuts to COSME and the Council’s reductions to the SME instruments: to create an SME—friendly business environment it is crucial to provide the necessary financial instruments.  Last but not least, financial resources for the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIT), the Agency for the Cooperation of Energy Regulators (ACER), the European Union Agency for Network and Information Security (ENISA) and the European Global Navigation Satellite Systems Agency (GNSS).

name: Markus FERBER
text: Draftsman for the opinion of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. - Mr President, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council, ladies and gentlemen! We in the Economic and Monetary Committee only have a small budget to administer. The most important thing for us are the three supervisory authorities. We are - I believe - clear that the three regulators have to be financially well resourced in order to fulfill their mandate. But they should limit themselves to their mandate and not go beyond it. The premise must always be that there is a budget only for tasks that are also covered by the legislature, and that requires the supervisory authorities to be faithful to their mandate. We definitely see room for improvement here. We think it is correct that the Commission proposed for the review of the three supervisory authorities that industry should also make a contribution here. However, we want to ensure that the EU budget will continue to be used in order to be able to perform the supervisory functions. Last point: one of the three supervisory authorities will have to leave London after the British vote. Here we want the first funds to be made available for the 2018 budget year so that the relocation of the European banking supervision can proceed smoothly.

name: Joachim ZELLER
text: Draftsman for the opinion of the Committee on Budgetary Control. - Mr President, Minister, Commissioner! Two time lines will meet in the 2018 budget year. The EU 2020 strategy, the current MFF, the current funding period and the terms of office of Parliament and the Commission are drawing to a close. At the same time, it is important to lay the foundations for European politics after 2020. The balance sheet and the outlook meet. It is therefore necessary, from a budgetary control perspective, to check whether our efforts and instruments have achieved the agreed objectives. At the same time it is important to determine how we are realigning ourselves. For example: 80% of direct aid in agriculture goes to 20% of the beneficiaries. Was this how we were able to stabilize incomes, especially those of the smaller farms? A multitude of financial instruments makes it almost impossible to maintain the necessary parliamentary control of the budget. Substantial contributions from the Union budget go to trust funds. So far, however, they have eluded a meaningful review by Parliament. We expect more transparency in 2018 on these and similar questions that we have set out in our statement.

name: Petr JEŽEK
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs. – Mr President, it is clear that there are not enough funds available to deal with the migration crisis as well as the security challenges we currently face in the EU. Indeed, polls have suggested that these areas are the ones Europeans expect the EU to do much more on. As rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs on the 2018 budget, I advocated that further money be allocated to deal with these crucial areas. In addition, we pushed for more funds for the agencies which are at the forefront of the Union’s response. We also need to ensure that the agencies in the area of justice and home affairs are adequately staffed. Therefore, we advocated that these agencies be exempt from the staff reduction targets of 5% under the multiannual budget. In tomorrow’s vote I call on our colleagues to give the rapporteurs a strong mandate for their discussions with national governments in order to ensure that the Union and its agencies can respond in the most effective way possible to the challenges we face.

name: Reimer BÖGE
text: Draftsman for the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. - Mister President! International trade and the agreements that go with it can be a crucial instrument of foreign policy by bringing growth and employment to the regions of the world. But if they are open and rule-based, they also have to do with opening up the values ​​and principles of an open global society. If we have an ambitious trade strategy for everyone in the next few years with many new, supplementary trade agreements, then it is important that we firstly provide the Commission with enough man and woman power to not only negotiate but also understand and agree see how trade deals develop. We must ensure that the funds for Aid for Trade are an indispensable instrument for advancing structures and projects, especially in less developed countries, so that they can benefit from these developments. I also believe that technical assistance and economic aid are very important to our direct neighbors to the east and south of the European Union. One last thing, Mr President: in the longer term, we will also have to talk about including macro-financial assistance, which should be better equipped, in the European Neighborhood Instrument in order to increase the coherence of the European Union's measures.

name: Iskra MIHAYLOVA
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. - Mr President, on behalf of the Committee on Regional Development, I express its opinion as rapporteur for the 2018 budget. We emphasize the importance of cohesion policy as a fundamental Union public investment policy based on solidarity and contributing to the creation of growth and jobs. We emphasize the need to ensure an appropriate level of appropriations to cover cohesion policy payments, in order to demonstrate the Union's ability to meet its commitments and build confidence in it. We note the unacceptable delays in the implementation of current programs, which have so far undermined efficiency, and we are concerned about the small number of payment requests submitted under the 2014-2020 programs. We call on the Commission to continue to focus on the results of the implementation of the Union budget and support all steps taken towards a results-based approach. We welcome the new financial package of 140 million, designed to facilitate the implementation of the Structural Reform Support Program.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, Commissioner, rapporteur! I think it is important for all of us that the European Parliament's budget also set priorities. We start with: As requested by the Council, we will of course also comply with the 1% reduction in posts per year; there will be internal shifts. But I believe that this target is of course not only a target for the European level, but it would also be very gratifying if the finance ministers at home in their own countries were to implement the 1% post reduction to show that they are doing it this statement is really serious. Of course, we are also focusing on preparing for the next European Parliament elections in 2019. Above all, we want to protect democracy in Europe. We do not want forces that are against democracy and only invest in the military to weaken Europe's soft power here. We also want to make our administration much more efficient, which means that we have pushed the Konrad Adenauer project in Luxembourg accordingly. We want to consistently implement the digitization of processes and the continuation of the introduction of the Irish language and also review the studies on Brexit and the funding of green transport accordingly. There is also a lot to do in the parliamentary budget for MEPs. In recent years there has been a lot of bureaucracy in the house, with a lot of reviews and audits. This requires additional massive activities from the MPs. The officials in Parliament are also burdened accordingly. We are therefore in favor of returning to the flat rate systems, that flat rates are paid. It's efficient, it's cost-effective and the best option for taxpayers. The flat rates are a matter of course in our Member States too. We don't want anyone to have a flat rate take away, we want to force this system.Last point: I believe that we have now proposed that interns in the European External Action Service should be paid.I think that's right, but this budget line must also be endowed so that we give young people the opportunity to get to know the European service and to work for the added value of Europe.

name: Daniele VIOTTI
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, allow me to start with a non-ritual thanks to the rapporteur, my colleague Mureşan, for the work he has done and for how he wanted to involve all Parliament and all political groups in the construction of this budget, which we are presenting today and that we will vote tomorrow. I thank him for his availability and for having understood and interpreted the requests coming from citizens and also for having presented the budget today. I say this very sincerely, so there is no misunderstanding: I think we all agree in this House, at least we parliamentarians, that this is not yet the budget we want, because we cannot think that a budget equal to '1% of Europe's GDP is something satisfactory and that it gives answers to the challenges we have. And these are no small challenges: work, growth, help to our small and medium-sized enterprises, an economy that responds to the environmental challenges we have, responses to growth, issues related to migration flows, transport, common defense, as you ask us. With this budget we try to give some answers, we try to give those answers that, in our opinion, from our point of view, citizens ask us: the 600 million euros more we put on the initiative for young people, the increases to restore the correct figures that the Commission had put on Horizon 2020, on the CEF, all this means giving opportunities to our companies, our universities, our research bodies, municipalities and regions, that means. In the same way, on the issue of migration, we finally try to make a reasoning that comes out of the logic of the crisis, because we can no longer talk about the migration crisis, we can instead give answers that are lasting over time, both as regards aid. humanitarian, both as regards the reception in our countries and therefore have resources also for solidarity - even if solidarity, honestly, cannot be bought and does not have a figure, that must be given to us. You see, Minister Kivine, I have heard your words: You are concerned, you have said that you are concerned about the increases proposed by Parliament. I'm honestly worried about the rise and unemployment numbers, just to give you an example. And I believe that the conciliation that we are going to open in a few weeks is a phase in which we must seek answers to those concerns and not to the concerns of budgetary rules. I also see that we are all also worried about how populisms, anti-European parties, etc. are becoming increasingly popular. I try to give you a solution, I try to tell you what the answer can be: go back to politics. Go back to politics and give answers to the concrete and true problems of citizens. I think, Minister, that there are these opportunities in the conciliation phase that is opening up. It's up to you. I do not want to be disrespectful, but I am a bit tired - I think we all are - of hearing the heads of state and government tell us that this Europe does not work, and then when there is an opportunity to put in standing something, to give answers and to have a Europe that works, then there is no political will to give these answers. There is an agreement, there is a possibility of an agreement - we are getting there, we can do it. What you call a satisfactory and balanced agreement, Minister, must be an agreement that is satisfactory for the citizens and balanced in response to the challenges I have listed.

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - Mister President! When we talk about the 2018 budget, we experience the same game as every year: the Commission makes a proposal, the Council cuts this proposal, and the European Parliament increases it again, regularly even above the level of the Commission. You don't have to be a prophet to say: in the end, after all the negotiations, we will be very close to the Commission's proposal again. We have a crucial flaw here in our entire process, which is based on the fact that, especially here in the European Parliament, we believe that we can always call for more money. We should finally realize: this is European taxpayers' money; We cannot dispose of that indefinitely; we should use the money in the way it is made available to us, and that is usually somewhere close to the Commission proposal or the proposal of the Council. The decisive factor for me is not the call for more money, but that we use our money appropriately, purposefully and in a focused manner. In particular, this means that we have sufficient funds for the migration crisis, but also for security, research and ultimately to strengthen competition. Competition is not strengthened by permanent subsidies, on the contrary, it is even weakened. That is why we advocate abolishing permanent subsidies, with the exception of small areas such as environmental protection. Instead, we have to make subsidies degressive. That would strengthen competition, that would be real subsidiarity in practice, that we would go back to the freedom and personal responsibility of the Member States. Therefore we will not be able to support this draft. Nevertheless, I would like to thank both the Commissioner for his draft and the rapporteurs for their excellent work. (The speaker is with it I agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr. Kölmel!My question is: We have decided here in Parliament that interns have to be paid, so we want to do away with unpaid internships.We have now planned to increase this sum in the Foreign Service.Do you think it is justified to pay interns in this area?

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr Rübig, thank you very much for this question.Of course, it is perfectly fine to pay interns, just as you should pay anyone who does a job, and pay appropriately.If, however, you imagine the financial sums here in terms of size - we are talking about a budget in terms of volume - depending on whether you accept the obligations or the means of payment - of EUR 160 billion - I believe we can go along with thatthe internship salaries do not bring about a restructuring of our budget.

name: Anneli JÄÄTTEENMÄKI
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I thank the rapporteur, Mr Mureşan, for his good and effective cooperation. I think we have a balanced position. We are investing in sustainable growth, tackling youth unemployment and creating opportunities for SMEs to create new jobs. These are all very important living conditions for Europe's future growth. I am pleased that our position is a requirement for EU climate funding increase. We cannot lag behind the goals we have set for ourselves or our international commitments. The Commission must make realistic proposals to achieve the objectives. I would like to remind you that we, as the budgetary authority, are a lot of guards. The acceptability of the EU in the eyes of citizens is often measured by how the Union spends its money, how efficiently, fairly, transparently and effectively. The position in this House has long been that the EU budget can be constantly increased. We are hesitant to make additions, but we have not excelled in the search for savings, that is what we have to say. In many Member States, however, the reality is different. There is great caution about increasing the EU budget. It is obvious that savings must be made after Britain leaves or will leave. I hope that, with a view to the next annual budgets, and in particular the next financial framework, we will also come together to think about areas where we can save or use existing money more efficiently. The Union's priorities are changing and the new priorities must have the necessary funding. However, this cannot mean that priorities will only increase. Similar savings must also be found to finance the new priorities.

name: Liadh NÍ RIADA
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. – A Uachtaráin, ba mhaith liom mo bhaochas a ghabháil leis an Uasal Rubik chomh maith as an tacaíocht a léirigh sé don teanga Ghaeilge san óráid a bhí ar bun aige.  Cé go gcuirim fáilte roimh ghnéithe áirithe de bhuiséad 2018, níl an méadú suarach seo sásúil agus tá an Pharlaimint agus an Coimisiún aontaithe ar an bpointe seo agus tuigeann siad go bhfuil gá le hinfheistíocht atá níos réadúla.   Tá imní orm nach bhfuil a dhóthain i mbuiséad 2018 chun stop a chur le himirce daoine oilte.  Níl a dhóthain anseo chun forbairt a dhéanamh inár gceantair tuaithe ionas go mbeadh deis acu slí bheatha a chruthú agus an tuath a tharrtháil.  An fhadhb is mó agus an cheist is mó maidir leis an mbuiséad seo ná cá bhfuil an tiomantas agus gealltanas á léiriú i dtaobh fostaíocht a chruthú.  Cá bhfuil an gealltanas i dtaobh ár ndaoine óga, cá bhfuil an gealltanas i dtaobh tacú lenár SMEnna, lenár n-iascairí? Is baolach gur easpa tola atá ann arís agus arís eile.  Mar fhocal scoir a chairde, táim ag iarraidh ar gach feisire anseo tacú le leasú 17 sa vóta ar bhuiséad 2018 amárach agus tacaíocht agus teachtaireacht láidir a thabhairt do mhuintir na hÉireann go bhfuil tacaíocht acu ón teach seo maidir leis an bpróiseas síochána in Éirinn agus le Comhaontú Aoine an Chéasta, go háirithe i gcomhthéacs Brexit.  Go raibh míle maith agat.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I am glad to take the floor to share my agreement with the position taken so far by this Parliament. Our Group very much welcomes the increase to the Commission’s budget, with EUR 2 billion in commitments and EUR 3.3 billion in payments and other good things mentioned by rapporteur Mr Mureşan earlier in his speech. Of course, one can argue that the budget is still not green enough, and I hope that next year the Commission will come up with a better proposal, but in that context, I would like to underline the great help and understanding given by the Alliance of Liberals and Democrats for Europe (ALDE) Group and in particular by Mr Deprez and Ms Jäätteenmäki to improve their understanding in the budget to address the climate change policies.  I will not pursue in this debate my stance on some of the other institutions’ budgets and their questionable techniques in assuring the funds they want. Mr Ashworth as a co—rapporteur mentioned them all, and I am a man who remembers – or perhaps in this context, does not forget – so that is why I will wholeheartedly support the position of Mr Ashworth taken in this aspect. And of course in the end of my intervention I have an appeal for the Council Presidency: however small and pressed you feel there between Berlin, Paris, Rome, Madrid and Warsaw, always remember the national epic of the Estonian nation: ‘Kalevipoeg’. „Ülemaks kui hõbevara, kallimaks kui kullakoormad tuleb tarkus tunnistada.“

name: Jonathan ARNOTT
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, a bit like a merry—go—round at a fairground, everything comes back around – regular as clockwork –once a year. In fact, I could probably save myself a couple of minutes and simply play a recording of last year’s speech, because the issues are pretty much the same this year as they are every year.  We know the drill: I could very easily say that these are our taxes, that we voted for Brexit, or that the EU is not spending its money efficiently or effectively, but I will not repeat and rehearse all the old arguments. I would note, though, that when politicians focus on the EU budget as a share of gross national income (GNI), that does not tell the whole story to the general public because the percentage of government spending is, of course, much higher than the percentage of GNI, and of course other government spending may well entail compliance costs with EU legislation.  When I spoke on this subject in committee, and indeed it has been the same in this debate today, I pointed out that the language that we use in these debates seems to be always the language of ‘cuts’ – it is all about how much a proposed cut here or a cut there is supposed to be. But, actually, what we are talking about here is still an increase, and the discussion is whether it is an above—inflation increase or a below—inflation increase.  What I want to see are genuine cuts, and for two reasons. One is that, with Brexit coming, there will, at one time or another – depending on how negotiations go – eventually be a shortfall. Two, I believe that on many projects it is just better and more efficient to cut out the middleman and for nation states to do things directly themselves. For saying that in committee, I was accused of populism, so I thought I would take a look at the word ‘populism’. I looked it up in the dictionary, and it tells me that populism is support for the concerns of ordinary people and the quality of appealing to – or being aimed at – ordinary people. It just strikes me that only in this place could caring about ordinary people possibly be construed as being some kind of insult.

name: André ELISSEN
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (NL) Mr President, today we are discussing the 2018 EU budget. To my regret, it still contains the greatest possible nonsense expenditure. In order to counterbalance the Europhile party, I and colleagues have tabled a number of amendments. I will give a few examples. Stop European funds to fight unemployment, economic recession, poverty, the migration crisis and security threats. Above all, just leave this to the sovereign states. The Youth Employment Initiative has completely failed to solve youth unemployment and must be stopped immediately. Despite immense expenditure by the EU in recent years, a solution to the massive migration and human smuggling in Europe has still not been found. And finally, the EU's stance on Turkey is hypocritical and cowardly. Turkey should never become a member of the EU. Negotiations must therefore be stopped and no more billions should be sent to Turkey. If it were up to me and my party, we will stop today with the ineffective, money-wasting European Union and Parliament. This budget strengthens my conviction.

name: Diane DODDS
text: – Mr President, I acknowledge that this is a budget about normal budgetary procedures and is in a pre-Brexit scenario. For my part, I believe it should be directed at growth, jobs and prosperity, and not the usual list of unnecessary items. However, in voting to leave the European Union, the British electorate declared that Brussels could no longer demand their taxes or dictate the spend.  Our legal obligations to the EU budget should end in March 2019. That is not to say that we will cut and run: we should honour existing commitments under a fair and reasonable settlement. However, this cannot be done in isolation. The block on trade talks is about coercion and not cooperation. It is detrimental to mutual progress, and we should find ways of moving forward.

name: José Manuel FERNANDES
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Mr Representative of the Council, dear colleagues, once again, we have Parliament united and with clear priorities: we want more jobs and, in particular, youth employment, we want external and internal solidarity, we want a competitive economy and we want social and territorial cohesion. It is also repeated the fact that the Council, once again, makes cuts, and cuts without any rationality. The Council even cuts back on its own priorities - cuts against its proclamations and cuts against its own commitments. It is not acceptable, for example, to cut Horizon 2020, which has an excellent execution, which is the largest research program in the world and which is essential for innovation and the competitiveness of our economy. I challenge you to explain why you cut 491 million euros in commitments and 111 million euros in payments in this program. The Youth Employment initiative must be improved, but it must continue. Support for the backbone of our economy, which is SMEs, must also be increased. Cohesion policy is essential. External solidarity is also important. And then, Commissioner and Council, it is essential that we increase the implementation of cohesion policy. It is also essential that we have sufficient payments for the purpose of these programs, which are in the hands and management of the Member States. The European Union's budget is only 1% of gross national income. It would be interesting to ask how much it would cost the European Union not to have this budget. I have no doubt that it would cost much more than this 1% of gross national income, which proves the need to increase it, but also the importance and added value of this same budget.

name: Jens GEIER
text: - Mr President, dear Commissioner Oettinger, Minister, dear colleagues! In our votes today, we adopted a resolution on the next medium-term financial framework, and this resolution reiterates that the European Union's budget is currently underfunded. Against this background, it is particularly important for me to underline that new tasks that the Member States are entrusting to the European Union can only be financed with additional money. I am thinking particularly of the call for additional efforts in the area of ​​the common security and defense policy. Our colleague Kölmel from the Conservatives just said in his contribution: We should get by with the money that has been made available to us. That is a noble request. When I imagine: We have a pot of soup and the eaters are sitting around it and they are just getting full. And then there is an additional eater, which is security and defense policy in this case, but the soup is no longer. Then not everyone will be full anymore, and to that extent you cannot always get by with the money that is made available to you. This becomes particularly clear when we also think of the European Fund for Strategic Investments. We all want this fund to succeed. But we all want there to be investments in innovation and research - even the Council wants that. Mr Fernandes was right in pointing this out. I therefore cannot understand, Minister, why you are concerned here about the European Parliament's proposals for increasing additional efforts of EUR 416 million in research policy and over EUR 800 million for better transport routes and transnational power lines in Europe. These are investments in the future and in jobs in the European Union, and we should agree on that.(The speaker agreed to answer a question on the blue card procedure under Rule 162 (8) of the Rules of Procedure.)

name: Bernd KÖLMEL
text: Ask about the “blue card” procedure.- Mr Geier, just a quick question.You rightly ask: yes, where should one cut?Would you agree with me that the area of strengthening competitiveness should be critically examined if there are areas that have been promoted for decades and that obviously competitiveness has not yet been increased?

name: Jens GEIER
text: Answer to a question about the “blue card” procedure.- I have no exact idea what area you are thinking of.When we hold such a discussion in Germany under such auspices, one generally thinks of agricultural policy.I am not saying that it is not possible to save in this budget.But I say that if the Member States take a position and say that we no longer want to pay into the budget, but we want the budget to do more and more, then tensions are inevitable at certain points.

name: Zbigniew KUŹMIUK
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! In the debate on the 2018 draft budget, I would like to strongly support Parliament's position of canceling all the cuts made by the Council in the draft presented by the Commission. Parliament's attempt to increase commitment appropriations of nearly EUR 2 billion over the ceilings proposed by the Commission, including 366 million for the Youth Employment Initiative, as well as the rebuilding of funds for Horizon 2020 and Connecting Europe, is also worth highlighting. An increase in the amount of EUR 110 million in the "Security and Citizenship" heading also deserves support, because although the number of immigrants arriving in EU countries has dropped, more than one hundred thousand have arrived for nine months, which necessitates additional support for the host countries. Also, the reinforcement of the "Global Europe" section with an additional amount of EUR 300 million will provide an opportunity for more generous support from African trust funds to support their development and thus prevent further waves of immigration from Africa to Europe.

name: Jean ARTHUIS
text: - Mr President, Minister, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow we will vote on our own vision for the 2018 budget. As chairman of the Committee on Budgets, I would like to pay special tribute to our rapporteurs, Siegfried Mureşan and Richard Ashworth, for their excellent work. I support the two major axes that our general rapporteur wanted to give to this budget, growth and employment, in particular vocational training for young people, on the one hand, and security and migratory flows, on the other. I would mainly like to stress the additional endowments needed in particularly successful programs, such as Horizon 2020 and Erasmus +, as well as in agencies which are growing in the fields of asylum, external border control and police cooperation. Erasmus +, the thirtieth anniversary of which has been brilliantly celebrated, generates frustration as more than one in two applications is rejected for lack of funds. The parameters of the upcoming negotiation are fairly simple: no revision of the financial framework, no arrears of payments. But nothing is over and, if we want to lead the conciliation in November and conclude it, I urge the Presidency to free itself from the eternal internal contradictions in the Council, between the short-sighted rigor of net contributors and vested interests. beneficiary countries, between the deep cuts in future programs and the under-use of cohesion funds - may I stress that we are going to return 10 billion euros at the end of 2017 due to the under- consumption? -, between the major declarations of the European Council and the weaknesses of European solidarity on the ground. Let’s not forget that this budget, due to Brexit, will perhaps be the last funded by 28 member states over twelve months. This is how urgent it is to agree on the future that we hear give to Europe.Which budget for which Europe?At this stage of the budgetary process, we remain confident, we are eager to vote on budgets that give the Union the means to prepare for our future and to protect us, budgets that speak to Europeans, budgets that demonstrate to public opinion.effectiveness of European added value.

name: Xabier BENITO ZILUAGA
text: - Mr President, despite the proposal to increase the budget for 2018, we still do not measure up. In this budget we sacrifice migration and asylum funds in favor of a nefarious migration control policy that they try to disguise as development cooperation, but which is a policy unworthy of the name. Regarding investments, you maintain your Juncker plan, providing financing to private investments that were surely going to be made as well, and when you decide to invest, as with the “Connecting Europe” Mechanism, you do so in large fossil energy infrastructures, that is to say , more and more gas pipelines.
