Without resources, ladies and gentlemen, there is no real policy. For example, without investment, after youth employment plans, there will be no new youth employment. Without appropriate investments, we will continue with a disastrous and job-destroying production model. What is needed is a public investment plan for Europe. These budgets only serve to dirty the atmosphere, fatten the bills of the big energy companies and feed the false ghosts of immigration. Europe does not need more or less speed, but what it needs is a different direction.

name: Jordi SOLÉ
text: – Mr President, as we are approaching the final period of the current multiannual financial framework (MFF), we would like to see a budget that finally gets closer to our priorities in terms of EU policies which are: full and higher-quality employment, solidarity towards poorer territories, but also to those citizens that have to endure harsher economic and social conditions across the EU, commitment towards sustainability of our planet, and tackling real sources of instability and inequalities across the world.  Therefore, we basically support the deal reached in the Committee on Budgets, according to which we reinforce programmes such as COSME, Horizon 2020, Erasmus+, or the Youth Employment Initiative, as well as climate related programmes like LIFE +, further measures on migration and refugees, and so on.  I hope that Parliament’s position, which is a bare minimum to us, to our Group, will not be yielded during conciliation and I thank the rapporteurs for their work.

name: Marco VALLI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am sorry to point out to this House that no effort has been made this year to try to reduce the costs of politics. The Parliament, in fact, wants to restore most of the cuts made by the Council for many items on which concrete and substantial savings could have been foreseen, especially on administrative expenses. The same Parliament has foreseen an increase in its costs, increasing its budget by 2.3% compared to 2017. We are talking about almost two billion, again this year, on the shoulders of taxpayers. Unfortunately, the costs of politics increase every year, the double headquarters in Brussels and Strasbourg continue to cost hundreds of millions a year and, even if there is a majority in this Parliament and among the Member States, they do not want to eliminate it. European funding for parties and foundations continued to increase, going from less than 17 million in 2009 to a proposal of almost 52 million for 2018. This budget line, which the 5 Star Movement rightly does not use, should be fully canceled. Among other things, the gap between the privileges of those involved in politics and the enormous sacrifices required of citizens is still too strong. Just think of the privilege of the members of this Parliament: a pension is provided without paying a euro of contributions, all borne by the citizens on whose shoulders, on the other hand, pension reforms are made, as in Italy the Fornero reform. In addition to administrative waste, in our opinion, useless and harmful projects must be cut, such as the Turin-Lyon railway section, which does not bring any added value for the dome, even criminal at times, of public contracts and subcontracts, which, in infrastructural in Italy, we have seen how you work very well. Not to mention the failure of the Juncker plan, which did not bring any additionality with its projects. Finally there is a point for us fundamental, which is that relating to breeding and financing for bulls.It is important that this item is no longer financed because it is a medieval tradition, which in no way supports the founding principles of the European Union, and by continuing to allow the regularity of these funds we continue to finance a barbaric and medieval practice.(The speaker agrees to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)))

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: question "blue card".- Dear colleague, you are talking about divestment, and in particular Lyon-Turin.Do you think that it is by abstaining from investing that the European Union will give work to its children and, in general, allow economic development?

name: Marco VALLI
text: Answer to a "blue card" question.- You have to do an environmental and economic impact assessment when you spend a lot of money.The Turin-Lyon project puts tens of billions of euros on the table for the next few years.I believe that there are other priorities than this useless work, when it is possible above all, by spending less, to fix the existing line.This type of mega-infrastructure projects usually earn the big subcontractors who then, very often, also have organized crime under the hood, as regards Italy, and companies that work, even cross-border, between France and Italy.Therefore, it is necessary to better evaluate the infrastructure projects, including the Turin-Lyon, which should not be financed.

name: Barbara KAPPEL
text: - Mr President, Minister, Commissioner! In the 2018 financial year, Union measures will be financed which, primarily from an economic and social policy point of view, stand for sustainable growth and more jobs. This is to be achieved through more investments in education, in research and development, in infrastructure, in small and medium-sized enterprises. I would like to emphasize two priorities that Parliament's draft report provides. These are the increase in funding for the Youth Employment Initiative from EUR 366.7 million to a total of EUR 600 million and the restoration of the Connecting Europe Facility and Horizon 2020 budgets. In Horizon 2020 alone, the Council's proposal included cuts of EUR 500 million in commitments and EUR 120 million in payments, despite the fact that Europe is currently missing EUR 150 billion a year in R&D and 83% of the total projects financed under H 2020 would not have been possible without EU funding. According to Parliament, there should also be more funds for other programs that create growth and employment. These are Erasmus + with plus 32 million, COSME with plus 22.5 million and the REC. The provision of financial support for small and medium-sized enterprises is also essential. That is the most important driver for growth and employment in Europe. Corresponding budget lines also for the expansion of the digital infrastructure and for the successful implementation of the WiFi4Europe project.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, as has already been said in this House, I voted today in a position of the European Parliament on the new MFF, on your communication, of course. I think it is a very solid and very good position, which I think can support you in developing the new proposal for the MFF. Our colleagues think they worked very well. There's a colleague here, the other one I don't know if he's in the room. I think it will also help you to come faster than announced, ie in May 2019, with this proposal. Regarding the budget for 2018, our colleagues have done a very good job again and I think that the main direction of the budget is economic development, jobs, things that Europe needs at the moment. I hope that, in conciliation, you will support Parliament, so that it does not happen again as usual, with the Council wanting to give absolutely nothing, but only trying on the principle of reducing its national contributions to reduce various directions that are important, including Erasmus, and support Parliament, which wants to be a budget for the people. I would also like to support some requests from the Committee on Transport. First of all, the recovery of the money from CEF for FC, which is very important for the Transport Commission. You saw that the works were very successful and that there were a lot of participants in the tenders and I would just like to draw attention to one very simple thing: I don't understand why you can't find very small amounts of money, under ten million euros, in order to complete the coverage of the EGNOS system, a system that is vital for air transport.

name: Isabelle THOMAS
text: - Mr President, I in turn would like to congratulate our rapporteurs, Siegfried Mureşan and Richard Ashworth, who have done a remarkable job and who have worked in harmony with the majority of Parliament. Before turning to the budget, I take advantage of the presence of the Council representatives to ask you, Ladies and Gentlemen, to change the leaders' program. Indeed, it was validated while ignoring and in contempt of respect for Parliament and the Commission, proposing to conclude the future multiannual financial framework at the end of 2019, that is to say when there will be, at the same time , constitution of Parliament and of the future Commission. Thank you for hearing this request. Regarding the budget, I would like to emphasize two points. The first is a simple principle: consistency. We share with the Commission and the Council most of the priorities for 2018: investment, jobs, sustainable growth, management of migration challenges. Proof of this is that we are planning to increase these budget lines. Therefore, in order to maintain this consistency, we will not be able to accept any reduction in these amounts during the negotiations. The second point is our determination in the fight against youth unemployment, a scourge which affects the very future of the European Union. Commissioner, I would not want there to be any misinterpretation of what we are proposing. In no case are we proposing an advance, a frontloading in 2018 of the appropriations provided for by the revision of the multiannual financial framework in order to relaunch the initiative for young people. What the majority of this Parliament wants is for the European Union to invest half a billion euros in the youth guarantee for 2018. Billions are being announced to support strategic industries, billions to boost investment, very good! So for 2018, we need half a billion against this social catastrophe of unemployment among young people, half a billion for solidarity and to prepare for the future.You can be sure that this will be a point on which Parliament will be uncompromising in the negotiations to come.

name: James NICHOLSON
text: – Mr President, I would also like to congratulate both rapporteurs. I think we are all well aware that the months and few years ahead could be quite rough, and we will have quite a rocky road to travel. Not only is the overall budget going to be under pressure, but with the UK leaving, the remaining 27 will probably also have problems, as the UK may have. As it stands, with the UK’s departure the CAP budget is going to be hit particularly hard. That is something I would certainly want to see put right, because this is just one of the many areas that the 27 Member States will have to face up to. However, I have always put on record that Europe, through the budget, has been extremely positive for my region of Northern Ireland, and I hope that will continue. But I fail to see how that can continue if the UK is not here to represent its regions. I hope that this message will get back to Mrs May, that when she makes her proposals for continuing aid it is taken into account. Because if you do not have representation it is very difficult to make sure matters are managed properly.

name: Gérard DEPREZ
text: - Mr President, first of all my congratulations to our two rapporteurs, Siegfried Mureşan and Richard Ashworth, who have done - we all agree - a remarkable job. For my part, I will not repeat what has been said before me, and excellently, the chairman of our committee and several speakers. I would like to limit myself to welcoming a few advances that I consider significant in the draft budget for 2018. I want to welcome the strengthening of the appropriations allocated to defense research. It is a pressing need in the current state of destabilization of our eastern and southern flanks and we must move forward towards a European Defense Union. I welcome the reduction or reallocation of pre-accession aid which Turkey is currently receiving. It is time to show Erdogan that his authoritarian drift is not bearable and that he must stop insulting European leaders. I welcome the strengthening, requested by the citizens of all our countries, of the resources devoted to the fight against terrorism. Europol, in particular, needs more staff and more operational funds to improve coordination between the police and security forces of our Member States. Lastly, I welcome the fact that the resolution proposed to us expressly calls, on my proposal, for the creation of a financial assistance mechanism for victims of terrorist attacks. Our financial solidarity cannot be limited to the consequences of fires, earthquakes and floods. In a Europe that sees itself as a Europe of values, the blood that flows deserves at least as much attention as the water damage.

name: Marie-Pierre VIEU
text: - Mr President, the budget is the accounting transcription of our political priorities. In times of difficult economic recovery, I think it is important and positive that the Union gives priority to research, education, climate change and, of course, the fight against youth unemployment. I think that there lies the European added value which, in the face of identity withdrawal and nationalist temptations, can counterbalance the obsession with austerity which has characterized budgetary policies in recent years. I would nevertheless like to make two essential remarks on the proposed budget. On the one hand, I am against the growing funding of a militarist and security Europe, because military research and the co-funding of returning migrants cannot form the basis of a mobilizing European project. On the other hand, the free trade policy, the treaties of which collide directly with industrial and agricultural policies, cancels out all or part of the benefits of the latter. Priority therefore to ecology, democracy and securing the course of life.

name: Marco ZANNI
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, once again in the budgetary procedure there is little courage and proof that the European Union is a failed project, a project that will not have a great future. As usual we are witnessing this negotiation, this debate where the Commission asks for more resources - every year it asks to increase the budget - and the Council and the Member States want to cut and refuse to give more resources, indeed they would like some back . I believe this is truly proof that this project cannot go on. We must ask ourselves why the Member States do not want to invest additional resources in the budget but want to keep them on their national territory to invest them in other ways, without sending them in a complex way to Brussels. There will be a reason why they prefer not to invest in an instrument that today does not give the expected results in terms of growth, in terms of new development, in terms of job creation. The reality is that the EU budget today is burning billions of euros in failed projects, which have failed to achieve those promised goals - I am talking about the Juncker plan, I am talking about the billions burned for the Youth Guarantee, I am talking about, for example, new projects on common defense or the support of funds for Africa. My question is: if we already struggle to achieve results within our borders, let alone what the results may be by going to operate in other countries. And of course there is a continuous increase in administrative expenses. What is the European Union doing? He decides to ask for more money for propaganda, to communicate to the citizens - who have discovered the deception of the Union - how beautiful the European Union is and how many beautiful things it does. This is not the way to proceed, and we will see it in the coming months.

name: Lefteris CHRISTOFOROU
text: - Mr President, first of all we have to really thank and congratulate the co-rapporteurs, Mr Ashworth and Mr Siegfried Mureșan, who have done an excellent job of making the budget more humane, more social, in line with the expectations of the people. The message must go to the European Commission itself, but also to the European Council. I think it is very important that this budget focuses on the development of small and medium-sized enterprises, on the employment of young people, to create impetus and growth, especially in small countries that do not have the same access and the same opportunity as the big countries and have the opportunity. and the ability to raise funds and funds through the budget. Ladies and gentlemen, the very principles and values ​​of the European Union do not allow me to vote for even one euro for Turkey. A country that violates and flattens principles and values ​​and constantly insults the European Union itself cannot receive funding from the European Union. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen of the European Council, you must send the message that European taxpayers, if asked, will not accept a single euro to finance Turkey in any way. A country that violates human rights, owns my own country, a member state of the European Union, violates principles and values. It does not mean a solution to the Cyprus problem without keeping occupying troops, guarantees and invasive rights, it openly provokes, it even obstructed humanitarian aid to Turkey. And here I must point out that at the same time that we are giving almost 150 million to the Turkish Cypriots, we cannot agree to prevent aid to our captives. And I really want to invite all my dear colleagues to we send the message that the European Union is strong and no Turkey can blackmail it, no Turkey can really behave so unacceptably.And one last thing: the chapter on European defense and security is important, we support it, we support the European army, because only then will the European Union be shielded and provide security and guarantee to all the member states of the European Union and to my own country thatis in significant danger from Turkey.

name: Jean-Paul DENANOT
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, tomorrow - I hope so in any case - our European Parliament will vote a clear rejection of the drastic cuts proposed by the Council in the general budget 2018. This vote will be a strong sign, as opposed to a incomprehensible and - I would dare say it - irresponsible position, completely out of step with the real needs of European citizens. Today, I must tell you, I am worried. Of course, we are increasing the sums allocated to the initiative for youth employment, of course, we are providing substantial assistance to young farmers who are settling, of course, our position reflects explicit support for all sustainable policies in the sectors of employment, energy and social inclusion and yet today I am worried. I am worried that the coming budget conciliation will turn into a farce and that Member States will force us to adopt a budget, once again, at a discount. I would like to remind you that the 2018 budget - like the others by the way - cannot be voted on without the consent of the European Parliament. If his voice was not to be heard, our room should, I believe, consider refusing him.

name: Sander LOONES
text: - Turkey and the European Union, it's not exactly a love affair.On the contrary, it may be a relationship of understanding at best because Turkey is where it is and in these uncertain geopolitical times that is a relevant trade-off.At the same time, I really think it's time to be honest.Is it important that Turkey does not slide further?Is it important that Turkey does not choose Russia?Yes, that is important.But does this mean that Turkey should just become a member of the European Union?No.No.It is time for us to recognize this and consistently implement it.That also means that we must stop giving money to Erdoğan under the European heading of accession aid.But what do I find?Also in this European budget, 589 million euros will go to Erdoğan next year under the heading of accession aid.That has to get out.We have to stop doing that.Citizens expect more from us.We must deliver that to them too.

name: Miguel VIEGAS
text: - Mr President, this budget is conditioned by a short financial framework in view of the objectives proclaimed by the institutions of the European Union and which reflects a deep crisis of confidence that has led the Member States to cut back on this multiannual plan. A financial framework that cuts across cohesion and the common agricultural policy in favor of items related to defense and armaments and to which this budget naturally gives expression, as is the case with the External Action Service, which aims to recruit 5,000 people . A budget that gives Turkey twice the amount foreseen for the Erasmus program, due to a deal concluded by Germany in spite of the rest of the Member States, but which nobody was opposed to. A budget that focuses on financial instruments and the conditionality of support, while cutting the funds allocated to research. In short, it is a budget that does not present consistent solutions to relaunch investment and counteract the route of social and economic divergence that is accentuated with the deepening of this process of capitalist integration in the European Union.

name: Dominique BILDE
text: - Mr President, this budget shows, once again, a flagrant absence of a long-term vision, avoiding the financial consequences of Brexit, which should nevertheless be anticipated. The same goes for funds intended for security and for migrants, since the European Parliament is counting on a drop in migrant arrivals. However, they started to rise again this month. The European Union therefore risks having to drain its emergency funds for lack of a lasting solution. This lack of anticipation is also reflected in the budget cuts which affect the heart of a true European project for the future: research and training. Thus the Erasmus + program sees its funding cut in favor of a European solidarity body, which we guess will mainly benefit NGOs helping migrants. I will therefore not support these arbitrations, which are symptomatic of a Europe without a project, locked in short-termism and headlong rush.

name: Daniel BUDA
text: - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the general budget of the European Union for the financial year 2018 seems to be a balanced one, although it had a less desirable start, given that the Council has made cuts in certain key areas, but which have was partially corrected along the way, which is why I congratulate the two rapporteurs. However, I believe that it is extremely important to be anchored in the realities on the ground when discussing the long-term efficiency of spending. It is not enough to tick an expenditure related to an area without assessing, in a concrete way, the impact of these expenses and, in particular, the benefits and sustainability of the investments. In the field of agriculture, we must take into account the major challenges of this sector, ranging from the phenomenon of aggressive aging, from the lack of labor, to the search for new markets. That is why I believe that the program for the installation of young farmers must be further supported, as a guarantee of preventing the depopulation of rural areas. At the same time, we must ensure the sustainability of these farms in the medium and long term, by identifying new markets as we continue to face the Russian embargo. However, I believe that we need to be extremely careful with the trade agreements that are concluded at the level of the European Union, referring in particular to the one with the Mercosur countries. Such an agreement is likely to create major difficulties for us, given that farmers in these countries are not required to comply with any limits on cadmium, glyphosate or antibiotics, which allows them to obtain a unit cost per unit. produced far below that obtained by a European farmer, and this affects the long-term sustainability of European investment in agriculture. I believe that the agricultural sector, research and innovation in this field must continue to be funded consistent, so that we can ensure both the efficiency of farmers and the protection of consumer interests, which can benefit from quality products at affordable prices.

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Parliament's position on the European budget for 2018 is very clear on the cultural side: let's strengthen programs for education, training, youth and culture, let's not use Erasmus + as a treasure trove to draw from according to the needs. Restoring the budget allocated to the European Solidarity Corps is not an opposition to the initiative, but adopting and reaffirming the right order of things. In the same way, the formalized proposal to increase the funding foreseen in particular for the Erasmus youth sector is more appropriate than ever, a unanimous position of the CULT commission, which is part of the strategy aimed at reaching more and more children and young people outside the country with Erasmus funding. from traditional training courses. Hence the indication is to multiply the Erasmus + budget in the next financial framework and make it a program for all Europeans. On a more general level, then, if we want a Europe more up to its ambitions, the 2018 budget begins with a path towards a significant increase in the allocations of the next financial framework, to be obtained to a greater extent with own resources. It is a choice that can no longer be avoided. (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Rule 162 (8)).

name: David COBURN
text: blue-card question. – In the annual budget report, the Council proposes to cut EUR 240 million in payments, and you call another EUR 750 million proposed by the Council unjustified. Normally economic liberals want to cut taxes. In the European Parliament, they want to do the opposite. Guy Verhofstadt in the 1980s and 1990s was called the ‘baby Thatcher of Belgium’, and he believes now that we need special European supranational taxes. Surely you would agree with me that taxpayers in Europe are fed up having their pockets picked just to pay for more grandiose and mad projects? Surely you agree with me, sir?

name: Luigi MORGANO
text: Answer to a "blue card" question.- It seems to me that he is posing a problem of a more general nature.It is clear that if we move towards the direction of own resources, the transfers from the Member States are reduced.This is a choice of field, but also to strengthen the European Union.I think you disagree because you clearly have a preconceived political position;unfortunately dialogue, when there are preconceptions, is very difficult.I am not supporting at all, with my position, what you have said.

name: Tiemo WÖLKEN
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Oettinger! I would just like to address three issues very briefly here: Firstly, the fight against youth unemployment in the European Union. This is of particular importance to my group and me. I am therefore pleased that we have at least achieved an increase in the funds for the fight against youth unemployment to EUR 600 million, even if I would have liked more. Second: financing the European Solidarity Corps. I welcome the idea of ​​the ESK; it brings young people together and strengthens European solidarity. As the budget rapporteur on this subject, however, it is important for me to emphasize once again at this point that new initiatives require new money. Thirdly, I would like to address the issue of fighting poverty worldwide. We prevented the irresponsible 6% cut in development spending. With the increase in funds in heading IV of the budget - Europe in the world - we have already set the first correct signal. Last week, I and many colleagues had many ONE youth ambassadors there who are committed to the fight against poverty worldwide, and they call on us to spend EUR 100 million more on education and development aid - I think: an appropriate demand.

name: Andrey NOVAKOV
text: – Mr President, in my view, this budget will be the biggest jewel of Europe’s crown next year – not because it is one of the biggest ever proposed, but because it is reflecting European cities, European regions and European citizens’ needs – and I am underlining this: needs, not wishes!  EUR 2.5 trillion in 20 years are invested in European regions. No one has ever been even close to this, and it was the right thing to do. Moreover, this institution has always been one of the most ambitious when it comes to the budget – the right thing to do. It was the right thing to do to ask to restore all cuts proposed by the Council. It was the right thing to do even to increase the draft budget proposed by the Commission, because a great step forward needs brave investment, not cuts.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, sustainable growth and employment, especially youth employment, security and climate change must remain high on our agenda. The cuts proposed by the Council must therefore be rejected, which said it was ready to spend in the sectors in which the European funds guarantee greater added value, only to propose a series of cuts. If the European Union wants to be credible, it must invest in research, innovation and policies to combat unemployment, providing more funds to programs such as Connecting Europe Facility and Horizon 2020 and allocating adequate resources to initiatives for youth employment, without neglect agricultural and cohesion policies, which are the real backbones of the European economy. More resources must also be allocated to manage both the internal and external dimensions of the migration and refugee crisis, in order to follow up on the policies undertaken in this field. During the conciliation phase, therefore, Parliament must have clear ideas about the real priorities to be pursued.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, again "spectators in the same project", in an austerity budget, in a budget that supports violent fiscal adjustment, a budget that does not have the funds to tackle unemployment, to fight poverty, does not have the funds to development. A budget of no more than € 150 billion, at a time when Mr Draghi has allocated € 1.7 trillion through quantitative easing. You realize that this process can not proceed. At the same time, it is a budget that gives money to Turkey, a country that holds 37% of the Republic of Cyprus, a country that threatens Greece, a country that violates Greek airspace. How is it possible to give money to Erdogan, who is very aggressive? A budget that gives money to Albania, which oppresses the Greek national minority in the Northern Epirus, which demolishes the houses of the Greek national minority. Is it possible to vote on such a budget?

name: Jan HUITEMA
text: - (NL) Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, the European Parliament must look much more critically at its spending pattern. The available budget is now the starting point. This provides the perverse incentive to actually fully spend the budget. As a result, no or hardly any priorities are set. Unlike in national parliaments, it does not seem politically interesting in this House to be left with money that flows back to the taxpayer. Of course there are issues that we need to tackle at European level, such as terrorism, improving the European internal market and guarding Europe's external borders. However, I see a lot of money being wasted on political showpieces. Think of free train tickets, a European museum and even an extra budget for sending Christmas cards. Taxpayers' money must be handled differently. I therefore propose a European "salmon standard": income should no longer determine expenditure. Parliament has to deal with any setbacks itself. If more money is spent on the one hand, it will have to be cut elsewhere.

name: Takis HADJIGEORGIOU
text: - Mr President, if you will allow me at the outset, I would like to make an appeal to the representatives of the European People's Party, not to say that I want to make an objection. They come here every year and support an increase in funding and then, when they go to the discussions that follow, they support what they disagree with here. In other words, they support the reduction of funds. This always happens. We cannot be populist here and go where decisions will be made and do something different from what we support here. Secondly, Mr Oettinger, I want a clear answer to this: you have left an implication for the attempted reduction of funds to Turkey, and I am referring to the funds related to the accession process. You specifically said "I understand the issue of funds to Turkey". This "understanding" puts me in some trouble. Do you agree or have a different opinion? And I'm not talking about the funds that have to do with refugees. I am referring to the funds that have to do with the accession process. I want to know if you end up disagreeing with this or not.

name: Eleftherios SYNADINOS
text: - Mr President, the 2018 budget fully reflects the Union's misguided political priorities, the Islamization and de-Christianization of Europe, the rise of terrorism and illegal immigration, the rampant action of NGOs and, of course, the control and control of state . Funds are spent in neighboring, indifferent, if not hostile countries, such as Turkey, under the guise of Union security, and not in suffering Member States. This is not the Europe that the people want. A Europe that, while we all realize that it is headed for disaster, its political elite is only concerned with the financial management of the Union and the Member States. Basic principles of the Union are being violated, and in areas such as social security, pensions, health systems and education, the Union is abusive, although explicitly prohibited by the Treaties. The citizens of the Member States will not remain inactive in this political coup that is taking place. Especially the Greek people, who for seven consecutive years experience the so-called solidarity and subsidiarity of the partners through the imposition of memoranda and the recession.

name: Patricija ŠULIN
text: - In the European Union, we have to face many challenges, so we need a budget that is not a toothless tiger.The budget must respond to the challenges arising from the complex geopolitical environment, the still weak economy in the European Union, as well as to support the European Union's readiness for the future.I support additional funding for security and for young people.A better security situation in the Union will not fall from the sky for free, but the competent institutions must be given adequate resources to work.Young people still have serious employment problems in the labor market as well as in starting a family and solving housing problems.Helping young people to become independent is an investment in our future and in the future of the European Union.However, I am against reducing funding, as the Council wants in the areas of research, innovation and infrastructure investment.€ 500 million less today for Horizon 2020 is like parking European researchers in the parking lot.

name: Costas MAVRIDES
text: - Mr President, in this budget there are funds for which the rapporteurs are to be congratulated, for example, on growth, employment, security and migration management, and in particular on youth unemployment, which remains a scourge in Europe. , and we expect that there will be no cuts when we move on to the next step of the negotiation. However, ladies and gentlemen, and I am addressing the Commission, I am impressed by the arguments in favor of continuing funding for Turkey and for Erdogan. I am impressed by the fact that, while we all know Erdogan's behavior, we continue to reward them. We know the behavior of Turkey and inside, but also in the Member State called the Republic of Cyprus, and towards Greece. So I ask: how do we decide which countries to impose sanctions on and which countries to reward, as we do in Turkey today?

name: Milan ZVER
text: - Thank you very much, Mr President, for allowing me to speak on this subject.I am the European Parliament's standing rapporteur for Erasmus + and I feel obliged to thank all those colleagues who have supported the increases in the next Erasmus + budget, which is, in fact, a success story.For the last three years, this program has been very successful, we can also say that it is somehow the best investment in the future of the European Union.However, in some sub-programs the success rate is still relatively low, even 24 percent of applications are accepted in some places and this means that more than three quarters of applications are rejected and this is of course not good.So the potential of Erasmus + is much greater than the financial capacity of the European institutions at the moment, so thank you again to all of you who have supported the increase in the budget for Erasmus +.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: - Mr. President, I greet Commissioner Oettinger, the main message of the 2018 budget is that although funds are limited we want to clearly show that we can and want to respond to the challenges facing the European Union, and this can be seen through the budget.Thus, security and stability and challenges such as youth unemployment, the fight against poverty, the need for new knowledge and skills, innovation, investment in small and medium enterprises are also highlighted.The second message is that we want to accelerate cohesion policy, the implementation of projects, because these are projects that are visible in the daily lives of our citizens and are needed to strengthen the European economy.The third message is that we do not want to reduce the amounts for Horizon 2020 and the Connecting Europe Facility, because these programs are the key to the basic infrastructure, fundamental for achieving stronger growth, and that is our ultimate goal.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: Member of the Commission. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen! We have noted down all your concerns and your focal points, priorities and what is important to you and what you see critically and will then evaluate Parliament's position very carefully after your vote and decision tomorrow. Before the concertation begins, we will send the Council and Parliament a detailed written opinion in which we will show what the two-way effects of amendments are. I will also pay particular attention to the topic of pre-accession aid for Turkey and show you which projects we have financed in recent years and what the starting position for 2018 is for pre-accession aid, in order to discuss with you the scope for action of the cut. We believe that this opinion will make the discussions easier, and I am also convinced of today's debate that we have a good chance of receiving a new 2018 budget on time.

name: Ivana MALETIĆ
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, thank you for this opportunity to listen to the extremely succinct points made by the committees, the surprisingly balanced views made by the political groups and the extremely rich interventions by the Members. Highlighting or commenting any of one would do gross injustice to the others, so I will not do that. I will just reiterate the Council’s willingness to work really hard with the rapporteurs appointed by Parliament and Commissioner Oettinger to turn this summer of discontent into an autumn of conciliation.

name: Siegfried MUREŞAN
text: rapporteur. - Mr President, thank you. Many thanks to Commissioner Oettinger and Minister Kivine for the constructive spirit of their speeches. I would also like to thank in particular my colleagues in Parliament, the shadow rapporteurs from all the political groups, with whom I have worked very well. This clear and strong position of Parliament would not have been possible without their support. I would also like to thank the rapporteurs for their views on the various parliamentary committees I have heard today. Parliament's position is extremely well-founded. All requests for more resources for certain budget lines are well-founded and, colleagues in Parliament, I know, I have always thought three times before accepting a budget request, because, indeed, our priority must be to manage the public money carefully, with maximum restraint. That is why we want to allocate money to exactly those areas where citizens are waiting for the European Union to deliver: growth and jobs, on the one hand, and citizen security, on the other. In order to achieve these objectives, we have also proposed a package of pilot projects and preparatory actions that reflect the political will of the majority of Members of the European Parliament. Thank you all. I look forward to the discussions, the conciliation negotiations within the next twenty-one days.

name: Richard ASHWORTH
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, the annual budget is always a complex process and this 2018 budget, being the last year before Brexit and the last before the set of European elections in 2019, will bring its own unique challenges.  I want to thank colleagues for their comments this afternoon and I have taken on board the views that they have expressed. It serves to remind us what a wide range of spending priorities there are in this Parliament and it serves to remind us of the strength of expectations there are within the committees.  Tomorrow we vote on a mandate. It is a mandate which will take us into the budget negotiations with the Council. I hope that we have a clear mandate because then we, the rapporteurs, will go into negotiations united, we go into the negotiations with a clear set of priorities and we go into the negotiations with the determination to ensure that we deliver value for money, and added value, not just to the Member States but to European citizens.

name: Paul RÜBIG
text: - Mister President!I would just like to say that we have over 1,800 amendments to the budget for tomorrow and over 120 roll call votes, one of which costs the House an average of EUR 400.I find that scandalous.I believe that we should not vote in this context.I would ask that the budgetary procedure be considered as it is currently going.That is totally unacceptable to taxpayers.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Thank you, we will pass on the proposal.The debate was closed.The vote will take place on Wednesday, 25.10.2017.Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Tamás DEUTSCH
text: in writing. - The European Parliament's plenary will vote this week on its position on the 2018 EU budget: the EP would significantly increase EU funding. We are particularly pleased that, after the Committee on Budgets, the plenary is expected to adopt my proposal to increase cohesion funding by EUR 240 million to the level of the European Commission's 2018 draft. As a record amount of development funding will continue to come to my country in 2018 thanks to government efforts, it is important to have enough money in the EU budget. The European Commission must continue to pay the money due to Hungary in 2018. The European Parliament has today voted on its resolution on the European Commission's reflection paper on the future of EU finances. During the parliamentary negotiations on the post-2020 framework, our most important task is to bring as many EU development resources as possible into the Hungarian economy and to ensure EU support for Hungarian agriculture.

name: Sandra KALNIETE
text: in writing. – Tomorrow Parliament will vote for the EU budget for 2018 which includes a budget line for EU Strategic Communication and equips the EEAS with adequate staff and tools to face the challenge of disinformation from third states and non-state actors. I hope the Council will listen to this call and will allocate adequate resources.

name: Pavel POC
text: in writing. - The ministers of the Member States are happy to appropriate the successes they are achieving only on the basis of European cooperation or on the basis of the action and pressure that we in the European Parliament are exerting. It is a rather unpleasant surprise that in a case such as the draft budget, they propose cuts for programs that have the highest success and added value. These are the programs that Europeans have promised and that they logically count on. I am pleased that the Committee on Budgets has passed a proposal that takes into account the commitments we have made and the goals we must achieve. An example is the increase in funding for the Horizon 2020 science and research program. It is, among other things, the primary source of funding for European cancer research. I would also like to add that I do not agree that the Commission has presented a draft budget that does not take into account the results of the Court of Auditors' report. Although the Union has promised to spend 20 percent of its funding on climate change by 2020, we are still below that limit. We see a similar scenario in the case of biodiversity protection, where, according to the Commission, there would be an increase of only 0.1 percent. I believe that the European budget should proportionately reflect the problems, threats and risks that Europeans are currently facing, and I therefore call on the Council to take this into account during the trialogue.

name: Bogdan Andrzej ZDROJEWSKI
text: in writing. - In the face of the challenges facing the Union, I consider the budgetary debate a key issue in defining the EU's political strategy. I would like to point out that, while maintaining budgetary discipline, the necessary financial resources from the Union budget must be used to meet political priorities and enable the EU to meet its specific commitments. The key issues for me are strengthening the economy, competitiveness, employment, in particular for young people, and security. However, education and culture directly related to strengthening a competitive knowledge-based economy should not be forgotten. As a member of the CULT committee and the long-term budget rapporteur for this committee, I would therefore like to emphasize in particular the role of adequate support for programs in the field of culture and education and call for the allocation of sufficient commitment and payment appropriations to these programs to ensure that they are properly implemented in line with their objectives. and to tackle their low success rates due to under-funding. These programs have clearly demonstrated their European added value and enjoy unflagging popularity among the beneficiaries. I consider it to be an issue that requires priority action, not only in this year's budgetary procedure, but also in each subsequent one, to counteract another payment crisis. Therefore, I recall that any increase in the level of commitment appropriations should be accompanied by a corresponding increase in appropriations for timely payments.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Bart Staes, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets, on the discharge for implementation of the European Union general budget for the financial year 2015, Section II - European Council and Council (COM (2016)0475 - C8-0271 / 2016 - 2016/2153 (DEC)) (A8-0291 / 2017).

name: Bart STAES
text: Reporter. - (NL) Mr President, Mr President of the Council, ladies and gentlemen, for the seventh year in a row, unfortunately, I cannot recommend that you grant discharge to the Council. To grant discharge, ladies and gentlemen, that is not an abstract thing. That is the end result of a thorough exercise, an exercise in supervision and control by Parliament of how the money from the European budget, and thus the European citizen and taxpayer, has been spent over the past year. Were the correct procedures followed? Can it be substantiated how much money was used where? Moreover, did the resources used ensure that citizens got value for money? The basic premise of any proper and proper discharge should be that everyone who spends money from the European budget must be monitored in a transparent manner as to how it was done and also whether it was done responsibly. The European Parliament is responsible for this exercise in accordance with the Treaties of the European Union. The Council makes a recommendation to the European Parliament on this matter. Unfortunately, since 2011, the European Parliament has refused to grant discharge to the Council, based on the fact that there is an ongoing power struggle between Parliament and the Council, and also on the basis that Parliament has a habit of to put questions to institutions to which it must grant discharge, both in writing and orally. The Council takes a purely legalistic position and believes that the European Parliament should really only grant discharge to the Commission. That is not in line with practice. Parliament puts questions to the Commission, puts questions to the Secretary-General of the European Parliament, puts questions to the Economic and Social Committee, the Committee of the Regions, all agencies. The Council, on the other hand, refuses to answer our questions. The Council therefore refuses dialogue. It must be said - I admit it: there is progress. The Council is presenting more and more information on its website, so that little by little we find out what is happening with the budget of the Council, the Council of Ministers and the European Council. Nevertheless, relations between Parliament and the Council of Ministers remained particularly tense until last year. Let's face it: only dialogue ultimately leads to a solution. At the start of my mandate as rapporteur, I therefore met the Secretary-General of the Council. Ms Gräßle, Chair of the Committee on Budgetary Control, did the same. We wanted to find out what the outlines are for arriving at a modus vivendi, to improve relations between Parliament and the Council when it comes to granting discharge. After long and extensive discussions with my shadow rapporteurs, in close consultation with the chairman of the Committee on Budgetary Control and in close consultation with the coordinators of all political groups in the Committee on Budgetary Control, we have reached an agreement. That agreement was presented to the Conference of Presidents last Thursday and since then we, as Committee on Budgetary Control, have a mandate to enter into negotiations with the Council of Ministers, myself as rapporteur, Ms Gräßle as chair of the Committee on Budgetary Control and in the presence of Klaus Welle, Secretary-General of the European Parliament. What are those contours? What is that mandate? 1. The Council and the European Parliament play different roles in the discharge. The European Parliament grants discharge. The Council gives an opinion and a recommendation to the European Parliament on the discharge. 2. The recognition that the Council and the European Parliament must do this on the basis of correct facts and correct information. 3. We ask the Council to commit to answer the written and oral questions put to them by the European Parliament. In return, we as the European Parliament say: if you, Council, have any questions for the European Parliament, then we are ready to answer those questions in a form of good reciprocity.The result of this mandate and of the negotiations should be that the tension between Parliament and Council is resolved and that we can deal with each other in an open and transparent manner, so that the public also learns during the discharge exercise how to deal withthe 540 million euros that the Council spends annually.I hope, Mr President of the Council, that our offer will be one where we can enter into dialogue, where we can finally resolve our conflict and properly resolve a discharge between Council and Parliament.

name: Bart STAES
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, as a Council President I have the somewhat ambiguous pleasure of standing in front of you and speaking on the matter. However, I will try to be as to-the-point as I can and, taking it from where the honourable rapporteur ended, from the Council’s position we also see a faint glimmering, a sparkle of hope, in moving things towards improvement.  Going through my formal statement, it is my duty as President of the Council to identify the two aspects of this reiterative annual process: both going through the same procedure as every year, but also now seeing some potential for movement.  The Council’s position, however, stands. It says that the Council has always scrupulously respected Article 319 of the Treaty according to which the European Parliament, acting on a recommendation from the Council, gives a single discharge to the Commission. As you know, over recent years the Council has considerably improved access to relevant information about the activities, the governance and the financial management of the institution. This is, by the way, recognised in the text of the resolution you will be voting on.  As in previous years, the European Court of Auditors did not detect any serious weaknesses in respect of the issues examined for the Council.  In 2011, the Council transmitted to Parliament the draft memorandum of understanding in order to organise better the cooperation between our two institutions during the discharge procedure. The Council has always been open to discuss concrete issues and concrete drafting. I understand today that the Conference of Presidents has recently agreed on a mandate in this regard and we think this could be a new momentum. I hope that our institutions will have the opportunity to discuss this soon.

name: Marian-Jean MARINESCU
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, I have listened carefully to the President's reply. I believe that much more needs to be done to reach an agreement between Parliament and the Council, a somewhat artificial agreement because, in the end, the treaty says very clearly: we need to deal with this discharge for the Council as well. I think that this year the Parliament has made great efforts. We had a working group and, with the help of the rapporteur and the other rapporteurs of the political groups, we managed to come up with a proposal, I think, decent and normal - I repeat once again, in line with what the treaty says - and which will it gives the public the opportunity to make clear what is happening with the public money that is allocated to the Council. The rest I think are things that should not happen between two institutions that are, in fact, responsible for granting the discharge, according to the treaty, and I think we need to get over this. As I have said several times in plenary, in other years, on the occasion of the budget discharge, as long as the budget discharge is not granted to the Council, nothing happens, in the end this procedure is derisory because why to other discharge institutions if nothing happens with the non-granting of the discharge to the Council. So, I think that in the end we have to be two serious institutions that have to comply with the provisions of the treaty.

name: Inés AYALA SENDER
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - Mr President, yes, this year 2017, the Court of Auditors has offered us the possibility of a finally non-negative DAS. On the other hand, in the case of the Council, and despite the efforts that I acknowledge to Mr Staes and Mrs Gräßle, it is going to be the eighth year in which we denied and nothing happens. However, as we are optimistic, we believe that at this time there are small steps, but they are significant. As said, there is a new Secretary General with a mandate until 2020, Mr Tranholm-Mikkelsen, in the Council, who already in 2012 made the greatest efforts at the head of the Danish Presidency in the case of discharge of 2010. There is also a mandate from the Conference of Presidents to a parliamentary working group - of this Parliament - that must be able to rebuild trust and cooperation between institutions, so fundamental in the interests of greater transparency. And there are some movements of rapprochement that have been achieved as part of the annual activity reports of parts of the Council - general directorates. They are small steps, it is true, but they are necessary to rebuild trust and who knows if one day, in the end, in the Interinstitutional Agreement we will have clear guidelines for this discharge.

name: Ryszard CZARNECKI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, I feel like I am experiencing déjà vu during today’s debate. The lack of cooperation from the Council, and the difficulties repeatedly encountered in the discharge procedure that we have because of that fact, keep on going. First, the Council continues to be silent in relation to the remarks made by us in our discharge resolution from April, reiterated from previous years. Then, neither have the budget of the European Council and the budget of Council been separated, nor has the Council joined the Union transparency register. The Council’s whistle-blowing rules continue to be publicly unavailable and the detailed anticorruption guidelines do not exist.  Regarding building policy, the information provided on the Council’s website does not include details about the cost incurred in relation to the Council’s buildings, and that is unacceptable. We know, of course, that there is a critical exchange of information on buildings policy between the building departments of Parliament and the Council, but the exchange should definitely become regular and detailed information should be given to Parliament in the Council’s Annual Financial Report. Here, I would like to recall once more that we need progress reports on building projects with a breakdown of the costs incurred to date, together with information on the costs related to the delayed completion of the Europa building.

name: Hannu TAKKULA
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, to my great regret we are again forced to refuse regarding the granting of discharge to the European Council and the Council because of the lack of information and communication. This ongoing disagreement about the legal competence to provide the discharge is an unfortunate situation which remains unsolved. I am pleased to note that there has actually been some discussion between Parliament and the Council on the matter, but I still find it an insufficient basis for granting discharge. When it comes to discharge procedures regarding the Commission and other European institutions, we have a certain set of rules that must be followed and there shall be no exceptions or privilege for any institutions. Transparent governance when using European taxpayers’ money is a fundamental right and the current unsolved situation severely undermines this right. We should be able to guarantee that all of the European Union institutions use EU citizens’ money transparently. As for Parliament, it is currently unable to scrutinise how the Council budget is spent. The situation allows unfortunate grounds for questions on the use of the budget.  Discharge is not a voluntary procedure but an official procedure to make sure that the EU budget is used in the way it is meant to be used. I hope that the dialogue between Parliament and the Council will continue and that this issue can be solved in a way such that in the future there is a possibility to grant discharge to all European institutions.

name: Jonathan BULLOCK
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I am in the unusual position for a UKIP MEP to be in favour of this proposal; the proposal being to refuse to grant a discharge to the EU Council. Every year, the Parliament looks through the books of each of the EU institutions and agencies to approve them, and every year, these bodies comply with the process, with the exception of the Council. Why does the Council not comply? The EU Treaties may say that the Parliament only grants discharge to the Commission, but I think there is a moral obligation to comply with what is essentially a transparency process. When you look at why the Council may not want to go along with this, you see that just last week, on the day that Brexit negotiations continued, the Council put out a public tender for 4000 bottles of champagne. Well, Mr President, perhaps we in Britain could have our share of that; I think it works out at about 500 bottles by our budget contribution to celebrate Brexit. We would even settle for 148 bottles, if we divided equally between the countries. That would be enough to celebrate Brexit! But seriously, when half of Europe is in some form of crisis and with austerity biting, you are ordering four thousand bottles of champagne. This needs to be stopped; this needs to be audited, this needs to be looked at by the Parliament, and we must have this transparency over the budget and use of taxpayers’ money in this Council.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: Probably 3 900 would have been more appropriate.

name: Ingeborg GRÄSSLE
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, Mr President-in-Office of the Council! I would like to address you, Mr President-in-Office of the Council. We are pleased that you are here: Welcome. We have already debated Council discharge here and the Council Presidency was not there. I want to give you great credit for coming. I would ask you to influence the Council so that we can really finally come to a solution, because the Council is making things a little easy for itself. According to the contract, you have the obligation to propose a decision to discharge us. We ask that you do all the work and not always only half the work. We have been accusing you of refusing to work for years. You are not making a discharge proposal for the other institutions. You are not making a discharge proposal for parliament. The reciprocity that you demand in the memorandum of understanding, you had it long ago, you would use your options under the treaty and nobody could prevent you from doing so. Nobody. Besides, nobody would stop you from doing so. The proposal of the one discharge, this proposal forms a contractual status from 60 years ago. The discharge provision has never been updated and this is a failure of all the working groups that have so far handled the contract. You are actually asking us not to discharge the Commission any more if we do not want to discharge you. I mean, Commissioner, let's do that, then we'll see what's going on in this Europe! In other words, I would ask you to take part seriously. We have a mandate from the House and we are willing to do so. We know the Council's constraints, but we would also like to ask to be taken seriously. Take us seriously too. The thing about the champagne bottles I wasn't that much of a problem. I don't even want to know. There are probably few more boring households than that Council budget.But it is a fundamental question for us, and the fundamental question can only be that officials, please, are not allowed to judge parliamentarians.That is absurd.With such a proposal, no Council official in his Member State would come before his national parliament.But here such absurd demands are made, because you can do it with us.If we are ready to really seriously move forward with a solution, I am sure that we will get a solution too.Hence my appeal to you.

name: Cătălin Sorin IVAN
text: - Mr President, in the European Parliament and in the European institutions in general, we have often complained that European citizens do not know what we are doing in the European Parliament. Today I feel that it is very good that I do not know what we are doing in the European Parliament, because if they knew that we in the European Parliament have such discussions about how a European institution is in conflict with another European institution only on such a subject. minor but sensitive at the same time - the Council does not want to let us know how public money is spent, European money, the Council is against transparency - then believe me that even fewer European citizens would trust the European institutions, and more few European citizens would vote. I think we have a much more serious problem than a budget discharge. It is a matter of democracy, it is a matter of transparency, it is a matter of respecting the treaties of the European Union, which is much more serious.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, the Council and the European Council consider that it is a state within a state, that it can do whatever it wants, that it is not controlled at all, while it is a given that Articles 316, 317 and 319 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union give the European Parliament the right to grant discharge for each section of the budget. This means that it also grants discharge for the activities of the Council and the European Council. But when the Council does not come, does not discuss, does not give information, it is obvious that it is "writing in its old shoes" the rights that the European Parliament has. This year we see a slight difference: at least the Council is here. Last year it did not even come. But we want specific actions and responsibilities and at the same time we insist that we want specific information. The activities of the European Council and the Council itself cannot be exempted. At the same time, we must monitor the action of the Eurogroup, which uses the Council's facilities, uses interpretation. An institution that is not controlled by anyone, the Eurogroup, which takes decisions to the detriment of the peoples of Europe.

name: Miroslav POCHE
text: - Mr President, we are slowly getting used to the fact that the rapporteur, who will be given the task of drawing up the Council's accounts in the Committee on Budgetary Control, will eventually inform us that it will not be possible to close the accounts again due to lack of cooperation from the Council. And it amazes me every year. How is it possible that a body whose existence is so closely linked to ours is not willing to respect the fundamental competences that the European Parliament has? How would we react if any other institution behaved in this way? I welcome and strongly support the fact that last week the Conference of Presidents decided to instruct the Committee on Budgetary Control to negotiate an agreement with the Council on the form of cooperation in the preparation of the next accounts. If we are talking about an agreement, it must not be synonymous with a concession by the European Parliament in terms of the scope and depth of the information provided. The Council has a duty of transparent management of public resources, as does all other European institutions. The European Parliament must therefore insist on its demands. It is both our privilege and our duty and our responsibility to the public. I would also like the negotiations to include the Council's involvement in a transparent register.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: – Mr President, thank you for giving me this opportunity. Sorry for being late. Dear Council, here we are again. I regret to have to give the same speech pretty much year after year. I will try to be a little bit more civilised this year than I have been on some occasions. But the truth is that we have been refusing to grant the discharge to the Council for seven years in a row now, and whatever the reasons and the logic behind this, the fact of the matter remains that the taxpayers in the European Union deserve to have a transparent and open system. And they really deserve to have an end put to this farce of democracy, I have to say. So I would like to join the words of Madam Grässle, auf Deutsch, bitte, in English, please, in Finnish, olkaa niin hyviä ja katsokaa tätä asiaa kansalaisten näkökulmasta.

name: Petri SARVAMAA
text: President of the Council.- I can only promise to take this message to my colleagues in the Council.That’s the only thing I can definitely promise right now.In addition to that strange language, I wish to make it very clear and to reiterate that at this current point the Council stands behind its interpretation of Article 319.

name: Bart STAES
text: Reporter.- Madam President, very briefly.I think it was a fruitful debate.The Council has clearly seen that there is unity in this European Parliament.We want to move forward.We have a mandate.I think we are generous in what we will be offering.I hear that the Council wants to enter into dialogue.I hope that this will lead to an agreement so that my successor, who will have to deal with the discharge for the past year, will succeed in making a favorable recommendation to Parliament.I really hope that dialogue will lead to a solution to this conflict which, as Mr Sarvamaa said, should not remain a "farce".

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The debate was closed.The vote will take place on Wednesday, 25 October 2017.

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: The next item is the debate on the Commission and Council statements on the protection of journalists and the protection of media freedom in Malta: the case of Daphne Caruana Galizia (2017/2896 (RSP)).

name: Ioan Mircea PAŞCU
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, today’s debate has been triggered by the horrific assassination of Ms Daphne Caruana Galizia.  First of all, I wish to express my sincere condolences to her family, friends and colleagues. The circumstances of the death of Ms Caruana Galizia have rendered us speechless, but this debate shows that we shall not remain silent. We strongly condemn this barbaric crime. The perpetrators must be brought to justice. The mission of journalists requires personal devotion and courage, and those who have these qualities deserve our deepest respect and protection.  Media freedom is an indispensable pillar of our democratic societies. Journalists are the guardians of properly functioning democracies. Where there is no freedom of speech and people have to fear for their life every time they criticise something, there is no democracy. For this reason freedom of expression, media freedom and pluralism are guaranteed in the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. They are among the core basic democratic values on which the European Union is founded. These freedoms are an obligation for our governments. It is an absolute priority for all democracies to protect journalists also from financial or political pressure. The importance of media pluralism as a prerequisite of the rule of law and democracy was underlined by the Council in its annual rule of law dialogue last week.  Let me be clear: attacks on media representatives to silence their voices are unacceptable everywhere in the world. If they occur, we have to act immediately: condemn the crime, find and punish the perpetrators and re-establish the confidence of our citizens in the functioning of our democratic institutions. I am convinced that we are all aware of the responsibility of our governments for the protection of journalists and the defence of media freedom.  We commend and trust in the Maltese authorities in ensuring that justice is delivered. As the Presidency, we would like to join other Member States, which offered help to the Maltese authorities in the investigation of this appalling crime. We owe this to the memory of Ms Caruana Galizia and to all journalists serving our societies.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, a renowned and brave journalist died in the most brutal and shocking manner in Malta last week.  A wife, a mother, a mother-in-law, a friend, a neighbour, a colleague. Daphne Caruana Galizia appears to have been killed because someone wanted to stop her from reporting. And it happened right here, in the European Union!  Let me first express my deepest condolences to her family and loved ones. Your loss, I cannot imagine. I did not have the privilege to know Daphne personally but a few things stand out – her courage and doggedness in the pursuit of the truth, her readiness to ask the questions that really matter about politicians of all colours.  The very heart of democracy is that those who the people choose to lead them are also accountable to them. Journalists such as Daphne represent us all when they ask the difficult questions and when they keep digging even if it becomes uncomfortable and dangerous to find the truth.  When I attended the spontaneous vigil last Wednesday in Brussels, when I stood here in silence with you earlier today in the presence of Daphne’s family, to whom I have had the chance to express my condolences in person this morning, my deep concerns about what this tragic event represents in terms of our democratic values were dwarfed by the immediate human tragedy: the three sons and a daughter-in-law suddenly and violently losing a mother, and a husband prematurely and painfully losing his beloved wife.  At the European Council last week and again this morning, President Tajani made a strong call for a detailed in-depth international investigation. On behalf of President Juncker and all my colleagues in the College, I can say that the Commission very much agrees that ensuring an independent and thorough investigation of the facts and bringing those responsible to justice must be the top priority for now.  Prime Minister Muscat gave such an assurance to his fellow leaders on Thursday and the eyes of Europe and the world are now on Malta to ensure this is the case. I welcome the fact that the Maltese authorities have engaged with their counterparts in Europe and beyond, including forensics experts from the Netherlands, the United Kingdom and the United States, and wherever useful, Europol and Eurojust are there to help.  We know that good journalism can be a dangerous job. Last year 72 journalists were killed worldwide and more than 50 others have died so far this year. But the targeted and brutal manner of Daphne’s killing and the fact that it happened here on the soil of one of our Member States profoundly shocks. Even here in Europe, too many journalists are threatened every day. The campaign ‘Mapping Media Freedom’ has already reported more than 300 alerts of threats to journalistic freedom in the EU since the beginning of the year and more than 3 000 since the beginning of the project.  I pay tribute to all those who have stood up and asked the tough questions. Since – and I say this as a politician and democrat among politicians and democrats – since professional journalism is a necessary job because it ensures that all of us who are entrusted with certain responsibilities are also scrutinised for how we exercise them, that perhaps matters now more than ever, as we find ourselves in an era where anyone can publish their views online, where facts and fiction are sometimes mixed, where false information is repeated ever louder.  I have said before in this House that everyone is entitled to her or his own opinions, but no one is entitled to their own facts. That is what journalists do. They are the human face of stubborn facts. That is their job, their mission. A free media is the watchdog in our democracies.  Healthy democracy requires a free and pluralistic media, free from state intervention and from undue political or commercial pressures. Ed Murrow put it well when he said that every healthy democracy needs a good dose of itching pills, and as President Juncker said last week, the right of a journalist to investigate, to ask uncomfortable questions and report effectively is at the heart of our values and needs to be guaranteed at all times.  Under the Treaties, the Commission has limited powers in this area. We can, however, encourage and guide, which is why last year we chose to devote our annual colloquium on fundamental rights to the theme of media pluralism and democracy. Three quarters of respondents to the public consultation covering all our Member States in preparation for the colloquium said that they were aware of or have experienced limitations on journalistic activities by state measures, and more than two thirds of respondents said they have experienced or are aware of censorship and self-censorship. Such findings are very worrying. If journalists have to fear for their lives just for doing their job, they cannot operate with a level of freedom and independence that is essential for the media in any democracy, in any rule-of-law based society.  Media freedom and pluralism are fundamental rights enshrined in Article 11 of the EU Charter on Fundamental Rights and constitute essential foundations of our democratic societies. It is the duty of the Maltese state to investigate and prosecute this case in accordance with its constitution, its legal order and international human rights obligations. The Maltese authorities and institutions must deliver on their commitment to do everything in their power to ensure that the perpetrators will be brought to justice.  Malta needs to show to Europe and the world that its rules and regulations are healthy and robust. This is why it is important that the Maltese Government has indicated that the investigation and prosecution should be allowed to run their full course, that if problems of a more general or systemic nature are brought to light, they should also be addressed, regardless of the consequences.  Today’s debate proves once more that the eyes of Europe stay firmly fixed on Malta, because the murder of a brave journalist such as Daphne is a direct concern for us all. We will, it is our duty, continue to stand up for our shared values. Why? Well, for the sake of Daphne, her loved ones and everything she stood for, for the sake of the European Union and everything it stands for.

name: Esteban GONZÁLEZ PONS
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr. president. This morning I met with the widower and the children of Daphne Caruana and then I cried. Hopefully all the groups had a chance to listen to you. Daphne Caruana dedicated her entire life to journalism; she raised her voice where others don't dare; she faced governments, politicians, companies and mafias, no matter how many or how powerful. As one of her children said, she stood between the rule of law and those who wanted to violate it, and that is why they murdered her. She died with more than 42 open court cases and without even having access to her bank accounts. Harassed. Before murdering her, they made life impossible for her and her family; somehow, they started killing her when she was still alive. They have not killed rulers, they have not killed judges, they have not killed policemen. They have killed a journalist. And when in a state the rulers, the judges and the police live happily while journalists are killed, it means that democracy is failing. The disappearance of Daphne Caruana is much more than the tragic murder of an uncomfortable journalist. It is a message. It is a call to silence. She is a direct threat to all those who, like her, exercise journalism with freedom and independence. It is an attack on freedom of expression. There can be no true democracy without a free press. We fail Daphne. She failed the European Union, of which she did not serve as a citizen on European soil. Nothing and no one protected her sufficiently, especially the authorities and the Government of Malta, who should have guaranteed her safety and that of her family. They did not. Sadly, Caruana's murder is not an isolated case, as are not the letters that some media outlets in Malta are receiving threatening millionaire litigation for damages. That is also a compulsion. Murders in Mexico, murders in India, mass arrests of journalists in Turkey; even in the The United States president allows himself to question the patriotism of some journalists.
