Our problem is that Malta is at the heart of the European Union and it shows us that we, we, are not free from this global threat against journalism. The murder of Daphne Caruana is a shadow that falls on our conscience as proud Europeans. The European Union can therefore no longer be silent about what is happening in Malta. Our silence is the victory of Daphne's assassins and the defeat of democratic institutions. That is why my group has asked the European Commission to ensure a fully independent judicial investigation. We want to know who did it. We want to know why she did it. And we want to know who protects him from her and that they all go to jail. And I invite the Commission to urgently investigate the situation of the rule of law in Malta. As Daphne reminded us in her last words, the situation is desperate. All of us, the Commission as well, must ask ourselves whether we did enough. Ladies and gentlemen, just yesterday another journalist was stabbed at a radio station in Russia. Russian journalists tell the world: nobody defends us. Well, we did not defend Daphne, and for that reason to her children and with my heart in hand in this room, I apologize and say: I wish I could assure you that it will never happen again, that your mother will be the last! But I can not. We have to fight for freedom of expression every minute, every hour, every day and in every country in the world, knowing that the fight will be to the death and that it will never end. Without good journalism or good journalists, no democracy is complete. That is why European democracy will always lack Daphne. Her fight never ends.

name: Gianni PITTELLA
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the killing of Daphne Caruana Galizia is an attack on European democracy. Frans Timmermans said well: killing a journalist for her work means attacking freedom of information and thought, which is a fundamental value of the European Union. Whoever ordered and carried out this attack is an enemy of Europe. We need to catch those responsible as soon as possible: Europe and the Member States make the best investigators available to Maltese investigators, the Prime Minister and the Maltese Government have asked. But in addition to judicial truths, there is a political response that challenges us all. When, a week ago, I saw the scenes of the attack I immediately thought of my country, of Italy, of the mafia bombs that killed judges Falcone and Borsellino. Those bombs marked a turning point in the fight against the Sicilian mafia and the Italian state won its battle because it proved ruthless and united. Today we need to be united among us. All those who love freedom of thought and democracy join in this struggle. And it is not true that the European Parliament has been silent on these issues. The European Parliament set up a committee of inquiry on Panama leaks a year ago, which met Daphne in the course of its work. Last week the first conclusions of the investigation were approved: battle against the international mafia, fight against money laundering to track down illegal flows (we are united on this!), Black list of tax havens and sanctions for those who are complicit in these. These are the things that the special commission has asked for and that Europe must do now. We must better defend the freedom of those who provide information, I share this imperative and this concern. Journalism, especially investigative journalism, will always be uncomfortable, it must be uncomfortable, because it is counterpower and without that counterpower democracy and the rule of law are weaker.We need powers and counterpowers, this is democracy.The conditions must therefore be created for journalists to work throughout Europe and in the world - and in the world!Russian journalists, too, everywhere - in safe conditions, so that their sources are protected.Just this morning we voted on a resolution in which we ask the European Commission to present a proposal on whistleblowers, on the protection of whistleblowers, who are an important source for finding the culprits.Let's go ahead on this path, and I too want to greet and give the thoughts of my political group, and also my personal one, to Daphne's family members and reiterate that it is a moral duty, rather than a political one, to make sure that this so painful lossand so brutal in its development is not in vain.

name: Monica MACOVEI
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. - A WikiLeaks in one woman: Daphne Caruana Galicia. He died in the anti-corruption crusade in Malta. Daphne wrote in April that the wife of the Maltese prime minister has an account opened in Panama in which she also deposited the money received as a bribe from Azerbaijan. One week ago, Daphne was blown up by car. I do not understand why we are asking the Maltese government to investigate. Who to investigate? Prime Minister? When was Daphne killed for writing against the prime minister? Let's not joke anymore. First of all, this prime minister and the whole government must resign. At her funeral, the son said: “My mother was killed because she chose to stand between the rule of law and those who were trying to attack her. She also became a target because she was the only one who did that. ” This is what happens when state institutions are incapable. The last person left standing is often a journalist. Which makes him the first person to die. The mafia never stopped. We have governments that today are organized crime groups and send the message: whoever talks and writes about our hidden money, our corruption and fraud, will suffer. Empires of corruption were built over time, protected by iron walls. The only solution is to start the operation now with clean hands, led by governments that want and must ally with free journalists and honest people and defeat governments that do not want.

name: Sophia IN 'T VELD
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, first of all, I would like to pay tribute to Daphne Caruana Galizia. Her name has been mentioned several times here today and I would also like to give my condolences to her family. I met her sons this afternoon and I was really impressed by their wisdom and their strength, but if you read about her life, that’s not surprising. She was an exceptionally courageous and strong woman, and I think that we have to show the same courage, because I think we are all united today in shock, in grief and in our wish to uphold freedom of the media, freedom of expression. But we also have to act. The first one to act, obviously, is the Maltese Government: they will have to investigate her murder and make sure that the murderers do not get away with impunity. But also those who actually wanted her gone should not get away with impunity, because this was not just a murder tackling an individual person – she was exposing corruption and crime. We should investigate that as well, because this is not a mere Maltese problem: this is a European problem. We are talking about international networks of corruption and crime, money—laundering, hiding criminal money, and so on. So I think there is a task here for the European Union, and I think the European People’s Party just suggested that we investigate the rule of law in Malta – that was a kind of general statement, but I do think it is very important that we get clarifications from the Maltese Government about the allegations of corruptions which she was investigating. We have to continue that investigation, and I would suggest that first of all – in the very short term, within the next couple of weeks – that we organise an ECON-LIBE hearing and invite experts on the Maltese situation; on the investigations into corruption and crime. But I think we should also look into ways of continuing that and deepening that investigation and make sure that we eradicate corruption and crime and money laundering from the European Union, and Malta is part of the European Union. Finally, Commissioner, you said that the European Commission doesn’t have the competences to actually intervene, and I don’t think (as Mr González Pons said) that it is for the European Commission to conduct a police investigation into a murder. But you can investigate allegations of corruption, and you can indeed investigate allegations that, for example, the judiciary or the police is not independent, because if one Member State – whether it is Malta, Poland, Hungary, France or indeed the Netherlands or Romania – does not uphold the European standards when it comes to the rule of law, that means that there is no rule of law in the European Union. We have an area of freedom, security and justice, so if one Member State doesn’t function in this respect, then the whole system fails. So it is in everybody’s interests that we investigate. Is that painful? Yes it is. But this is a political union: we all have to make sure that these problems are eradicated, and I think we owe it to Daphne. We cannot just make statements here; we have to be courageous and go against those who actually do not wish us to investigate.  This has to be done, and I hope that we are going to find agreement amongst all the political groups for the exact instruments – the appropriate instruments – in honour of Daphne.

name: Miguel URBÁN CRESPO
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, first of all, how could it be otherwise: from our Group we want to show our full solidarity and our fraternal embrace with Daphne's relatives and with her loved ones; but also give that hug to all the Daphnes in the world who are still persecuted. Ladies and gentlemen, we must remember that tax havens within the European Union are a black thread that links tax fraud with networks of crime, corruption and persecution of journalists and leakers. The case of Daphne Caruana is a dramatic example of the complicity between the interests of criminal networks and oligarchies. It should be remembered that commissions of inquiry, such as the one on the Panama papers, are possible thanks to the work of journalists like Daphne, who revealed the Panama accounts of several Maltese ministers. Her investigation threatened many interests that are often even defended from this chamber, such as fiscal opacity, bank secrecy or the free movement of capital. We understand that it is essential to put the rights of whistleblowers above the private interest of companies. Today we have approved a report demanding legislation that protects and covers all the activities of whistleblowers and journalists. Also, in the report to be presented by the PANA Commission, we have requested that an agency and specific communication channels be established to protect those who risk their lives to bring to light information that benefits society as a whole. Let us hope that all groups in this House will vote in favor of these measures. And we also want to send a clear message to the Commission: to implement as soon as possible what we have approved in this House, ensuring the integrity and rights of whistleblowers and journalists, thus avoiding becoming complicit in new cases such as Daphne by omission.

name: Sven GIEGOLD
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, 16 October 2017 has been the saddest day for me personally as a Member of this Parliament. First of all, our sincere condolences go to the family of Daphne, whom I got to know as one of the most courageous people in the fight for justice and the rule of law in Europe. The way in which Daphne was killed tells us a lot about the unjust and criminal system which she was fighting. Daphne was killed in the open, there was no hiding. Her murderers did not even try to make the attack appear to be an accident. On the contrary, this was a brutal demonstration of power by those who consider themselves above the law. It is very clear why the murderers did not place a bomb under the car of the police chief or the attorney general. It was Daphne who shed light on a system of money-laundering and corruption in Malta, and not these authorities. Let me just name a small selection of illegal, or at least illegitimate, activities that Daphne has made public: letterbox companies owned by members of the government; the sale of passports to so-called investors; tax avoidance for multinational companies; online gambling based on weak supervision and hyper-low taxation. All these cases have one thing in common. Malta has sold its sovereignty to dirty money. Malta has replaced the rule of law with a culture of impunity for the powerful, and fiddling between political and financial elites. This is Europe, not Russia. Europe must act when fundamental rights are at stake. It is now up to us to finish Daphne’s fight, and therefore we would like to suggest five concrete steps. First, an international investigator has to be appointed who will be fully involved in the ongoing investigations on money-laundering and corruption in Malta. Second, Malta should take that opportunity finally to join the European Prosecutor. Third, we demand a serious investigation by the European Commission on the rule of law in Malta and systematic Treaty infringement procedures to enforce anti-money laundering law everywhere in Europe. Fourth, we also support Daphne’s family in their demand for the Muscat government to step down because of its failure in enforcing the rule of law in Malta. And lastly, we are proposing the introduction of a European Galizia prize here in this House for investigative journalists, modelled on the Sakharov Prize. The murderous attack on Daphne was an attack on European values, our fundamental principles. Let us not forget that people who suffer from corruption in their countries put their hopes in Europe. Let us not disappoint these citizens. Let us not disappoint Daphne and her family. Let us act together to defend our fundamental principles of democracy, the rule of law and justice.

name: Ignazio CORRAO
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, President Pittella said well when he pointed out that the explosion of a bomb sends us back to dark times for our country: the killings of judges, the activities of the mafia. But unfortunately I must remember that the instigators of those murders and massacres, the real instigators, we in Italy still do not know them, and indeed perhaps those instigators still sit in Parliament or are in positions of power. This is something we must remember when we talk about Daphne Caruana Galizia, who came to this Parliament. When she came to us she was already threatened, she was isolated, she was killed in life, as some have rightly said. She was left alone, she was killed in the most barbaric way, giving a signal to anyone, saying "beware, if you touch these naked nerves something like this happens to you", because this was done to her: she came here, she told so many things , he also accused Maltese politicians, he did it in his life, he touched naked nerves, he touched sensitive things and we must be careful now, we must give a different answer than what has been given so far. Because if it is true that President Tajani today made a commitment in front of his family, saying that there will be an investigation and that executors and principals will be found, we must all work to ensure that this really happens, otherwise this Parliament will look ridiculous, so let's remember it. this thing.

name: Mario BORGHEZIO
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we cannot fail to express, and we express it as a group, a great respect also for the ceremony, for the heartfelt and noble words with which the President of this Parliament introduced this day this morning. On the other hand, the political evaluation that, in my opinion, must be made with severity about the situation that made this murder possible, which reminds us Italians of many things, is different - I would also like to recall the precedent of another great journalist, the journalist De Mauro. , who was truly one of the first victims of this endless massacre of journalists, the heroes of investigative journalism. The problem is very clear and simple to explain. This Commission has the credentials to commit itself, as we have heard, since it is not doing and has not done anything serious to empty those cesspools, housed in tax havens, of hidden, parallel finance, through which money is conveyed. , the billions of drug trafficking, oil, smuggling and all that this courageous journalist had denounced? You don't have what it takes!

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, the tragic assassination of Daphne Caruana Galizia has brought to the surface a serious problem for centuries, which unfortunately still exists today: freedom of the press. Authorities have always tried to control journalists. Usually they did this by bribing them and, those who did not succumb to blackmail, threatened them, used violence against them and, many times, killed them. Nowadays, the attempt to abolish press freedom includes other methods, such as arrests and convictions of journalists and publishers, closure of newspapers, and banning the use of social media, as President Erdogan is doing in Turkey. Even in Greece, only a few brave journalists step in to the MPs, MEPs and executives of our party, Golden Dawn, the country's third political force, because they are afraid that their employers will fire them. All states must realize that journalists have a function and must protect them in order to carry out their work unhindered, thus guaranteeing freedom of the press, which is a basic principle of democracy. I wish Daphne's blood to be the last to be shed on the altar of free press internationally. May her memory be eternal.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I have listened carefully to the contributions from the Members of this Parliament. Today, for the Commission, is about honouring the memory of Daphne, it is about sharing our grief in this Parliament. But I fully recognise that the only way we can really honour her memory is by following up on the issues that underlie the assassination.  This starts, of course, with a full investigation of what has happened and bringing to justice those who are responsible. As I said in my contribution, if in this investigation, and in the course of this analysis, things are brought to light that are of a more structural nature or that warrant other actions, the Commission will certainly not hesitate to assume its responsibility, where we have a responsibility. Let me also add that in our Work Programme for next year we have insisted on the need, jointly with the European Parliament, to come up with a better protection of whistle-blowers. This is also an important step we need to take.  My colleague Věra Jourová promised to the Special Committee of Inquiry on Money Laundering, Tax Avoidance and Tax Evasion (PANA) in July that we would also step up our efforts to implement the decisions we have taken on fighting money laundering. I can, for instance, give as an example that we have now – let me just check the numbers – we have opened infringement cases that concern 14 Member States which have not notified laws transposing the 4th Directive and two Member States whose laws clearly show that these were not sufficient to transpose the Directive. We will continue this work in close contact also with this Parliament. We are always prepared to engage directly with the Maltese authorities at a political level to make sure that they implement the rules that we agreed at European level.  Let me end on the following. The effect of such a public display of barbarism – which this assassination was – the intended effect, of course, is to intimidate, to make sure that no investigation is carried out any more, that nothing is pursued, that others will be self-censoring their own investigation. I think this is the biggest challenge we face: that we are not intimidated by what was done; that we as Europeans collectively accept the responsibility in the EU to make sure that we are not intimidated; that institutions can function independently; that perpetrators are brought to justice; that if this is linked to organised crime or to corruption, that this is pursued. And this Commission will leave no stone unturned in that area to make sure that this atrocious, barbarous assassination does not lead to the conclusion which is clearly wanted by those who perpetrated it, namely that we don’t dare ask questions or we don’t dare investigate. This will not happen. This is a promise I make on behalf of the Commission, and this is how we will pursue the issue in close cooperation also with the Maltese authorities and other bodies that could be implicated in the investigation.

name: Frans TIMMERMANS
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, just as First Vice-President Timmermans has just done on behalf of the Commission, on behalf of the Council I can assure you that we will follow the developments closely, and I will pay particular attention to the views expressed here today during this debate.  The Estonian Presidency, and the Council as a whole, attach great importance to the protection of journalists and the defence of media freedom. We are all shocked by the appalling circumstances of the death of Ms Daphne Caruana Galizia. Words of condemnation are never sufficient. We are confident that the Maltese law enforcement authorities are capable of upholding the rule of law in the face of this atrocious murder and will conduct the investigation, with international assistance if needed.

name: David Maria SASSOLI

name: Cristian-Silviu BUŞOI
text: in writing. – When journalists are afraid, democracy is in danger, the ‘rule of people’ becoming the ‘rule of crooks’. Daphne Caruana Galizia is the 10th journalist to die in 2017, mainstreaming the terror for those who fight the most in the name of transparency. The real justice that can be brought to these reporters is to show that we really need their work and manifest our democratic values by blaming the demonisation of journalists and fully support these professionals in executing their democratic duty without any fear or intimidation.

name: Eugen FREUND
text: written. - Freedom of expression and freedom of the press are among the most important foundations of a democracy. The gruesome murder of the investigative journalist and blogger Daphne Caruana Galizia in Malta, who was involved in the processing of the Panama Papers, made it clear to us last week that freedom of expression can also be fatal. This sad event shows once again that journalists, bloggers and all those who have the courage to uncover hidden machinations in the public interest deserve special protection through appropriate laws. As a former journalist, it is particularly important to me to point this out. In the European Parliament, we Social Democrats voted for greater protection for whistleblowers. Whistleblowers help to expose corruption and shady business. It must not happen that they are often prosecuted for the fact that their job, their freedom and sometimes even their life are at stake. This makes the attitude of the ÖVP all the more incomprehensible, which on the one hand shows concern at the memorial event here in Parliament, but on the other hand does not vote for the protection of whistleblowers. Let’s set an example together for freedom of expression and let’s ensure that the protection of journalists and all those who expose abuses is strengthened in the EU!

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: in writing. - The assassination of Daphne Caruana Galizia is both a sad and deterrent expression of what power can do to silence the truth. Even the slightest restriction on independent journalism is a serious violation of citizens' right to free information. And where a journalist may pay with his life to expose corruption and abuses of power, the foundations of democracy are shaken. The aggression of power against free and independent communication can never go unanswered! The Maltese government must resign after being unable to clear corruption allegations. And the European Commission must launch an immediate and comprehensive investigation to bring the perpetrators to justice! The systematic curtailment of press freedom has already begun in some EU Member States and has been going on for years. In these countries, eradicating the independence and diversity of the media is in the interest of power. It must not escalate so that those who try to reveal the truth to the public will not feel safe! Urgent and effective action is needed so that intimidation of journalists can nowhere become a means of hiding the truth in the hands of the authorities. As transparency and independent, free media are core values, the preservation of which is now, unfortunately, constantly being reaffirmed, the Green Group is proposing an award labeled Daphnne Caruana Galizia for recognizing and protecting the work of fact-finding journalists.

name: Karol KARSKI
text: in writing. - I unite in sorrow with the late family Daphne Caruana Galizii, who devoted her life to searching for the truth, tracking down corruption at the highest levels of government, disclosed data from the so-called Panama documents that describe the process of allocating funds in various tax havens. I demand a thorough investigation and bringing the guilty parties to court. Whistleblowers are one of the most important ways to detect illegal activities, in particular fraud and corruption in the private and public sectors, organized crime, tax fraud and tax avoidance. Whistleblowing is linked to freedom of the press and is essential to bring to light illegal activities or activities that harm the public interest. It should be emphasized that the activities of investigative journalists such as the late Daphne Caruana Galizia serves to strengthen democracy, transparency in politics and economy, and public information, and should be considered essential actors in preventing illegal activities.

name: József NAGY
text: in writing.- The European Parliament could not leave without saying the bombing of the famous Maltese investigative journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia.Because how can we want Putin or Erdogan not to persecute the media if we tolerate the possibility of killing a journalist in the EU because he has come too close to government corruption cases?The European Union sees itself as a model for freedom of the press, to which intimidation of journalists is a huge threat.Malta must respond to this terrible act by tracing and prosecuting the perpetrators in order to regain the trust of journalists and the people.

name: Urmas PAET
text: in writing.- The murder of Daphne Caruana Galizia is shocking.Freedom of the media must be guaranteed in the territory of each EU Member State, without any journalist having to fear for their own safety.Daphne Caruana Galiziale's work became fatal, proving once again that the investigative press could unfortunately also be a dangerous job on EU soil.The Maltese Government must take the matter seriously and responsibly.In 2017, 42 journalists worldwide died, two of them in EU Member States.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: in writing.- In today's fast-changing world, the operation of the media has also changed fundamentally, but one thing has remained constant: the perpetrators of lawlessness fear the public, the public's judgment.What happened in Malta with Daphne Caruana Galizia shows that journalists are still at risk, even in the European Union.The scandal surrounding the Panama Papers marks a new era of transparency in which another world can emerge, where financial resources unimaginable to the vast majority of citizens migrate among the members of the elite.By today’s means, these secrets will no longer remain secrets, and the tragic death of Daphne Caruana Galizia will only further draw attention to the lawlessness of the offshore world and the fact that democratically elected European governments have a responsibility to their citizens in this regard as well.

name: Indrek TARAND
text: in writing. – It is tragic that in this day and age we still need to condemn the killing of journalists, and reaffirm our commitment to the freedom of the press. We no longer live in the medieval ages where people with power simply killed their opponents or people they did not like. These kinds of actions have no place in our societies, not in Russia, nor in the European Union. Media freedom is essential for a democracy to function; corruption will flourish if there is no one to cast a light on it.  This barbaric crime was committed to silence a particular journalist, but we must not forget the wider implications of this murder: the chilling effect on other journalists. Journalists should not have to fear for their lives, otherwise the perpetrators and oppressors get an even bigger victory, and democracy with the rest of society suffers. This is why the investigation has to be conducted with utmost seriousness, in order to bring the perpetrators to justice as soon as possible.

name: Jarosław WAŁĘSA
text: in writing. - The murder of Maltese investigative journalist Daphne Caruana Galizia is a scandal and an attack on fundamental European values, such as freedom of speech and the rule of law. The journalist's right to investigate, ask uncomfortable questions and raise awareness is at the heart of our values ​​and must always be guaranteed. Freedom of speech is the right to express our own views and to show our understanding of reality. Without independent and reliable journalism, no democracy is complete. If journalists cannot provide information for fear of endangering their lives, then we are confronted with a significant restriction of press freedom and a dramatic regression of democracy. A healthy democracy requires a free and pluralist media, free from state intervention, political and commercial pressure. It is very disturbing that such a scandalous act of violence has arisen in Europe. The Maltese authorities now need to prove that such crimes cannot be committed with impunity. Therefore, it is extremely important to conduct an international investigation of this heinous crime quickly and thoroughly. What matters now is that justice is done. We must stop the attack on freedom of speech and defend journalists around the world. Journalists should feel that they can exercise their function of commenting on public affairs, informing the public, imparting information and ideas free from threats, harassment or intimidation, and not prosecuted for expressing views that do not constitute incitement to violence.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the report by Marita Ulvskog, on behalf of the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs, on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Directive 2004/37 / EC on the protection of workers againstrisks deriving from exposure to carcinogens or mutagens at work (COM (2016) 0248 - C8-0181 / 2016 - 2016/0130 (COD)) (A8-0064 / 2017).

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: rapporteur. - Mr President! Tomorrow we will vote in favor of much stronger health and safety legislation in the EU. It is not just any legislation, but one that is about protecting workers, millions of workers in Europe, from carcinogens and mutagens. We have been waiting ten years for this. The previous Commission did not get much done, unfortunately. Fortunately, the current Commission has acted differently. We in Parliament have therefore welcomed the Commission's proposal, and in our committee work we have done everything we can to make the proposal even stronger. The facts are as follows: More than half of all work-related deaths are linked to cancer. Cancer is the single heaviest and most extensive cause of work-related death. So we can not have it. Not in a modern society that values ​​human dignity. We must not accept competing with poor conditions, with dangerous work environments; it can never be a means of competition for the EU. We must compete with being absolutely skilled and best at what we do, not with people dying from their jobs. In addition to the enormous personal cost, the estimated cost to Member States is € 334 billion annually. So that's what the cancer costs. It is a senseless loss, not only in human life but also in social costs. Tomorrow, we will vote on thirteen new limit values ​​for carcinogens and mutagenic substances that exist in the workplace. Eleven new subjects and two are being revised. These are substances that are found in a wide range of industries and in a wide range of workplaces, including the construction industry, the wood industry, the paper industry, in the production of everything from solvents, paper, furniture, toys, cars, aircraft. Hexavalent chromium, quartz dust and hard wood dust are some of the most important substances that are now regulated, given how many workers are exposed to precisely these limit values. Compared to the Commission's original proposal, which was already a big one improvement, Parliament succeeded in calling for further improvements in the negotiations. That, Mr President, we can be proud of. Throughout the process, we have emphasized the importance of starting from the precautionary principle. We must put the health and safety of workers first. The Commission proposed thirteen new limit values, which in themselves will save more than 100,000 people over the age of 50. This is a figure that does not even take into account the improved health checks or the limit values ​​that we have achieved in the negotiations. The health checks in the directive have now caught up with the asbestos directive. Thanks to Parliament, workers will be entitled to health checks even after leaving the workplace to which they have been exposed. The agreement with the council also includes stricter limit values ​​for hexavalent chromium and hard wood dust in the proposal. These are substances that cause such serious cancers as lymphosarcoma and lung cancer. We have also agreed that in future the Commission will have to review the legislation to evaluate whether the directive should be broadened to include substances that interfere with reproduction, ie substances that can harm the fertility of both men and women and unborn children. It is my and the committee's view that these substances are so serious that they should be covered by the most stringent wording of the directive. The Commission will return to this, hopefully before the end of its term. I would like to emphasize the good cooperation that has been the basis for us now being able to adopt the revision of this directive. The proposal we have before us is the result of consultation with the social parties and researchers. And I would like to thank the Commission, the Council, the social partners, the researchers who contributed throughout the process and, of course, I would also like to thank the shadow rapporteurs in my own committee, in particular Claude Rolin from the PPE Group who is now taking over as rapporteur for the second revision. this legislation. It is we can not always work together in this House - and we should not always have to do that - but we have.I think we have done it in a really good way, provided that this legislation goes all the way.Symbolically, I think it is important to get together and gather when you have a big and important task ahead of you, and we have done that.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, the investment of this Commission in a more social Europe has many facets. There is the principle of equal pay for equal work at the same place, which has yesterday been embraced by a large majority from East and West in the Council, but this Commission has also reinvigorated the promotion of workers’ health and safety. The protection of workers’ health and safety at work has therefore also been included as one of the principles of the European Pillar of Social Rights which was also embraced yesterday by the Council, to be proclaimed in November by the three institutions The fight against occupational cancer is also a matter of priority for me personally. Cancer kills more workers than any other work-related disease and causes many families enormous suffering. I am pleased that the Council and the European Parliament have reached a timely compromise on our first proposal to update the Directive on the protection of workers from the risks related to exposure to carcinogens and mutagens at work. This agreement between the co-legislators confirms the strong political commitment by all the European institutions to fight against work-related cancer. It should also pave the way for the second and third batches with a view to continue enhancing the protection of workers.  I would like to thank once again the rapporteur Ms Ulvskog for her commitment during the interinstitutional negotiations. This indeed enabled us to reach agreement on this file at first reading. It is only fair to say that the negotiations were not easy. For Parliament, one of the key points in the discussions was to include reprotoxic substances in the scope of this directive. In the end, a fair compromise was reached with the Council. The deal was a review clause which says that ‘not later than the first quarter of 2019 the Commission shall assess the opportunity of amending the scope of this directive to include reprotoxic substances’.  I can assure you that the Commission will deliver on this clause. This, however, as you all know requires comprehensive analytical work. Another difficult element in the negotiation was the exposure limit values to Chromium VI, respirable crystalline [silica] and hardwood and softwood dusts. In the end, an agreement was reached in line with the results of the scientific research and the discussions we had with the social partners. Thank you for all your work; I think we can be happy about the results and we will continue to cooperate further.

name: Kostas CHRYSOGONOS
text: Draftsman for the opinion of the Committee on Legal Affairs. - Mr President, the report we are discussing today is one of the biggest risks for millions of workers worldwide. The existence of carcinogens in the workplace. Cancer is the leading cause of work-related deaths and around 20 million workers in the European Union are exposed to carcinogens. The proposed measures aim to improve the protection of workers' health by reducing exposure to chemical agents, and that is why we must support them. However, I believe that there is a need to further expand the protective framework in order to include additional factors that threaten human health and fertility. There is also a need to reduce the limit values ​​of agents already provided, such as hardwood and softwood dust, inhalable silica powder and chromium compounds. Health must always be a priority.

name: Claude ROLIN
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - Mr President, tomorrow we will indeed vote on the revision of the directive on carcinogens and mutagens. It will be an important step. Not so much because it is a priority for the Commission, but above all because every year between 100,000 and 150,000 workers are diagnosed with occupational cancer. We cannot accept that workers destroy their health or lose their life trying to gain it. First of all, allow me to warmly thank the Commission, and in particular the Commissioner, Marianne Thyssen. While new substances have emerged, we had to wait ten years before this directive was subject to review. With its proposal, the Commission puts an end to this inaction. The institutional agreement which will be put to the vote tomorrow combines both ambition and pragmatism. Ambition, because it sets strict standards for occupational exposure. Pragmatism, because it provides for transitional periods allowing companies to adapt and to comply with the new rules. I would indeed have liked reprotoxic substances to be directly covered by this directive. This was not possible, but I am nevertheless pleased that the Commission and the Council have taken note of this call from Parliament and are taking action on it in the coming months. Finally, I would like to emphasize two elements. At the start of the year, the Commission tabled a second proposal to revise this directive. I hope that the Commission does not stop there. This directive must be reviewed regularly, in the light of scientific and technological developments, in order to advance and improve the protection of workers. In any case, and in the same philosophy as that adopted by the rapporteur on this first package of measures, we will continue with this quality of collaboration with you, Commissioner.I also salute the social partners who, in a preventive manner, negotiate sectoral agreements aimed at better protecting workers against carcinogens, in particular the NEPSI agreement which, for me, is truly an agreement that shows the way forward.In terms of health and safety at work, the key words, for me, must be "prevention and consultation".

name: Brando BENIFEI
text: on behalf of the S & amp; D Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, ten years after the last regulatory update on carcinogenic substances, we are finally taking a step forward. The work of the rapporteur, my colleague Ulvskog, is truly remarkable. With the agreement reached at the trilogue, we can say that we have added a piece to the battle against cancer, which remains the second leading cause of death at work in Europe, as Commissioner Thyssen well remembered. By dealing with many substances that affect different production sectors, we have been forced to make an effort to ensure the balance of the various interests at stake, starting obviously with the health of the workers. It will be essential to ensure that the rules are properly implemented, involving the social partners. A prime example is the Nepsi agreement, an excellence in social and sectoral dialogue. Workers' health is no joke and we will therefore continue to play our part as the European Parliament.

name: Anthea McINTYRE
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, it is very important that workers can be confident that they are working in a safe environment and that their exposure to carcinogens is very carefully controlled. So the first thing we must ensure is that exposure limits are actually measurable in the workplace.  Now the limits originally set out in the Commission proposal were the result of many years of detailed work including evaluations and fitness checks, and frankly it was easy for me, coming from the UK, to agree to the majority of the proposed limits, as we already have these lower limits in Britain. But as well as enforcing the exposure limits, Member States should be encouraging businesses to strive for the lowest levels possible, lower, in fact, than the levels set in legislation.  I am really concerned by claims that a consequence of Brexit will be a race to the bottom for workers’ rights and health and safety standards in the UK. But in fact the UK has the highest health and safety standards. We have one of the lowest fatality rates among Member States, second only to Malta, and our rates of work related ill-health, and of workers reporting that their jobs risk their health, are lower than most other Member States’.  So, to conclude, there is an established and rigorous process for setting limits to ensure that they are evidence-based, proportionate, measurable and achievable, and as policymakers we must respect this.

name: António MARINHO E PINTO
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. - Commissioner, Mr President, my dear colleagues, I welcome this report and the rapporteur on the protection of workers subject to risks related to exposure to carcinogens during their working hours, firstly, because the precautionary principle is expressly accepted. , with a meaning that, roughly speaking, can be summed up in the following proposition: in case of doubts about the effects of certain substances on people's health, workers' exposure to these substances should be avoided, even if this implies their suppression of workplaces. Secondly, because the Commission has also undertaken to undertake, by the end of the first quarter of 2019, a study on the inclusion of reprotoxic products in a future revision of the Directive. This review is justified because it is feared that reprotoxins may pose risks for reproductive health, namely for the development of the fetus, as well as during the breastfeeding period. There is, however, Commissioner, Mr President, a concern that, not being specifically raised by the content of this report, is always present in political debates involving scientific issues. I refer to the frequency with which, on the same subjects, scientific opinions are obtained in a diametrically opposite sense. How can there be scientists who certify that certain substances are not harmful to human health, while others guarantee precisely the opposite? It is necessary to denounce and combat those who exploit science to the spurious economic interests of certain companies and certain entrepreneurs. In the time of fake news, it is also necessary to combat these false reports and these lies under the cover of science. Thank you very much.

name: Patrick LE HYARIC
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Mr President, a major contradiction has been revealed here. Indeed, how can we affirm the project of a Europe that protects when more than 100,000 workers lose their lives due to occupational cancers? We do not measure enough, I believe, the suffering endured, the tears for families. The text that we are going to vote on may constitute progress since it will allow limiting the exposure of workers to eleven additional carcinogenic substances. It will also be necessary to organize real rapid implementation and establish effective monitoring of the health of workers throughout their lives. This is moreover very contradictory with what is being decided in certain countries, including mine, in France: the end of occupational medicine, the limitation of the number of labor inspectors and the abolition of the hygiene and health committees. security in companies. However, it is indeed human lives that we are talking about here. We will have to go further and faster, in particular by putting in place protection against reprotoxic substances, which would prevent miscarriages, congenital malformations and various health problems for the future children of exposed workers, and quickly protect the 19 million of workers exposed to diesel emissions. Between maximum health and maximization of profits, we must always choose the health, always the life of the workers. Let's not wait ten more years to do it!

name: Karima DELLI
text: on behalf of the Verts / ALE Group. - Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, while no one should have their health threatened in the course of their work, cancer, the second leading cause of death in Europe, is the leading cause of work-related mortality. One hundred thousand workers die from it every year, while all work-related cancers are preventable. We can, of course, be proud of this agreement, which makes it possible to protect millions of workers exposed every day to particularly toxic substances, such as chromium VI or wood dust. Proud because we offer, finally, in this revision of the 2004 directive, the possibility of prolonged monitoring, even after exposure of a worker to a substance, because cancer often begins several years ago. after the exhibition. But I call on the Commission to go further. The stated objective of extending the directive to more than 50 new substances is still far from being achieved: eleven substances in the first part in favor of which we will vote tomorrow, only five in the second proposed recently, without even the diesel vapors to which face three to four million workers each year. There is still some way to go in just 18 months before your term ends. In this report, you commit to reviewing the issue of reprotoxic drugs by 2019. Let me remind you that more than 1% of workers are exposed to them, ie between one and three million each year in Europe, because, faced with States which drag their feet, which sometimes prefer to protect industrial lobbies rather than the health of their citizens, we need the Commission, which must finally take a clear initiative. Because a Europe that protects is first and foremost a Europe that protects the health of its citizens.

name: Piernicola PEDICINI
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, we too support this Commission proposal because, in fact, it improves the protection of workers in the workplace against exposure to carcinogens and mutagens. We are therefore also in favor of Parliament's EMPL committee proposal to include in the scope of this directive substances which are harmful to the reproduction of workers. We remind you that we are talking about substances that have a threshold effect and therefore, in fact, even minimal exposures to these substances create a non-negligible risk, for those workers, of developing oncological pathologies in the course of life. Unfortunately, the figures are alarming, as you have already said: 53% of deaths from work are attributable to cancer, but there are 100 000 or even more cases occurring in the European Union. So we are facing a real health emergency, which must see us engaged with the utmost effort, without any kind of uncertainty and hesitation. Until now, unfortunately, the experience of the workers preceded scientific research: this has happened in the field of coal, it has happened in the asbestos industry but also in the handling of radioactive substances. Enough now, workers cannot be treated as if they were guinea pigs. So we invest in the search for innovative solutions, alternative solutions that can protect workers and their families from the curse of cancer.

name: Sotirios ZARIANOPOULOS
text: - Mr President, the report on the protection of workers from carcinogens at work, in addition to adding certain substances to control and changing exposure limits, is another wish list. The wishes, of course, stop where the company's profit begins. This is what sets the limits, since safeguards are limited by their economic feasibility, as their cost is called, the conditions of equal competition, etc. Carcinogenesis, the leading cause of death, is estimated at billions of euros in damage to the economy, not human lives. Capitalist barbarism at its peak. This barbarity is being experienced by workers everywhere, and in Greece, of intensified labor under the blackmail of dismissal. In the years of the Memoranda, accidents at work - in fact employer crimes - skyrocketed without counting carcinogens. The organized labor struggle for human working conditions, for the health and life of the workers will bring results if it aims at the cause of evil: the profits and the power of the capitalists.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! Safe working conditions, especially health security, are one of the key conditions for decent work and fair employment. We have it enshrined in the Treaty's Charter of Fundamental Rights, so it can also be considered a human right. And in this context, the fact of this report, which I congratulate the rapporteur very much, and I consider this revision of the directive very important, because scientific developments allow us, in principle, to conduct reviews quite frequently, which will allow us to verify the list of harmful substances, carcenogens or mutagens, and and they can allow us to verify these acceptable levels that we use. And these things are very important. I consider it particularly important in this report - and in line with previous calls from the European Parliament - this proposal to extend the scope of the directive to agents that are harmful to reproduction. Infertility, diseases of the reproductive system, lactation disorders or faulty fetal development are among the potential effects of harmful substances, and they are also one of the greatest concerns of workers in the context of exposure to harmful substances in the workplace. Both the legal protection and the related prophylaxis regarding the period of pregnancy do not cover the period before pregnancy or at a very early stage, when it is not yet formally established and reported. And for this reason, regulations that would allow for this prevention to be implemented earlier are very much expected. Today we know that there are at least a few dozen potentially harmful substances that have a harmful effect on the reproductive system, so it is very important to catalog them, to analyze them and gradually introduce them to this directive. This issue affects approximately three million workers who are exposed to these substances, but perception of the problem is much more important as infertility is a serious problem in Europe.Every fifth couple in Europe cannot have a child, so the perception of it is - as I said - completely different.The additional value of the report are those parts relating to the improvement of data collection methods and the exchange of good practices between Member States, as well as the provisions on more effective control, more frequent health checks of workers.

name: Evelyn REGNER
text: - Mister President! Thank you, Commissioner, for your commitment to the Posting of Workers Directive, but of course also to the fight against carcinogens. I would also like to express my special thanks to Marita Ulvskog for the work she has done on this important report. This week's winners are clearly the workers. Cancer - it cannot be repeated enough - is the leading cause of work-related death in Europe. Every dead is one too many. We can and must avoid these deaths. With the work that has been done, a lot has now been achieved. Binding occupational exposure limits are to be implemented for 50 carcinogenic substances instead of the current five. And of course I am also happy that we can expand the legal framework of the directive to include substances that are harmful to fertility. Two to three million workers are exposed to reprotoxic substances, and of course the legal protection has so far been more bad than right. That will change in the future.

name: Czesław HOC
text: - Mr Chairman! There is no need to convince anyone that exposure of workers to carcinogenic and mutagenic substances in the work environment is a key issue of occupational health and safety. There is nothing more valuable than the health of an employee. It is therefore fully understandable to ensure that all exposed workers are health monitored throughout their lives or that reprotoxins, which are substances that are toxic to reproduction, be included in the scope of the directive. It is also important to know the maximum occupational exposure limit values ​​for benzene, vinyl chloride, hard wood dust, lead and its inorganic compounds, and asbestos. It is important that the strict limit values, for example for chromium compounds, lead, wood dust or crystalline silica, are complied with in all Member States. It is important that the monitoring of these substances is reliable, true and comparable in order to continuously educate employees on this issue. Finally, it is important to protect particularly vulnerable groups: pregnant women, nursing women, disabled and adolescents.

name: Paloma LÓPEZ BERMEJO
text: - Mr President, cancer is the leading cause of occupational mortality in the European Union. Each year 53% of occupational deaths are attributed to cancer, according to the Commission's own data. We continue to have limited information on carcinogens and levels of exposure. In addition, new risks appear, such as nanomaterials, which remain to be evaluated. Despite knowing the relationship between endocrine disruptors and cancer, the European Commission still does not comply with the ruling of the Court of Justice of the European Union and establish a clear and ambitious regulation of them. They are not analyzing how precarious working conditions - such as job rotation, part-time with fragmented hours - make it possible to have multiple exposures to carcinogenic substances and, in addition, these same conditions make it difficult to access prevention services, on the other hand affected by the reduction of the budgets dedicated to it. In many countries, ILO regulations on mandatory notification of workers exposed to carcinogens are not met, and this is especially relevant in small businesses. And, despite these data, we continue to make very little progress in establishing regulations that prevent these deaths from continuing. National registries must be created with data disaggregated by sex, age and jobs. We must avoid exposure, but also replace carcinogenic substances, expand specialized medical services and increase labor inspections, among many other aspects. But I want to emphasize, to finish, that it is also necessary to establish plans, strategies for the return to work of workers affected by cancer caused by work, since they end up suffering employment discrimination and, in the worst case, loss of employment. job.

name: Georges BACH
text: - Mr President, Commissioner Marianne Thyssen! The European Union has some of the highest health and safety standards at work in the world and we can be proud of that. However, this does not mean that we can rest on what we have already achieved and lean back comfortably. The world of work is constantly evolving, new technologies, new scientific findings, new studies show that substances that have been used for years without hesitation are carcinogenic and kill thousands of people. Asbestos is the best-known example of such a development. That is why I welcome and congratulate the Commission for responding to requests for a revision of the directive. I don't want to go into detail about the individual substances; Our colleagues have done that enough. We must hold on to the idea that measures to protect the health of workers are an investment and not just a cost. Investments that benefit workers and their health have a positive impact not only on company productivity, but also on society as a whole. Of course, companies - especially small and medium-sized ones - have to adapt to the new regulations. Sensible transition periods are therefore provided. The precautionary principle appears to me to be very important in this area and I also welcome the fact, as some colleagues have already said, that reprotoxic substances were included in the compromise. I hope that will be included in the scope as soon as possible. Finally, I would like to emphasize that, under pressure from Parliament, medical surveillance is seen as necessary after the end of work and to protect the health of those affected. Thanks again to my colleagues, also for their speedy work. We have a little more than one here Year a decent dossier works.I once again congratulate the Commission, also for having established the next steps so far.

name: Georgi PIRINSKI
text: - Mr President, thanks to the strong position of the European Parliament and personally to the rapporteur Marita Ulvskog, stricter restrictions have been agreed on some of the most common carcinogens, an obligation for the Commission to report on the effects of substances that impair the reproductive capacity of people, by the beginning of 2019 at the latest, as well as the introduction of mandatory health surveillance of workers at risk, including after the end of their employment. The result is much better prevention and the opportunity to save at least another 100,000 lives, as well as health surveillance for more than 20 million workers exposed to carcinogens. It is now the responsibility of the Member States to implement these new requirements in a timely manner.

name: Julie GIRLING
text: – Mr President, I want workplaces to be safe, irrespective of their setting. I want to maintain the EU’s reputation as a setter of very high standards, but I guess that on the day when this Parliament voted to disregard the overwhelming majority of scientific evidence and restrict the authorisation of glyphosate, perhaps it should come as no surprise that we are being asked to vote to lower acceptable limits on chromium 6, which similarly have no scientific basis.  In order to ensure ongoing protection and confidence in the system, and that is what this legislation is all about, we should ensure that decisions on substances and levels are robust and not political. They should be based on the scientific evidence.  I therefore regret the inclusion of this item in an otherwise largely sensible and commendable trilogue conclusion and I can only come to the conclusion that, sadly, I will not be able to vote in favour. I will have to abstain on that basis.

name: Danuta JAZŁOWIECKA
text: - Mr Chairman! Commissioner! For all of us, the issue of employee health and safety is of key importance and is our priority. Therefore, from the very beginning, the Polish delegation in the PPE group supported the European Commission's project on the protection of workers against the risk of exposure to carcinogens or mutagens. The limits proposed by the European Commission were based on reliable analyzes and an agreement developed between social partners. Unfortunately, during the work on this directive, there were attempts in Parliament to drastically tighten the limits contained in the initial draft, not necessarily resulting from the need to protect health. The consequences of such a restrictive approach could be very dangerous. There are too many cases when, when it is impossible to meet excessive requirements, some companies begin to violate the law, and this has a very negative effect on the health of employees. In most cases, we have found reasonable solutions, but I cannot agree with the solutions proposed primarily for hardwood dust. The compromise limit is too restrictive. In my country, sawmills and producers of wood products are mainly small and medium-sized entrepreneurs and the unjustified reduction of wood dust to two milligrams per cubic meter is impossible for them. The same is the case with chromium. I am convinced that, as Parliament, we should base our decisions on sound scientific research and, above all, encourage industry and scientists to seek alternative materials and methods of production, and give entrepreneurs, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, time to adapt. I thank the rapporteur for her involvement in the work on the report.

name: Siôn SIMON
text: – Mr President, I welcome this measure as far as it goes and congratulate Parliament’s rapporteur on a good piece of work which extends the scope to reprotoxics, which was a good thing to do, and which I understand meant that she felt it could not be extended further. But I have to say that we have to do something – if not in this measure, then in other measures – but we have to do something to address the exposure of healthcare workers to the dangers of the carcinogenic drugs that they administer.  There are hundreds and thousands of healthcare workers in the United Kingdom alone dying from leukaemia, suffering miscarriages and having appalling healthcare outcomes that are entirely preventable. The technology to prevent this exists quite easily, and is only not happening because of cost. That has to change. It is indefensible.

name: Anne SANDER
text: - Mr President, Commissioner, cancer does not end at company doors. In the European Union, it is even the leading cause of work-related mortality. The agreement reached, which revises certain limit values ​​for exposure to carcinogens and incorporates new ones, is therefore welcome. It will help to better protect our workers across the European Union. It will also set accessible goals for our small and medium-sized businesses. Among the elements of the agreement, I would like to highlight the work that has been done on silica dust, which is present in the majority of manufacturing and construction industries, and which has generated much debate. From my point of view, the value we have found is ambitious but pragmatic, and represents a significant advance for human health. It must go hand in hand with the pursuit of good prevention practices. It must also be accompanied by targeted research programs on reduction or substitution processes, where technically feasible. We also need better data collection, studies and long-term monitoring. Currently, the European Commission is working on new proposals to cover more carcinogens. I welcome this approach, which should be negotiated with the social partners to stick to reality, because I believe that this is how we can guarantee the effectiveness of the solutions proposed.

name: Elena GENTILE
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am convinced that one of the most qualifying objectives for the European institutions and for this Parliament is that of work: not only fairly paid work, not just policies that offer all Europeans the opportunity to build their ownlife project, but also and above all quality work for the health and well-being of the workers.There is no doubt: exposure to carcinogens is the number one cause of illness and death among unprotected workers.I would also like to emphasize the risk to which pregnant workers and all male and female workers are exposed when exposed to endocrine disrupting mutagens.Therefore, making the precautionary approach principle prevail is a choice of common sense, as well as, obviously, underlining the consideration of the need to promote an assessment of costs that heavily affect health care, but also social spending.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Mr President, protecting the health of people and workers is a priority for all of us, and given the free movement of workers throughout the European Union, it is, of course, appropriate for there to be uniform rules on working environment requirements. According to statistics, cancer is the second leading cause of death in Europe. It is clear that long-term exposure to certain substances in the workplace is definitely one of the risk factors. According to the European Agency for Safety and Health at Work, hundreds of thousands of deaths from occupational cancer occur in the European Union each year. Health problems and these losses are, of course, irreplaceable for human lives, but they can also be quantified economically, allegedly by the loss of four to six percent of gross domestic product. The new legislation is therefore intended to ensure better protection of workers' health by reducing their exposure to harmful chemicals in the workplace. The negotiated form is a balanced compromise for employers, who will eventually have to implement these measures. The directive proposes limits that are relatively strict and leaves room for further tightening, especially for substances such as crystalline silica, hexavalent chromium and wood dust. It is correct that both types of wood dust have also been included among these harmful substances, and low limits are justified due to the proven harmfulness. I support this compromise.

name: Karin KADENBACH
text: - Mr President, Commissioner! First of all, I would also like to thank all the negotiators, because I believe that the package that we now have on the table is one of which we can be very proud. In recent years we have done a lot to improve the health of Europeans. In this context I am thinking of the Tobacco Products Directive, but I am also thinking of the limitation of emissions from motor vehicles. Because all of this has contributed to the fact that lung cancer in particular is actively fought here. And when we speak today of the additional costs that companies could incur as a result of the implementation of this amended directive, then we must not ignore the costs of inaction. Failure to act would not only continue to bring great human suffering to the European Union, it would also put a heavy burden on our health and, above all, our health systems, and that is also at the expense of entrepreneurs, it is at the expense of the EU as a business location. That means we have done a lot for the people here, but we have also done a lot here for Europe as a business location.

name: Agnes JONGERIUS
text: - (NL) Mr President, you go to work whistling every morning and as soon as you can enjoy your retirement, asbestos cancer is diagnosed. Cancer as a result of the work you have done. It happens thousands of times in Europe every year. That is why I am so pleased with the report by my colleague Ulvskog. I think it contains good standards, stricter standards about harmful substances released during industrial production, including chromium (VI). And yet, there are industries that have strongly opposed these new rules, preferring to keep exposing their workers to harmful substances because it is cheaper. The same industries have been bothering the Commission for ten years about the stricter rules the Commission wanted to propose. I think that's embarrassing. I never thought I had to be the one to update business on the economy, but let me say, dead employees can't make a business profitable. It would suit the companies if they urged now to work urgently on the transposition of these new rules.

name: Nicola CAPUTO
text: - (IT) Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, cancer is the main cause of work-related mortality in the European Union, as much as 53%, a very worrying value in an advanced society like ours, which should ensure the health of citizens and workers. The protection of health in the workplace must actually become a priority on the European agenda. I therefore welcome the revision of the directive on carcinogens and mutagens, as it is essential for better protection of workers. However, I believe that the precautionary principle must be applied more incisively in our legal system. Individual potentially carcinogenic substances not yet included among those subject to exposure limits must also be assessed more carefully: I am thinking, for example, of endocrine disruptors. There is a need for closer cooperation between the European Union and the Member States, which should ensure clearer and more comprehensive data to allow the Union itself to promote best practices. Finally, the scope of the directive must also be extended to reprotoxic agents, which are treated too weakly by the directive on chemical agents despite being very dangerous for human health.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Mr President, cancer is a major cause of death for thousands of workers, with between two and three million workers exposed to toxic substances. Asbestos is a classic case, as are wood dust, chromium IV and crystalline silicon dioxide. Therefore, serious measures must be taken to address the problems posed by exposure to carcinogens in the workplace. And it is a given that Directive 98/24 / EC gives minimal protection to workers. We therefore need a tightening of legislation, very specific rules on limit values, an extension of the scope to include new cancer-causing substances, special protection for pregnant women, and mandatory lifelong medical monitoring of exposed workers. Because the European Parliament must send the message that workers' health is above corporate profits.

name: Julie WARD
text: – Mr President, 100 000 people die each year in Europe because of work—related cancer diseases. Whilst the Commission proposal is a good first step, we must broaden the scope of the directive, as suggested by the rapporteur, to allow for the inclusion reprotoxic substances, a growing problem in workplaces – especially for women. The French Agency for Food, Environment, Safety and Health indicated that 180 000 French workers have been exposed to such substances, which can cause all manner of reproductive issues for both female and male workers.  Improving workers’ health protection by reducing occupational exposure to chemical agents that may cause cancer or mutations should take into account specific issues and real situations, including adopting a gender perspective. I particularly want to highlight the role of trade unions and workers’ federations, who have been fighting for years on this issue and have provided excellent evidence for the drafting of this report and the preparation of this debate.

name: Tania GONZÁLEZ PEÑAS
text: - Mr President, cancer is the leading cause of work-related death, with more than 100,000 deaths in the European Union. For this reason, we must congratulate ourselves on this report and greater regulation to prevent cancer in the workplace. It is a step forward that toxic substances for reproduction are included in this proposal, but we must continue working to protect pregnant workers from the first weeks of pregnancy and prevent hormonal imbalances produced by these substances. This report contains many positive elements. However, ladies and gentlemen, this work of regulation on safety and health at work is of little use if the protocols are not followed and applied. This is the case of the forty-nine workers who in December 2012 suffered the most serious mercury poisoning in Europe at the Asturiana Zinc factory. An accident full of negligence: from risk assessment to protective equipment and also a medication that is given too late. Today they suffer serious consequences and are not even receiving the medical assistance they need. They continue to fight and from here we support them so that they receive that medical attention. But cases like this cannot be repeated.

name: Georgios EPITIDEIOS
text: - Mr President, cancer is the second leading cause of death in Europe and the first related to work. Unfortunately, poor working conditions expose workers to substances that are hazardous to their health, as well as to substances that are hazardous to their reproductive capacity. At a time when fertility is a huge threat even to all European countries, and given that work-related cancer can be prevented, European countries must respond. They must force companies to improve working conditions and protect workers from contact with substances that are dangerous to their health. They should also protect the fertility of men and women, and especially monitor pregnant women from the first moment of their pregnancy. Finally, they should monitor all workers who have been exposed to carcinogens for life. At this point, the financial costs involved in all these activities must not be taken into account. Human life is not valued in money.

name: Wajid KHAN
text: – Mr President, protecting people in the workplace is of the utmost importance, and while much has improved, 53% of work-related deaths are still caused by occupational cancer. In the days before the EU, it was the trade unions who stood up to protect workers from carcinogenic substances like asbestos, and now – thankfully – there is a directive with specific exposure limits. As a proud union man myself, I want to thank them for the role they have played and continue to play.  So about this report, which places limit values and 13 further carcinogens: given that around 50 carcinogens account for 80% of total exposure in the workplace, it is very welcome that the Commission plans to introduce limits for additional substances. Regular healthcare checks after exposure must continue for as long as it is necessary.  Finally, it is my hope that workers in manufacturing, construction and many other sectors will continue to be protected after Brexit because, after all, they are the lifeblood of our economy.

name: Marianne THYSSEN
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, once more, I would like to thank the rapporteur and the shadows for reaching a balanced compromise that will clearly make a difference for workers’ protection from now on. As always, we take note of your questions and remarks and, as I said, our work will not stop here. This legislative proposal is a first step in a series of forthcoming initiatives in this area.  I am pleased that in June this year the Council reached a general approach on our second proposal to amend the Directive. This confirms the political commitment of both the Commission and the Member States to fight occupational cancer. I count on the European Parliament to adopt its position on this second batch so that the interinstitutional negotiations should start as soon as possible.  Dear Members of Parliament, some of you mentioned diesel engine exhausts and that this is one of the 25 chemical agents evaluated that are of a major concern for causing occupational cancer. Why have we not yet proposed an occupational exposure limit (OEL)? Diesel engine exhaust is a complex issue, in particular in terms of defining exposure and identifying adequate measurement methods. It contains different components depending on the type of engine used. Identifying the engines that produce carcinogenic exhaust requires further analysis. The Commission is continuing its efforts to find the most appropriate action, and has the intention to include diesel engine emissions (DEE) in its forthcoming second phase consultation of the social partners with a view to considering to address DEE in the fourth batch. Work—related cancer is a real tragedy for workers and their families, and is at the same time a heavy burden for the whole of society. We now have a chance to make a real difference in people’s lives. The Commission counts on your support on these legislative files that aim to further fight occupational cancer. I invite you also to continue our constructive cooperation.  Thank you very much, and congratulations on the results of the trialogue.

name: Marita ULVSKOG
text: rapporteur. - Mr President! I would like to start by saying that all the limit values ​​that are included in our agreement are limit values ​​that already exist on a scientific basis in some of the member states, usually the richest member states. This means that in those EU countries that have had a more difficult path to economic strength, they lack that protection. And now we are proposing that the same level of ambition that we have in the richest parts of the EU should exist throughout the EU. I say this in polemics with a Member who is no longer here, who thought it was a misery that they should be forced into this non-carcinogenic showdown we are engaged in. This legislation is, as several of you have pointed out and as Commissioner Thyssen has also done, the first of several. From Parliament's side, I can promise that we will be very difficult. We will work to ensure that it comes as soon as possible, with as many important topics as possible. I take it that Commissioner Thyssen said the fourth round for diesel. We will probably try to work for a faster timetable for diesel, because it is one of the topics that is enormously important and where it is also the case that the social parties are deeply involved in the matter. But so far we have come a long way. We still have a lot to do, and from the committee's side we will continue to fight with this issue, which is so concrete and where it is actually possible to make a fantastic difference by working together to save lives.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The discussion is closed.The vote will take place on Wednesday 25 October 2017. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Ádám KÓSA
text: in writing. - For workers and their families, cancer causes not only a significant deterioration in the quality of life, but also the direct costs of public health care and direct and indirect material losses.
