Workplace cancers are having an impact on the economy as a whole, as they reduce labor supply and also put a strain on public finances, as more health care needs to be spent. Furthermore, we need to protect the productivity of aging workers for a sustainable society. At the same time, new regulations and limits, such as those on mutagens and those affecting reproduction, must be realistic, reasonable and realistic. In my view, the adoption of the package will not succeed in enforcing all these aspects at the same time, as the regulation of substances that reduce reproductive capacity would call for a separate piece of legislation due to its complexity or the lifelong control system, which puts SMEs in a more difficult position.

name: Romana TOMC
text: in writing.- Every year, more than 100,000 people die in the European Union as a result of work-related cancer.We have been waiting for more than 10 years for the legislation in this area to change.The revision of the existing rules will also ensure greater protection for workers.We require comprehensive examinations of workers, even after their retirement, as some symptoms do not appear until a few years after they have been exposed to the risk.Exposure to cancer-causing substances should be kept to a minimum.Any new research that shows new risks needs to be included in the legislation.

name: David Maria SASSOLI
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Soraya Post, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on fundamental rights aspects of Roma integration in the European Union: combating anti-Gypsyism(2017/2038 (INI)) (A8-0294 / 2017).

name: Soraya POST
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, my name is Soraya Post and I am a Roma woman from Sweden belonging to the Sinti group. I was born condemned. I have been a human rights activist for 40 years. So in 2014, when I got elected to represent the Swedish Feministiskt initiative, I took on the mission of safeguarding the principles of democracy, of spreading and defending fundamental human rights, gender equality and the respect of the basic values of our EU Treaties. One of my goals with this report is to place the situation of the Roma on the political agenda and to make real, tangible change at last. The EU is at a very critical point at the moment, and the destiny of 12 million people is not a priority. This clearly goes against the values of the EU. But this neglect is not a new phenomenon. It has been going on for 800 years. And the result is that now, in 2017, the situation of the Roma people is not better than in third countries. And, as I said, following my mission, I want to fight against injustice and inequality. This is not an easy task. The last time we had a debate on Roma issues in this Chamber in April, three MEPs took the opportunity to spread hate speech. And, although we have strengthened the Rules of Procedure of the European Parliament, the President of the European Parliament failed to react, failed to condemn and sanction hate speech. I was not very surprised. Roma people have been neglected, discriminated against, stigmatised, excluded and dehumanised for 800 years. We have never been good enough for European societies to accept us as equal citizens with guaranteed equal access to our fundamental human rights. The result is clear to see in all the shocking reports of the EU Agency for Fundamental Rights and NGOs. Anti-Gypsyism, the specific form of racism directed against the Roma, was first recognised in the European Parliament in 2015 through our resolution. Anti-Gypsyism, however unconscious it might be, can be revealed in the EU acquis as well, which often fails to take into consideration the realities and challenges of Roma, who are unable to enjoy the same rights and opportunities and the same level of protection as other EU citizens. Until we manage to remedy anti-Gypsyism, the root cause of the unacceptable situation that Roma are still facing in Europe in 2017, we will not see any improvement, even if the European Commission initiates good programmes. Is there a need to improve this situation? Yes. Is there a way to improve this situation? Yes. Is there a way out of mistrust from both sides? Yes, of course there is. My report, which has been the first European Parliament report addressing anti-Gypsyism on a wide scale, lists 12 pages of demands and recommendations, of which I will only mention a few. We demand the setting up of truth and reconciliation commissions at Member State and EU-level to acknowledge the persecution, exclusion and disownment of Roma throughout the centuries: to document these in an official white paper and to make the history of Roma part of the curricula in schools, which is crucial for creating trust. We deplore the violation of the right of Roma to free movement. We also call on the Member States of origin to take their responsibility to combat poverty and exclusion of all their citizens, and on the Member States of arrival to increase cooperation across borders to combat discrimination and exploitation and prevent exclusion continuing in the country of arrival. We demand active, meaningful participation for Roma at all levels. We call on the Court of Auditors to check the performance of EU programmes, as they seem to fail to reach out to the most disadvantaged. We call for compensation for Roma women having been subject to forced sterilisation. We call for the continuation of an improved EU framework for national Roma integration strategies after 2020. We call on the Commission for the introduction of anti-discrimination indicators in the field of education, employment, housing and health, as anti-Gypsyism undermines the successful implementation of the national Roma strategies. And we call on the Commission to treat anti-Gypsyism as a horizontal issue and develop an inventory of practical steps to combat anti-Gypsyism.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to start by thanking the rapporteur and Parliament for the continued support to the Roma integration process. The 2011 resolution of the European Parliament played a key role in the launching of the EU framework for national Roma integration strategies up to 2020. Today, I particularly want to thank Soraya Post for her relentless and tireless work in this field – not only in this report, but for the work you do in general.  This report, as the rapporteur says, rightly highlights anti-Gypsyism, which is being felt in our society through anti-Roma hate speech, growing terms of segregation and forced evictions. Anti-Gypsyism and socioeconomic exclusion go hand in hand, so we must tackle these together. Many parts of the report confirm the conclusions we also made in the mid-term review – improvements in education, this is key of course. Fewer Roma leave school early and more Roma children participate today in early childhood education. However, segregation in education has persisted, and the situation has deteriorated. In several Member States, the majority of Roma children attend classes where most – or almost all – classmates are Roma. Educating Roma children in segregated settings prevent them from equal chances to participate in later higher quality education and from gaining access to the labour market, and this is why the Commission launched infringements: to ensure effective, equal access for Roma to a quality, inclusive, mainstream education.  I am also grateful that the report recognises existing efforts and calls for continued action from the Commission’s side in several areas. For instance, it explicitly calls for the extension of the Joint Programme on Access to Justice for Roma and Traveller Women, piloted since last year in five Member States by the Commission and the Council of Europe. The aim is to empower Roma women, improve their access to justice and fight the multi—faceted discrimination that they encounter. These are all priority areas highlighted by the report.  The report’s call for setting up a truth and reconciliation commission is welcome. These bodies, focusing on national histories and engaging directly with societies, are of course best placed at national level. This process should be Roma-led, with the involvement of other stakeholders as well. Thus, and given its mandate, the newly set—up European Roma Institute of Arts and Culture could be well positioned, rather than the Commission playing a leading role in this process, and we are of course ready to support this.  There are many very valuable proposals in this report. We would like to thank again the rapporteur and the Committee for the work that you have done, and we look forward to the discussion.

name: Malin BJÖRK
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. - Mr President! First of all, I want to say thank you to you Soraya Post. We are fortunate in the Parliament that has you leading this work. I am pleased to have been able to lead the work of the Gender Equality Committee, where we have produced recommendations that specifically address the vulnerable situation of women and girls. It is the case that structural anti-Gypsyism hits women and girls extra hard. The situation is unacceptable, but above all one can feel that what is most unacceptable is the absence of political action. That is what this report is trying to do. In the Gender Equality Committee, we want to see targeted efforts to strengthen the rights and situation of Roma women, and that is an important part of the political response to fighting anti-Gypsyism. We want to see investments in good health care, especially sexual and reproductive health and rights, good abortion care, good contraception, good maternity care. It should be a matter of course, but it is not today. Children should have the right to schooling, also when they travel around and when they work in Sweden, for example. Investing in Roma women, as I said, is part of an important and concrete way to combat structural anti-Gypsyism. Colleagues, anti-Gypsyism, just as the Soraya Post said, it is undemocratic, it is unworthy and we will not give up until it is eradicated.

name: Pál CSÁKY
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. - On behalf of the European People's Party, I welcome this material. I think it is important that such a document was born in the European Parliament. I thank Mrs Post for her cooperation, who can confirm that the European People's Party has been very active in drafting the amendments and finalizing the report. The essence of this report is to try to introduce a new approach to Roma policies so far. For years and decades, the issue of Roma integration has been on the agenda of almost every Member State. Different approaches, insights, ideas, strategies have come to light, but unfortunately no breakthrough has occurred in the issue. We must say that raising the issue to a European level has not brought the hope that has been placed in it so far, although it must be admitted that progress has been made and without it the situation would be even worse. The essence of the current report is that it focuses on anti-Gypsyism as a phenomenon. As long as we fight this phenomenon and take measures that will be positive in the areas of housing, employment and health, as well as education, there is a chance that we will be able to get out of the current situation. This is because when anti-Roma sentiment is deeply ingrained in the strata of society, it is very difficult to move forward in other areas as well. Finally, I also consider it important that the Central and Eastern European context of the issue is included in the material. I sought and worked on the opinions of Hungarian, Slovak and Czech experts, and I am pleased that the issue of Roma settlements, which are primarily the problems of Romania, Bulgaria and Slovakia, has also been addressed, and we call for solutions to be developed. the governments of those three countries.

name: Josef WEIDENHOLZER
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. - Mister President! We are having a very important debate today. Roma and Sinti are the largest ethnic minority in Europe - 20 million live in all Member States. So you are the only pan-European minority. Many Member States have fewer inhabitants. Roma have been discriminated against for many generations. During the Nazi era you were exposed to a cruel Holocaust about which far too little is talked about. Not least because of this, Europe has a political obligation towards this ethnic group. The Charter of Fundamental Rights in particular obliges us to stand up against all forms of discrimination and degradation. The Soraya Post report is a very important contribution because it takes a holistic approach and places the task of integrating the Roma under the primacy of fundamental rights. Yes, it is about much more than just social policy measures, for which sufficient funds must be made available in an efficient manner. It is about an inclusive approach that treats the Roma as an important and equal part of the population - without discrimination. It is therefore also reprehensible to play Roma against the so-called indigenous poor. Anyone who needs help is in need of help, be it access to the labor market, education or looking for a place to live. The same principles apply to everyone. We are grateful to Soraya Post for taking this approach and taking it with verve. A country's civilizational progress can be seen in the way that country treats its Roma population, and there is still a lot to be done. Above all, we have to fight antigypsyism.

name: Branislav ŠKRIPEK
text: on behalf of the ECR Group - Mr President. I appreciate the creation of this report. I also thank Mrs Soraya Post for her efforts and for taking a long time to make various changes to this report in the meetings. As shadow rapporteur, I understand the need to deal with discrimination, which is crucial for any advanced society. But I understand this also because I met this community of people in Slovakia and I was able to work actively with it. And I also saw various interesting things. I must emphasize at this point that we are all equal before God in our human dignity, and therefore the position of the Roma in Europe, as well as their involvement in society, we must pay due attention and we must do much to make them work well in society. every single country, especially in our Member States. We in Slovakia have a big problem. Our Roma community is huge and we are a small country of five and a half million. We have five hundred thousand Roma who report as Roma. And yet, I think that this report will have little effect on the lives of the Roma, because it does little to emphasize the need to get involved, for themselves. And I see them as an essential part of the solution. They need to know how to be involved in the process. We in Slovakia have good examples when the Roma have taken their destiny into their own hands and simply taken responsibility for their lives and results. With the help of various Christian organizations, they showed a great ability to begin to help themselves, their weaker, poorer people, and became people of hope. And not only for the Roma, but also for the people around them. So I look forward to a time when the Roma will not be a problem, but they will bring solutions to unemployment and community development of family building.

name: Marina ALBIOL GUZMÁN
text: on behalf of the GUE / NGL Group. - Madam President, the reality is that the Roma people continue to suffer discrimination and racism in our countries, discrimination in access to housing, segregation in schools - which in countries such as Hungary, Bulgaria or Slovakia reaches 60% -, a higher incarceration rate or forced sterilization. All of these are not specific cases. Anti-Gypsyism permeates our society and, therefore, also our state and European institutions and also the media. There we have the example of Spain, where television programs, such as Los Gipsy Kings or My Great Gypsy Wedding, collaborate in the maintenance of stereotypes and promote hate speech. This report recognizes anti-Gypsyism as a systemic form of racism, an essential recognition to be able to begin to change the entire policy approach. It is essential, for example, to end the austerity policies and cuts in public services that guarantee equity. We will never achieve equality if the State does not put in place the mechanisms to guarantee it. And in the fight against romaphobia, we should start with this Parliament, where on too many occasions we have heard stigmatizing speeches, even calls for violence, without any subsequent condemnation from this House.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: for the Verts / ALE Group. - Madam President! I would also like to begin by thanking the Soraya Post for an extremely good report and also the shadow rapporteurs for their good cooperation. We have a lot to be ashamed of in Europe when it comes to how we have handled and in many cases still handle the Roma in our countries. That is why it is important that we draw attention not only to the Member States and the Commission, but also to ourselves, for the prejudices that we have learned many times since childhood. We need to understand where they come from in order to change. We must also realize that the long discrimination the Roma have been and are being subjected to has a price. The prize is primarily about us actually acknowledging what we have done and doing and apologizing for it. Restoration is essential to achieve reconciliation and to build trust. An important step would be to designate August 2 as a day of remembrance for the victims of the Holocaust and also to make amends to the survivors. There is still a lot to do in Europe and in the world. Today's debate does not solve the problems of the Roma, but it is a step towards a more inclusive and accepting Europe, where the Roma are not allowed to be treated differently and where the governments of the Member States fulfill their obligations to give all citizens equal treatment. But in order to achieve results, stronger protection legislation is needed, based on the various conventions we already have and the EU's core values. Financial incentives have not helped so far, but what we perhaps need to work on most is a change in our attitude, the majority. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question) under Rule 162 (8).

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: a question asked by raising a blue card.- Madam colleague, I agree that there are many things that need to be improved, but I do not agree that we should just be ashamed.Here, my colleague Škripek pointed out a moment ago that there are a number of things that have succeeded.I want to ask you: do you really just have to be ashamed or do you have an example of good practice?Do not tell me that nothing has been done at all in your country against discrimination against Roma citizens.

name: Bodil VALERO
text: answer (“blue card”).- Of course, there are many examples of good practice.In Sweden, we have worked very actively, including the White Paper.But we have 800 or maybe more years behind us where we have a lot to be ashamed of and where we still have not made up for our history, also for example when it comes to forced sterilizations etc. In some countries we have actually taken a step to cometo right this reconciliation but there is an enormous amount left to do.There is what is good, what is going on, but there is much that we have to be ashamed of and where we have still not apologized.

name: Gilles LEBRETON
text: on behalf of the ENF group. - Madam President, the Roma often arouse a feeling of rejection in Europe. They are even victims of discrimination in some states. Yet they have been present in Europe for several centuries, as their ancestors from India arrived there in the wake of the Mongols, but their nomadic way of life has never allowed them to integrate. The Post report is therefore right to be concerned about their fate; some of his proposals are reasonable. It calls, for example, on states to condemn certain barbaric practices, such as the forced sterilization of Roma women or the illegal removal of Roma children from their parents. It also has the merit of asking the Union to deprive the states which persecute the Roma of certain European funds. Unfortunately, the Post report also has several flaws. He is instrumentalizing, for example, the Roma to carry out a new attack on the freedom of expression of nationalist MEPs. Above all, he condemns the approach of trying to assimilate the Roma, whom he describes as "paternalistic". However, I am in favor of the policy of assimilation of the Roma by their State of nationality, because I observe that, all over the world, communitarianism is destabilizing and fragmenting societies. Respecting the Roma presupposes their assimilation and not their condemnation for eternity to remain a group apart.

name: Anna ZÁBORSKÁ
text: - Madam President. I welcome the fact that the report presented also recalls the historical debt that the majority communities have towards the Roma. It is important to recall the centuries of segregation and prejudice that have repeatedly led to violence, from pogroms to the systematic murder of Roma in extermination camps. Only through knowledge of this aspect of the past can younger generations in particular understand the responsibility of the majority to which they belong for the current state of mutual coexistence. Its most visible manifestation is the existence of excluded communities in several Member States. It is precisely the images of living in extreme poverty that feed the prejudices about the Roma, distrust and feelings of superiority among the majority. The situation is improving, but it is still not good. Poverty is hereditary. A child born in conditions of real poverty has statistically little chance of obtaining a quality education and a well-paid job. The fight against extreme poverty is therefore a basic condition for integration. This struggle is not just about the Roma, but about all those who live on the margins of society and cannot stand on their own two feet. The historical questioning of the majority's conscience in relation to the Roma should therefore be independent of practical steps to tackle poverty and social exclusion. The Union and its Member States have a commitment to every citizen of the European Union to do everything in their power to live in dignity. In order to respect his human dignity. Regardless of whether he is Slovak, Hungarian, French, Roma or German.

name: Juan Fernando LÓPEZ AGUILAR
text: - Madam President, Commissioner, it is true: the Roma people - no less than 20 million people in Europe - have historically been besieged by the most humiliating stereotypes, and have been linked, in a stigmatizing discourse, to crime, with the lack of training or with social conflict. And we have had to listen here, in this European Parliament, to the most miserable expressions of those prejudices on the part of some really reprehensible speeches that would have received and deserved parliamentary sanction immediately. But this discourse has contributed to their social exclusion and, therefore, it is essential to become aware of the extent to which a relaunch of the will of Europeans and their Member States for integration is needed to promote job opportunities and education and combat the deficit of incorporation into training cycles, looking particularly at those most vulnerable people - women, minors - who therefore suffer from a double deficit of social exclusion. And I want to thank the work done by our colleague Soraya Post, who honors this European Parliament with her commitment against anti-Gypsyism and against all forms of Romaphobia.

name: Anders Primdahl VISTISEN
text: - Madam President! The challenges surrounding the Roma people in Europe are historical and profound, but do not change the fact that it is first and foremost a national task to stand for the integration of the Roma people in the various nation states. Nor does it change the fact that, although we in the EU have already spent a great deal of money on solving this problem, we have not come as far as one might have hoped. There should therefore be a reflection in this House on whether more money is really the best way to go when it comes to improving Roma integration in the individual nation states. Finally, the experience from my own home country, Denmark, where we have not historically had a Roma population, is that there is an abuse of EU rules for migrant workers for a group of Roma who come and do not have a real desire to work, but uses the system to set up camps in Denmark. That is not the intention of the migrant workers. It is therefore not something that should be accepted by the European Union either.

name: Michaela ŠOJDROVÁ
text: - Colleagues, the Roma are our fellow citizens and I personally have many friends among them. They have their traditions, language, mentality. But above all, they have the same rights and obligations as all EU citizens. I am aware that in some areas their integration is very slow. Obstacles persist, but these are usually on both sides. Of course, the state has a responsibility to enforce its rights, and the European Parliament rightly appeals to the Member States with a number of demands to improve the situation of Roma citizens, especially in countries where integration is failing. The report presented is very critical, as if all the countries in the EU have just been passively looking at discrimination against their citizens. As if everything was just negative, but that's not true! I must emphatically defend myself from the position of Member of Parliament for the Czech Republic. Personally, I worked for 3 years on the project Equality and Quality in Education and I monitored the education of disadvantaged children, including Roma. I can confirm that some small Roma children are discriminated against, but above all by their own parents, who do not take them to kindergarten, do not take them to primary school. I'm not saying all parents because I know many families where the situation is changing. But if more than 50% of Roma children do not prepare for primary school, then they will also fail in it and drop out early. To prevent this, we have introduced compulsory pre-school education from the age of 5 this school year, and we have introduced support measures to help overcome these obstacles to the integration of disadvantaged children. We changed the legislation, increased the budget to help these children get a better start in life than their parents had. This year, the Czech government decided to renovate the place of worship of the Roma Holocaust, to buy a pigsty in Lety. I am proud that it is the Minister for the KDU-ČSL who will rectify this historical injustice. Colleagues, let us have the courage to criticize, but also to acknowledge examples of good practice.

name: Péter NIEDERMÜLLER
text: - Ms. President! We all know that Europe's most vulnerable and most disadvantaged minority is also Europe's largest and largest minority. These are the Roma in Europe, who are as much citizens of the European Union as any of us. Yet they are often forced to live in quite different, inhuman, degrading conditions. Roma can be deported if a municipality so wishes, Roma children can be taught in run-down schools, segregated classes, Roma can be deprived of social benefits arbitrarily, and hardly anyone has a say in their interests. For a significant number of Roma people, Europe is not about protection, security, but humiliation, exclusion and hopelessness. We have said so many times that it is all unacceptable, both morally and politically. Yet hardly anything is happening, although all that is needed is respect for human dignity, the creation of an inclusive society and the inclusion of Roma in European societies.

name: Angel DZHAMBAZKI
text: - Madam President, colleagues, Honorable Rapporteur, I find the report to be extremely one-sided, unbalanced and misleading. Member States are accused and criticized for different treatment, prejudice, deliberate deprivation of access to education, housing and, in general, the violation of different types of rights. I do not agree with the suggestions made in the report, nor with the proposal for a common approach and common brackets. I give a few examples that are completely incomprehensible to me: "discrimination on housing, forced evictions on racial grounds and the destruction of homes without an alternative". Dear colleagues, have you heard of private property? And how would you react if someone moved into your home? I guess in a different way. "40% of respondents have to climb fences, cross highways or encounter stray dogs in their daily efforts to get water." Does anyone seriously claim this? This is absolutely frivolous. "Several hospitals in Hungary, Romania and Bulgaria have segregated and non-compliant maternity wards." I argue that this needs to be proven. I heard here that forced sterilization was taking place. This is slander and a lie. "Forced operation." Colleagues, this is written in the Orwell era, this is cultural Marxism and unacceptable Bolshevism.

name: Agnieszka KOZŁOWSKA
text: - Madam President! Discrimination against Roma is a fact and an embarrassing fact. Despite special programs and policies for spending money, we did not achieve the satisfactory results, as we expected, because a large part of the Roma community still suffers from poverty, because of unemployment, lives in poor conditions, and the report describes it quite precisely. There are many numbers that exactly illustrate this state of affairs. Moreover, stereotypes and prejudices overlap with all these inadequacies, creating a vicious circle from which it is very difficult to get out. And after all, Roma identity, Roma history and the Roma holocaust should not only be the subject of experts' talks, but should simply be part of our lives. Therefore, I welcome the report under discussion today as it presents a new approach, a new language to the Roma issue, and stresses the importance of mutual trust and encourages the Member States and the European Commission to build it up. I believe that this is the key to understanding this report and its message. This report aims to actively involve Roma in social, political and cultural life by consulting with representatives of the Roma community, supporting leadership, educating and supporting young leaders of the Roma community and, above all, moving from a paternalistic attitude to a full partnership. The first step in this direction is the audit of programs implemented in the Member States, as proposed in the report. These programs have been implemented with full commitment for years, so it is worth taking a look at them to see why they are not as effective as we would like and look for new solutions, e.g. by involving the Roma beneficiaries in this assessment.

name: Csaba SÓGOR
text: - Ms. President! The report is truly comprehensive, based on a detailed overview of the Roma integration process and anti-Gypsyism. I would like to highlight in particular the Commission's call for practical steps to be taken to combat anti-Gypsyism and for it to be drawn up on the basis of national Roma integration strategies, successful local practices and programs. Within each country, it is necessary to apply practices appropriate to the specific situation. Significant progress has been made in Romania in reducing the drop-out rate, but it is almost inappropriate if this does not extend to the compulsory 10th grade, which is a condition for most employment. Students should be relieved of the burden of family maintenance, and I see the need for the consent of Roma experts and school mediators. At the same time, intervention plans should not target the individual but the family, otherwise a symbiosis will develop between childcare support and family support. I would recommend equal access to support and Roma integration with the involvement and development of the whole community, otherwise the measures could even lead to conflicts. At the same time, we should provide social benefits as an active means of inclusion in the labor market, as this is the only way to break the trap of passive benefits.

name: Lívia JÁRÓKA
text: - Ms. President! I would also like to thank the committee for its kind words, and I am glad that Cecilia Malmström is here, who helped a lot with the Roma strategy at the time, and we already knew that digitalisation was essential in order to combat 'anti-gipsism', anti-Gypsyism. . That is why I would like to suggest that a digital case reporting system be introduced in the national equality bodies and in the Equinet system. I see anti-Roma sentiment in Europe today because there are no common ground. My parents met in a common workplace, today there is a lack of common schools, common jobs. So the first thing we need to create are common places. We have a common history, a common economy, we have been Europeans together for 800 years. Roma are not Indians, Europeans, we have the right to write our own history and teach it to our children, it is necessary for them to be able to teach our children in our own language, and I suggest that we look at countries with really strong anti-Roma sentiment. . At that time, Hungary was attacked for the Hungarian Guard, we stopped the Hungarian Guard immediately, but it is shocking to me that in your country, Sweden, for example, the Nazi party was equally intimidated on the streets, and that is very…. (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Julie WARD
text: – Madam President, Roma, across Europe, including in my country, face countless problems such as unemployment, poor access to public services, notably education, health and housing, multiple forms of discrimination and social, cultural and economic exclusion. This situation has worsened in the UK since the referendum with Roma children in Manchester, for example, too afraid to play outdoors because of racist attacks. I fully support Soraya Post’s position and agree that the problems related to Roma discrimination must be addressed through a rights-based approach. We are talking about the respect of the human rights of Roma people who have been living in Europe for centuries. The EU has a responsibility to go beyond the social inclusion aspect. We need a global strategy and a transversal approach if we really want to make a difference. I want to focus particularly on Rome women who find themselves at the intersection between anti-Gypsyism and sexism. As a founder of the Elie Wiesel parliamentary network to raise awareness of genocide, I particularly welcome Soraya’s call for a truth commission on the Roma Holocaust.

name: Notis MARIAS
text: - Madam President, gypsy phobia is on the agenda in many countries of the European Union. It is due to prejudices and stereotypes. Let us not forget the dozens of pogroms, historically, that were made against the Roma and, of course, we must not forget the millions of Roma who were killed in the Nazi concentration camps. Therefore, measures need to be taken to support the Roma, to combat discrimination, to address stereotypes and to integrate. And this can be done mainly through education and the creation of conditions of trust. At the same time, I believe that the Roma community must also assume its own responsibilities, it must not be exploited, especially by various political parties that use them only for elections, in order to get votes. At the same time, they should not fall victim to tactics that take their own funds and use them without these funds going to the benefit of the Roma themselves. We must therefore take all these aspects seriously.

name: Benedek JÁVOR
text: - First of all, I would like to thank Mrs Soraya Post for her excellent report and for her cooperation in her work to protect the interests of the Roma. I would like to draw attention to a single element of this report. There have been views here in today's debate that the Commission, the European institutions, should not have a say in the affairs of the Member States and should not comment on the issue of Roma integration, these are the responsibilities of the Member States. However, the Commission is intervening in these matters in a number of ways. Among other things, by allocating and disbursing European funds for this purpose. However, the money that - the European money that the Member States use for the sake of Roma integration, for the catching up of the Roma - very often fails. They do not actually reach the most vulnerable groups, they are not used properly by the Member States, they disappear hand in hand, so the Commission must do everything in its power to ensure that this money is used effectively and profitably for the benefit of the Roma community.

name: Cecilia MALMSTRÖM
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, it is extremely timely that we have this comprehensive report on anti-Gypsyism, which not only describes the problem but also comes with concrete ideas. The Commission supports the creation and development of national Roma platforms to ensure the inclusive involvement of stakeholders in both implementation and in monitoring. As you know, this year we launched the Roma civil monitor project and it is supposed to promote civil society capacity building. Today, over 90 NGOs are involved. Roma participation here is, of course, a key element. We also support the efforts of the European Parliament and the proposal in the report to commemorate the Roma Holocaust, and we have called upon Member States to commemorate this on 2 August. As you know, the Commission has participated in several events on 2 August, but also 27 January, which is Holocaust Memorial Day, in order to commemorate the victims of the Roma Holocaust, and I think that would be a good thing. Lately, efforts have been made to try to improve the effectiveness of the different funds with increased Roma participation, as well as increased efforts to make sure that they reach the intended recipients and to fight fraud in this regard. As you know, we have a variety of legal tools to fight discrimination and hate speech, and we will continue to do so. These are good, they are very good. We will continue to open infringement proceedings against those countries which discriminate, for instance, against Roma children in education. We had a few other cases as well that we are looking at and we will continue to do so. That is the role of the Commission and we will take that role very seriously. So, we have tools of many kinds, but as Ms Post correctly says, legal tools, laws, all that is important, but what is most important is people’s attitudes. So we need to keep on fighting hate speech and pure discrimination of course, that goes without saying. But what is also very important is awareness-raising, information, education, inclusion and measures to prevent daily prejudices and the stereotypes that also lead to hate speech and hate crime. In this fight there are a lot of things to do, but I think the report is a very important tool, and I want to thank Ms Post for the work that she has done.

name: Soraya POST
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I would like to thank all colleagues for their comments and for all their dedicated work. I would also like to show my gratitude to my shadows – Bodil Valero, Cecilia Wikström, Marina Albiol, Pál Csáky and Branislav Škripek – and their advisers, assistants, and the secretariat of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE). I would also like to thank the Committee on Women’s Rights and Gender Equality (FEMM), which gave a lot of input, so I feel very comfortable not putting all my energy into all that, because I know they will do their work. I am also very grateful for the input received from experts and NGOs, who are working day by day to make the desperately needed changes. It is our obligation as politicians to safeguard the human rights of all people. Otherwise, we cannot uphold the values of the EU or talk about democracy. All EU citizens have a responsibility to act and to react to injustice. We have to show will and commitment to make a change. Twelve million Roma are considered second-class citizens, and 800 years of human rights deprivation and harassment is enough. We cannot stay in the Middle Ages in 2017. I hope you all agree. So let us make this change together because we can only do this together, with huge trust in each other, if we want to make a change. I wanted to respond to Mr Dzhambazki’s input and tell him that I did not expect him to like my report.

name: Sylvie GUILLAUME
text: The debate is closed.The vote will take place on Wednesday.Written statements (Article 162)

name: Jaromír KOHLÍČEK
text: in writing. - Mrs Soraya Post's report contains a lot of interesting statements taken from various articles, which, regardless of the examination of the reasons, generally represent the subjective opinions of the authors. A classic example is the arbitrary determination of who is considered a Roma. As a rule, all socially excluded persons in a given state are politically incorrectly labeled in this way. In the Czech Republic, just over 5,000 citizens registered as Roma in 2010, while approximately 500 Roma children studied in special education. Paragraph 20 of the report calls on Member States to address migration bias against Roma refugees and asylum seekers from the Western Balkans, many of whom are Roma, which may be related to specific factors affecting the local Roma community. Point 21 expresses deep concern at the number of stateless Roma in Europe. The author completely ignores the existence of tens of thousands of non-citizens in Latvia and Estonia. Paragraph 29 calls on Member States to set up hate crime units within the police force. I believe that such an approach would create inequality before the law and that it is therefore contrary to basic EU standards. There are 90 recognized national minorities in the EU, and the author apparently chose one of them with the intention of defaming certain EU states.
